caramel coffee and chocolate malts with some roasty smoky flavor too along with a slight hoppiness in the aroma..very dark brown with tan head and some lacing..tastes of coffee caramel dark chocolate milk mostly with a hint of piney hops and smoke..medium bodied tingly and sweet even a bit creamy..overall watch it disappear very drinkable and flavorful

Pours black with a dissipating tan head. The aroma is of toast, dried fruit, leather and some alcohol. The taste is very well balanced - up front, toasty and complex malt, medium body that accentuates the richness of the malt, slight bitter hop and chocolate finish to kill the sweetness. This is great.

Extra in a trade from Jstax, Thanks buddy! Pour is black with a dark tan bubbly head..Nose is rich fudge,roast,sweetmess, chocolate candy..Taste is fudge,peanut butter,sweet chocolate,roast,candy..Palate is sweet, rich cbocolate cake

Damn good beer!  Almost no head which was surprising.  Good aroma but I have a head cold so Im sure it was muted.  Pitch black color from where I was viewing it.  Amazingly subtle changes in flavor and everyone of them is great.  Thick, roasted, malty finish that sticks around in a great way.
Bottle. Pours black with very thin bubbly tan head. Heavy roasted malt, dark chocolate, and burnt brown sugar on the nose. Finishes with a grassy hop bitterness that lingers nicely. Excellent porter.
Pours out dark with a quickly disbursing head.  Rich aroma of whole grains, toast and coffee.  Full flavors of toast, coffee with a nice bitter finish with notes of resin and citrus.
12oz bottle from Binnys Depot in Chicago. Dark brown colour with slight tan head, nice sweet roasted malt and balanced hop bitter.

The initial smell is absolutely wonderful.  Dark, chocolaty, sexy, and marshmallowy.  I am drinking it on a clean palate at this moment in hopes of tasting all the dark notes in the brew.  I like how dark the appearance was in my little batman beer mug.  Very "the night".  
The finish flavor on the tongue is very chocolaty and cocoa. 
Yum!
Bottle->stem.  Almost black, substantial tan head.  Matls and chocolate nose.  Great roasted malt flavor with chocolate, fruit, and spices.  Bitter aftertaste is just righht.  Fantastic.

Bottle 12 oz, bottled 07/12/12. Pours dark brown in color wih thin bubbly tan head. Milk chocolate, roasted malts in aroma. Quite strongly roasted malts, some salty licorice and sligtly burnt wood. Some houseflavor yeast notes also. Salty licorice in aftertaste. Regular porter, nothing to hang in the christmas tree.

Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and hints of dark fruit. Pours black with  no head or lacing. Taste is medium bitter with chocolate and hints of coffee. Clean hopped finish and no aftertaste. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Fizzy. Overall, while an enjoyable porter, the taste was not all that complex, but I would drink it again.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2012 Bottled. Pours deep brown with a medium sized tan head, fair lacing. Nose of roasted malts, coffee and dark fruit. Sweet flavor of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and brown sugar, the finish is slightly bitter. Full bodied, oily to creamy texture and soft CO2. A pleasant and very enjoyable porter. ★★★★

Dark black and thin tan head.  Roast, caramel, and  coffee aroma notes.  Full bodied, taste like aroma, roast & bitter notes pronounced at finish.  Decent balance with medium bitter finish.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle to glass. Pretty flavorful & complex for a porter. Chocolate, mild coffee, some slight bitterness. I think the tag-line is dead on! One of my new favorite porters- just wish we could get it in AZ!

12 oz bottle.  Pours black with long lasting, beige head.  Aroma is of bready, toasted malt, chocolate and hints of dark fruit.  Body is medium and creamy.  Taste is toasted malt, dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee and citrusy hops.  Finish is long and bitter. Great porter.
UPDATED: OCT 16, 2012 Pours black like a old viscous motor oil with a thin creamy beige head. Chocolate pie in aroma with some licorice and vanilla.

Sixer from Beer Universe Saugerties.  A robust and roasty porter.  Black body, deeper tan head.  Easily consumable at 6.5...I had three and am content with my injuries of the day.  Yes this is a sexy beer.

Upon my first sip, I knew that this is a superb beer. Pours black with a manageable head that isnt so big that I have to wait forever before I can drink. Nice dark roasty flavor, full body, hints of chocolate and smoke. Nice label too!
Bottled. Pitch Black coloured. Dense light Brown head.aroma. Chocolate, roast, Cocoa, herbs, Spice. Flavour. Chocolate, roast, coffee, Cocoa, herbs, Spice. Medium to full bodied. Ends roasted bitter.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2013  Bottle at bar. Black color, beige head. Strong malty taste with chocolate, coffee, liquorice and nuts. Excellent porter.
Perfect. Thick, sweet, chocolatey and a hint of coffee. One could almost mistake it for a milk stout. I was real sad when it was gone.

Ar: Lots of cocoa and slightly burnt caramel - a hint of vanilla.
Ap: Black and opaque - small tan head with poor retention and a thin ring of foam.
T: Burnt coffee, some charcoal - medium sweet - deep caramel, some ash, molasses - medium-low bitterness couples with the roast - finish is smoky with lots of coffee notes lingering.
P: Medium-full body with medium carbonation - somewhat thick - finish is medium-dry.
O: A decidedly bold porter filled with coffee, chocolate, and all sorts of roast - very satisfying and all-around well-made.

(Bottle, 0.355 l, at Angleterre, 20121010) The beer poured black. Its head was medium sized and lighlty brown. Aroma had coffee, roasted malts, burnt malts, lightly smoke and some amount of chocolate. Palate was full bodied and oily with medium carbonation. Flavours were roasted malts, burnt malts, chocolate, sweetness, hops and bitterness. Aftertaste was long lasting and it had chocolate, roasted malts and bitterness. A very balanced and mouth-filling porter.

Bottle. The Room SoHo. Yeah this is a good one. all around really tasty porter. dark chocolate and vanilla aroma. drinks super clean and surprisingly lightly. not overtly sweet but has a
nice dark licorice note that I presume
comes from some mixture of the chocolate malts and hops. I could drink this one all night. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2012 Deep black pour. Robust roasty aroma with coffee. Robust mouthfeel and nice mocha taste. Very good porter, one of my favorites as with most any other Founders brew in every style. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Founders Porter is an opaque, brown-black beer with a brown sugar-colored froth that stays put.  It has an aroma of roasty malts, caramel or brown sugar and zesty hops.  Wow.  It has a very American smell.  Its pretty full bodied and soft.  It vanishes from the mouth quickly and leaves the tongue a bit scratchy.  It has flavors of dark malt, roastiness and maybe chocolate.  A sort of lemon peel bitterness and some sort of grass or hay and spice seem to come from the hops.  Its balanced perfectly.  Its bold and delicious.  This shows everyone what a porter is all about.

12oz bottle. Pours an oily black with a head of brown foam that quickly diminishes to a creamy dark tan ring and silky lacing on the glass. Aroma is heavy on the roast, with some hop bitterness. Maybe a touch of dark chocolate. Flavors are rich and powerful. Coffee, dark roasted grains, chocolate and hop bitterness make this a powerful and incredibly flavorful porter. Its reputation is well-deserved.
Silky smooth body what makes this porter. Decent nose roasted malts dark chocolate. Nice bitterness to cut the taste so isnt heavy on palate. Good drinkable porter.

Pours a dark mahogany, impenetrable to light with a small tan head quick to subside. Smells of malts, yeast and vanilla. Oily mouth-feel with moderate carbonation. Strong malt, kind of watery otherwise in taste, definitely made with just the basic elements of beer. Faint tastes of bittersweet chocolate and vanilla, malt balances out the hops but moderate bitterness to the brew. Finishes dry and bitter, solid good hardly anything special.

Extremely dark body with a medium head. Creamy roasted malt body with dark, almost burnt coffee bean flavors, notes of chocolate, caramel and smoke, with a balanced, spicy hop finish that lingers long.

Bottled: 05/29/12. 12 oz bottle into a DFH signature glass. 

A - Pours a dark brown body, almost bordering on black. Not as dark or thick as a stout as some light gets through the edges. One finger light mocha head with excellent lacing and retention.

S - The thing I thought of was...Founders Imperial Stout. It has an eerily similar nose, albeit a bit toned down. Rich and roasty malts which almost border on smoked, cocoa powder, and coffee beans. Excellent aroma.

T - Roasty and slightly smoky malts, milk chocolate, and espresso beans. There is a bit of a piney hop presence given the 45 IBUS, but the beer is a few months old so its mostly just present in a light bitterness. 

M - Silky and smooth, well carbonated. 

O - The imperial stout is a great beer, and this does come off as a lighter version of that beer. This is one of the of the best readily available shelf porters on the market!

A strong dark raw coffee bean aroma that is not over powering gorgeous black color with a thin light tan head. The founders porter has a great taste filled with coffee and a hint of chocolate. The coffee taste comes back in the finish. Overall, i am normally not a porter fan but because ive had some good recent porters i am becoming a fan.

12oz bottle-----> shaker.  Pours super dark black with tiny tan head.  Has faint aroma of coffee and caramel (aroma might be the weakest facet of this beer).  Taste is nice bitter coffee and dark chocolate with a bit of licorice.  Palate is typical thin porter.  Overall- a great porter made by a great brewery.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 Very dark brown almost black. Very little carbonation what little there was was medium brown bubbles. Oily feel but also creamy. For the strength it has a lot of flavor. As stout as porters get before crossing into being a Stout. Well done. Serving: Bottle

Bottled.  Pours black with very nice light brown head.  Nice combo of tart fruit and roasted malt on the nose.  Strong chocolate and coffee flavor opens into a bit of fruitiness, with a smoky, malt finish.  Rich mouthfeel, medium to full-bodied.  Nice kick of alcohol throughout, especially in the finish.  Nicely balanced, tasty porter.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Pours a nice dark color with an off tan head that doesnt last too long. Good aroma of roasted malt and chocolate with some hints of caramel and coffee. Taste is heavy with a nice mix of sweet and bitterness that lasts a while with seemingly dry finish. Body is medium overall and delicious. Would drink again.
Initially tasted very bright to me. Very dark yet has a surprising sweetness to it. Not overly bitter at all, and not as roasty as expected. Would drink again.

The beer is jet black, with a thick, beige head. A thick sheet of lacing coats the pint glass. No room for improvement here.

The aroma...ahh. Roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. What a welcoming scent.

The beer tastes fantastic as well. Teeming with flavor, this is one of the finest porters I have ever had. Chocolate and roast in beautiful harmony.

The feel is medium to full bodied, and silky smooth.

I highly recommend this beer. When it comes to stouts and porters, Founders Brewing Co. is simply world class.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-26-2011

From notes: Poured an opaque deep brown-to-black with a small caramel-colored head.  Caramelly, roasty aroma, perhaps a coffee note too.  Full-bodied, with a slight thickness.  Roasty coffee flavor with a slight anise note in the middle.  Also picked up a nutty note, as well as a grainy note that reminded me of oatmeal.  Very nice.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks DSG. Pours black with a small head, aroma of dark bread, light acidity and wood, flavor is bitter with coffee, chocolate, cherries and smoke, medium bodied, great
Bottle to oversized snifter. Looks good; black with mocha lacing. Smells solid; chocolate, malt, and roast. Tastes like it smells with a nice mouthfeel. Good, but overrated IMO.

Im not a fan of coffee flavor at all, and this beer has some.  But compared to the last couple ultra-dark beers Ive had, its a lot more tolerable.  More smoke and roast taste than coffee.  If I ever find myself in the mood for this style, this would be the one to grab.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2013 Gorgeous mocha-beige head, dark dark brown. Smells subtle and sublime - big roasted malts, dark chocolate and coffee. Tastes incredibly smooth and balanced - great roasted finish. Feels great - solid medium body with soft carbonation. What else could you ask for in a porter?

Enjoyed this beer on tap at Hinge in Northmapton, MA.  The beer had a rich, thick black color with a dark brown hue and a good-sized creamy-foamy off-white head with good retention and lacing, and great cling.  Its aroma featured a blend of chocolate and caramel malt, with light touches of coffee, and some lighter earthy and floral hops.  The taste was sweet and malty with features of chocolate, a bit of caramel, and some mild grainy-earthy bitterness, which was well blended.  The body was slightly creamy and a touch on the wet side with average carbonation and fizz, and a good, filling and creamy mouthfeel.
From tap. Black with almost no head (small flight glass though). Aroma is awesome with roasted coffee, chocolate, sweetness. Taste is smooth with chocolate and coffee. A very nice solid porter.
Lots of roasty and chocolate notes, a slight hint of coffee and smoke. Thick and silky mouthfeel. Great beer.

Bottle picked up at Premier Gourmet in Niagara Falls New York. Pour is ridiculously opaque, with a small tan head and little islands of lacing that dont really stick to the glass walls. Smells quite obviously malty, caramel and dark chocolate. Tastes like sweet dark chocolate, there are hints of tobacco in there too. Really awesome.
bottle. pours thick and black. small head. very roasty with chocolate. very flavorful. one of the best porters out there.

355ml bottle, bottled 29/05/12. Almost pitch black with a small mocha colored head. Aroma is a little subdued, showing slight caramel, roastiness, bitter chocolate and burnt sugar, leaning more on the sweeter side as it warms up. Not bad. The flavor starts off with chocolate and rolls into a dry, long and roasty, almost burnt toast finish with a hint of smoke and ash. Mouthfeel is a little thin and coating. A good, roasty porter.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with IPhonephan. Chocolate malt in the aroma leading to a gorgeous smooth bitter liquorice malty taste. One of the nicest chewy porters I've ever had. I will track down another bottle!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fuck.... this was the last regular I hadnt tried. I waited way too long. A smoky, cocoa-y, amazing porter. Lives up to the hype.

Draught at Beer Authority, NYC. Black beer with a nice lasting beige head. Roasted chocolate aroma, cocoa powder, vanilla, licorice, soot, figs, dark bread, hop notes, creamy, some tar. Flavor from cocoa powder, milk, dark chocolate, milk chocolate, figs, rather roasted, creamy, vanilla, some hops, iron notes, some milk, dark bread, coffee, caramel, some nice late bitterness. Long lovely balanced finish with chocolate, cocoa powder, figs, soot and milk chocolate. Pretty much anything you can ask for in a porter.

12 oz. bottle at Mirabell German restaurant.  Pours an opaque dark brown, almost black with a small tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is full of chocolate, vanilla, espresso and nuts.  Taste is sweet but not sickeningly so.  Finish is drier than expected.  Full body with creamy mouthfeel.  One of the best porters Ive tried.

Pours deep, dark brown with a trace of fizzy, tan head around the rim. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, espresso, earthy hops, figs and other dark fruit, vanilla, and light oak. Flavor is roast malt forward with some supporting dark fruit esters and faint hops; chocolate undertones throughout with a dry, coffee finish. Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 Poured from a 33 cl bottle into a goblet. Very dar brown, almost black pour with a tan head. Coffee and dry hay aroma.  Toasted malt and hit of coffee in the taste. Slightly bitter hoppy aftertaste.

Bottle from Pavlov Badzewski. Colour...damn near black with a thick off white head. Nose...delightfully roasty with hints of chocolate and walnuts. Palate...frothy, sweet but dry and nutty with more of that toasty and roasty aspect that carries on and on across the palate.

12 ounce bottle, bottled 03/29/12.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch tan head.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  The aroma is great, it smells like roasted malt, chocolate, and some coffee.  It tastes like roasted and burnt/charred malt, milk and bittersweet chocolate, and coffee.  Theres a nice mix between the sweet and bitter flavors.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy with moderate carbonation.  This is a very good brew, its certainly one of the best porters Ive had.  I know Ill be buying more of this beer, I dont know why I havent tried it until now!

355 ml bottle shared with czar and minderbender. Pours an opaque black with short-lasting beige head. Smells like roast and chocolate. Taste is very sweet, milk chocolate and roast. Some smoke, too. Light bitterness, followed with a hint of sweet cream. Roast aftertaste. Thick body, velvety mouthfeel. Most excellent porter!

Pint at rattle n hum. This beer is BLACK. I got it poured about 40 min ago, and the cap was still a bubbly 4mm or so. Sick lacing from the original 1" khaki coloured cap. 

A wickedly chocolate malt flavour, complimented by a soft smoke. Probably like a victim of 94% burny area, for some reason got horny and there was a willing homosapian that wanted to choke on the happy fluids excreted by said burny victim. BUT, that burny victim wouldn't have much other than a pineapple diet. But more smoke than love-fluid.

Oh yeah! The smell! Perfect chocolate, caramel, and dry-nutty balance. 

A pleasant beer. Suck on that.

Bottle 355ml. Thx to VT
Pours black with low beige head. Some lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, almost smoky, chocolate. Taste is of roasted malt, sligth acidity, smoke, "cream", chocolate. Palate; creamy, full bodied. Overall: Very nice finale. Impressive, serious porter.

Pours dark opaque brown with a milk chocolate head. The Aroma is lovely chocolate, coffee and a bit of toffee. Medium in body with light carbonation. Flavor is fantastic with a lot of roasted flavor and just enjoy hop bite. A fabulous beer.

bottle shared with VT and minderbinder: thanks. almost black with a nice beige head, some retention and lacing. loads of chocolate, almost burnt malts - complex, some smoke, lactose, vanilla beans. soft carbonation, full body, sweet creamy milk chocolate finish and bitter coffee. very good.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2017 12 oz. bottle- Pours bitch ass black with a one finger dark tan head that reduces to a collar and some some islands. The aroma is dark roasted chocolate, coffee, intense and creamy. The taste is similar, dark roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, all the nice trademarks of the style, only blended wonderfully, it all just melds, creamy dark deliciousness. Body is medium and carbonation is the same. Overall this rivals the best straight up porters I have ever had.

Poured from a 12 oz.. bottle into a tulip.

Coming out of the bottle, Founders Porter looks thick and viscous, with a nearly black color.  There is a small off-white head that manages to leave a bit of lace down the sides of the glass.

The aroma is full of unsweetened dark chocolate and roasted malt.  A bit of espresso and a generous hop bill adds a bitter aroma.

For a porter, this beer is definitely big on flavor.  The unsweetened dark chocolate and roasted malts dominate, but a general hoppiness works its way in toward the end.  Each sip also has a little bit of caramel sweetness, vanilla, and coffee.

Founders Porter is a little bit on the sticky side, despite not having a strong sweet character.  The carbonation is right in the middle between creamy and smooth, and the body is on the full side for the style, despite not having a huge ABV.  

This is yet another example of a well made beer from Founders.
Good, sweet and chocolatey aroma. Smoky sweet flavor. Dark, fruity notes. Quite wonderful.

Bottle at dans, courtesy of Aaron. Thanks Man! 2010 Vintage. Poured deep, opaque brown, almost black with a huge tan head. Peat, light smoke, roasted malt, dark chocolate, grapefruit, and coffee on the aroma. Taste is leather, dark fruits, tar, tobacco, smoke, cocoa nibs, dark chocolate, and espresso with a light coffee ground bitterness in the finish that seems to linger. Creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation and has really aged nicely. Pretty nice porter and very smooth, but a tad too smoky for me.
Bottle - unale to pour out of bottle to see color/head, roasted malt & chocolate aroma and flavor, very good porter

Average head and lacing.  Dark brown-black in color.  Aroma - Wow!  Rich coffee roastiness, licorice, and some cocoa.  What a great sniff!  Flavor - Wow!  Again, rich coffee roastiness, licorice, and some cocoa.  Bitterness lingers nicely.  Slurp slurp!  So many pitch dark ales can be too heavy in the body or too heavy in the cocoa for my preferences, but this one nails the right balance.  What an amazing brewery Founders is.  Now, if I could just find a KBS to see if they can convert me to the impy stout style!

Had at brewpub.  One of the best porters I've had.  Great looking beer that follows with a great taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Quality stuff, not great. Pouts dark brown with a small head, aroma is light and burnt. Flavor is roasted and tart, but not overly strong.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at a tasting at Ariels place. Dark brown with a beige head. Roasty aroma of coffee, a bit of chocolate and dark fruits hints. Sweetish roasty flavor with chocolate, coffee, and a pleasant drier finish. Medium to full body, silky mouthfeel. A very nice Porter.
Not real smoothe for a porter but it tasted real good the carbonation almost takes over

Tap at RattleNHum, Manhattan - 02/03/12.
Pretty solid black with a tan head, slight brown edgeing when held to light.
Roasted malts a good pinch of coffee and a dash of cocoa on the nose - great aroma!
Taste as per nose coffee and chocolate in equal doses and a little licquorice at the back.
Medium bodied with a thick creamy finish of malt, chocolate and coffee.
Great Porter!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle, pours a nice black, aroma is chocolaty and the flavour is so well, it has a good solid body and a nice finish, a good offering from founders
More than a porter should be. Great chocolate taste, sweet with no hip or other bitter after taste. Light brown head leaves nicely on the glass. Has the mouth feel of a stout.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a small brown head that dissipates quickly with some lacing. Aroma is dark roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is rich and lightly bitter with roasted malt and semi-sweet chocolate dominating the palate, with just a hint of smoke and grass in the background. Mild bitter finish. Very satisfying.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2012 Wow. This is a stellar porter. So many are all cream and no guts, but this has an assertively hoppy flavor, while balanced at the same time.
355ml bottle. Pours black with tan head. Roasted, almost burned aroma with smoke. Flavour is smoke, roasted malt, ashes and tobacco. Smooth, a little bitter aftertaste.

On tap at The Flying Saucer on 7/20/2012.  Pours almost black with a small brown head.  Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts.  Taste is well balanced between malt sweetness and hop bitterness.  Awesome porter.
A rich and flavorful porter, this pours a dark brown like Guinness, but the roasted hops offer a smokey coffee flavor.
Hits all the right notes for a porter. Great balance of smoke and malt, with just a hint of hop spice

Pours dark brown with black shadows. Malt, coffee, chocolate. Very rich but not bitter. Not as intense as the breakfast stout which for me is good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown (almost black) pour with a tan, creamy head. Good retention. Aroma is nuts, toffee, sweet chocolate, heavily roasted malt, slightly earthy. Starts off with malty sweetness accompanied by a tiny bit of carbonation and the sweetness is slowly subdued by bitterness and finishes in balance. Medium-full body, moderately low carbonation, slight alcohol warmth.

Bottle 355  ml. Pitch black with a small brown head, quickly diminishing. Aroma and flavour: roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruits, notes of vanilla, coffee. Everything that makes a good porter! Taste is a good balance of sweetnes and bitterness. A bit thin. Dry finish.
Black with creamy brown thick head that lasts the entire glass.  Chocolate and coffee in aroma and taste, that has a great bitterness to it.  Probably the best porter Ive ever had.

Pours a pitch black with a one finger tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma is of roasted malts, bakers coco, black coffee, and some mild hop bitterness.  Flavor is of roasted malts, bakers coco, milk chocolate, espresso, caramel malt, toffee, some tobacco, and some mild hop bitterness.  Has medium full body with a slick, creamy mouthfeel and a semi dry, long, semi bitter, but still sweet finish.  overall, a fantastic beer that is definitively the best porter I have had to date.
Draft @ Coalhouse Pizza, Stamford, CT. Notes of sweet tobacco, coffee, chocolate. Smooth, rich and pillowy, very solid porter.

Deep brown pour, small head. Perfect porter on the nose. Chocolate balancing dark roasted malts, just a bit of the hop character coming through. Big, robust flavor for a brew at 6.5%. Smooth - goes down easy. This onell scratch the itch for a dark brew without sending you packing. Nice.

Bottle in Ann Arbor.

Exceptionally dark brown pour, strong roasty, nutty aroma, gently sweet, bakers chocolate, just a hint of ash. Delicious.

Sample, from a bottle, Mondial de la bière, savoured on June 6 2012; eye: black, opaque, tiny ring of beige head; nose: roasting, cocoa, light burnt, roasted barley; mouth: roasted barley, light cocoa, burnt barley, finale in roasted barley with light presence of pleasant acridness, full body, average carbonation, oily texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS 

Échantillon, dune bouteille, Mondial de la Bière, savourée le 6 juin 2012 
il : noire, opaque, petit anneau de mousse beige; nez : torréfaction, cacao, léger brûlé, orge torréfiée; bouche : orge torréfiée, léger cacao, léger orge brûlée, finale en orge torréfiée avec légère présence dâcreté agréable, corsée, carbonatation moyenne, texture huileuse; en résumé : bien bon
Full robust flavors and amazing balance for all the senses. So well crafted.  I will always buy this beer

Mouth-watering aromas of cocoa nibs and sweetened coffee. Beautifully soft head that dissipates at the perfect rate. Pours black as pitch. The tastes are quite similar to the aromas. This beer is slightly sweet without being cloying. It has more than enough malty backbone to hold up the sweetness. The best part of all is the mouthfeel, which is silky smooth and lingers only a few seconds, begging you to come back for more. Overall, this is the porter that every other porter should use as a measuring stick. Brilliant.

A - Pours a very dark brown, almost black color with a thin finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind some lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of roasted chocolate and dark caramel malts with some dark fruit, coffee, smoke, and earthy hop.

T - Starts off with a mix of roasted chocolate malts with a bit of dark fruit sweetness, molasses, and vanilla. Through the middle, some earthy hops come through with some smoke and coffee. The finish is a mix of dark chocolate, roasted dark caramel malts, smoke, bitter coffee, and some dark fruits.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth and a touch chewy with a dry, roasted, and lightly sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nicely balanced porter. The malt profile is very good and the body and mouthfeel are just right.

Roasted chocolate nose, so brown its black full bodied porter.  Leans on the bitter side but this full robust porter is top notch.  Technically the alcohol is too high for a true porter but for me Founders brewed an excellent one.
12oz bottle, at Muldoons, nice roasty flavor smooth finish, hurt by being served in a frosted mug, still a great beer overall.

Bottle 355 ml. Thanks to SourNotes for this one! Dark brown (almost black) with a small brown head and a small brown lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, smoked malt, roasted malt, plum, raisin, vanilla, caramel and liquorice. Taste is about the same with a slight bitterness at finish. Mouthfeel is dry and alcohol is slightly perceptible. Nice balance and complexity. Very good porter!
Basically a perfect porter. Smells light and slightly chocolate.  Smooth drink but heavy palate.  If I could picture a perfect beer of this style this would be it
Pours dark brown. Roasted aroma is rich and full of chocolate. Taste is even more rich. Sweet not bitter. Roasted nut flavor as well. Very enjoyable!

Founders is one of the best breweries there is and this one lives up to their reputation. Roasted caramel, coffee notes finished with a light chocolatey sweetness at the end. Pours dark but drinks light.

Dependably good. Porters are not my fav, but this is okay. Pours like motor oil, but tastes much better.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle. Roasted bready malt aroma. Black brown body with a quick foamy brown head. Roasted coffee malt flavour has a light sweet roast aftertaste. Medium-full body. Quite tasty and drinkable.

Poured from bottle: dark brown/black, very deep, looked thick, but taste is smooth. Aroma of malts, coffee, maybe chocolate. taste is good and smooth. Not bitter. A little bite in the aftertaste. This is a good porter.



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark brownish black with a dark khaki head.  Aromas of coffee, tobacco, some chocolate.  Taste follows suit, roasty, coffee, unsmoked pipe tobacco.  Finishes with a nice little hop bite that is oh so pleasing.  Very good.

Light aroma of slightly roasted nuts and sweet toffee. Pours dark brown, thick no opacity to the color. Medium brown color head, smallish which didnt last. Low carbonation, medium mouthfeel which starts out light but fills up as the flavors and body envelope your  mouth. Even flavor throughout, some alcholol warmth at the very end. more tha n you would think for only 6.5 abv. Smooooth , creamy, RICH ,and luscious..but not overly bold or too flavorful. More subtle ,maybe even underflavored compared to some Porters or Brown ales. Great malt tatste though, satisfying , and leaves you wanting more. Very little bitterness, leans towards sweetness, flavors of dark chocolate, raisins, dark cherry , plum, roasted walnuts. Excellent Porter !
I dont get a lot of smell off this one, but it sure is tasty as hell. Lots of coffee and roasted flavors make this a good one. No head to it at all.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2013 Bottle.  Pours deep, dark brown with a trace of fizzy, tan head around the rim.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, espresso, earthy hops, figs and other dark fruit, vanilla, and light oak.  Flavor is roast malt forward with some supporting dark fruit esters and faint hops; chocolate undertones throughout with a dry, coffee finish.  Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

Beer #4 at the Mondial de la Bière 2012 (June 8), bottle. Black, small head. Aroma of roasted barley malt, lots of coffee. Slightly bitter taste of coffee, some fruit notes, good bitterness. A good drinkable porter!
Bottle pour. Dark tab head. Dark body. Medium carbonation and body. Aroma is of toffee and chocolate. Taste confirms, mostly chocolate and coffee.

12 oz bottle served in a pint glass.  Pour is deep cola with two big fingers of deep khaki foam that left a nice show on the glass.  Nose is big roasted malt, coffee, and a bit of toffee.  Taste is right on with the nose, but delivered in an uber creamy fashion with some raisin flavor that wasnt apparent in the nose.  This is a fantastic porter that Ive somehow missed up until I picked up this variety case.

Bottle poured a dark cola with a small tan head that dissapated quickly and minimal lacing.  Aroma is big on roasted coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, cocoa powder, and hints of raisin.  First sip begins with bold coffee and roasted malt flavor followed by bittersweet chocolate and cocoa.  Extremely well-balanced flavors that led to a smooth finish with smoke and slight bitterness lingering to play with the palate.  Truly enjoyable porter.

Pours a deep black with a short brown head. The aroma has lots of chocolate, with a bit of coffee. The flavor is chocolate up front, with the coffee showing up afterwards along with a bit of hop spiciness and a smooth body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

19th December 2009Opaque black beer, thick foamy light tan head. Toasted malt nose. Semi dry palate that is quite silky. Lightly toasted malt, a little creamy as well. An odd touch of glue is a distraction before unsweeet dark chocolate and a splash of espresso present. Could be decent but the glue is a real turn off.

Pours deep dark umber color with subtle aromas of burnt coffee, earth and hints of chocolate.  On the palate it comes through with rich bubbles and roasted malty flavors; chocolate, coffee, leaves, blueberry and a rich bitterness on the finish.

Bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Roasty malted aroma with some chocolate lingering.  Full bodied porter with chocolate and roasty malted  taste with some hoppy bitterness on the finish.  An excellent porter.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2013 35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 25.03.2011
Aroma has some dark chocolate, coffee and distant notes of berries typical to danish ales. Flavour has chocolate, coffee and some licorice. Good, but I expected more.
7+3+8+4+15
35,5 cl bottle @ home
Sweetish aroma with cocoa, some dark chocolate, distant sewer aromas and hints of metal. Flavour has deep roasted notes, chocolate and malty notes with a feeling of oat. Also some licorice tones do occur. Finishes somewhat hoppy with coffee. Now were talking!
7+4+8+5+16=3.9
Bottle. Poured black with a tan head. Big aromas of milk chocolate, roast, nut, and coffee. The flavor found roast, chocolate, and coffee. Medium body and a roast/coffee aftertaste.

12oz bottle - pours black with little brown head.  Nose is roasted malts and coffee.  Flavor adds grassy hops.  A little sweet, but mainly bitter.  quite dry to the lips and full bodied. Sweet aftertaste of a fruity nature.  A tad too roasty for me quite like dark/bitter chocolate and hence I would pair this with raspberry-coulis chocolate cake.

Wow. This is one great porter. Not too sweet at all. Perfectly chilled (Ill take credit for that part). Very subtle chocolate taste. Im quite pleased with this porter, and is one of the better ones that I have tried.

Bottle. Its a reddish, dark, dark brown beer, topped by a small, beige head. Coffee, sweetness and hints of hops on the nose. Rather one tracked, but nice, and that goes for the flavor too. Mostly coffee and roasted malts, some chocolate blends in, and then theres some hoppy bitterness. Roasted finish. A bit thin on the palate, medium bodied. A nice one indeed, althoug lacking a bit on complexity I think. 110930
Hell this is the bomb of all porters.  It is like sex in a bottle.  Absolutely righteous chocolate, espresso with a roasty finish. Yum.
(bottle) clear very dark brown with small brown head; aromas of bread, roast, bit metallic; rich, balanced flavour, excellent

Thick black body with many flavours elegantly balanced together to form a porter well worthy of the hype. Excellent stuff.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at hamiltons! Deep brown color with a thick tan head. Full body with chocolate and expresso up front with slight bitter smoky finish. Similar to deschutes black butte but bolder overall, great porter!

The pour is black with a thin brown head.  The aroma is expresso.  The taste is chocolate and expresso with a bitter finish.  An excellent porter and well worth the 90 minute drive it took to find it in the Mid-Atlantic.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle from Crossroads Beer & Wine, Burlington, MA. A really dark, black, pour with a creamy looking tan head; aroma of strong black coffee and chocolate malts; surprisingly light in the mouth, without being thin, some coffee and red fruit mingle with the richly roasted malts and demerara sugar; before a dry, warming, finish with light peppery hops and some smooth, milky, chocolate. A rather good porter, but I prefer a slightly heavier body.

Poured from the bottle with a frothy tan head which quickly died down to a thin film. Black with red trimmings, hops are apparent in the first moments but give way to expresso, chocolate, and some smoked wood aromas. Body is full. Black malt bitterness along with some chocolate and other burnt offerings make up the majority of the flavor. slight hop is in the finish. Another good beer from Founders.

Black with a light brown, moderate head. Aroma is malty with nice roasted notes. Taste is primarily roasted malt with some bitterness that balances well. Very easy to drink. This is a nice ale. Bottle conditioned, but a bit light on alcohol to cellar.

This is as good as advertised. I am biased because I love Porters. Picked this up at a Binnys, they displayed the RateBeer rating of 100.

I need to do a head to head with Anchor Steams Porter. Both are great porters, I think this one is more complex flavorwise.

Pours dark brown and black, small head. Nose is all chocolate and coffee with malty notes. Taste is nothing but favor, heavy body with chocolate and coffee flavors. Finish is dry and short but follows through.Nice rich porter!
Quaff Score 9 / 10

Pours a dark brown with a brown head and aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and slight vanilla with a toasty, dry finish. Excellent tasting porter, great brew.

12 oz. bottle, pours pitch black with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, some burnt notes and tar. Flavour of burnt / roasted malts, coffee, tar, some bitter chocolate and maybe some charred dark fruits. Medium-bodied and very well-made. Great example of the style.

Rich and robust. Smells of deep roasted chocolate malt. Hint of coffee. Full of flavor. Hearty. Slight bit of hops noticeable throughout. The roastiness is rather incredible. Love this brew

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very dark in color, almost no light gets through, medium carbed yet still has a residual foamy head. Aromas of brown sugar, light smoke, chocolate, light bread, toasted malts. Flavors of burnt/roasted malts, wood, smoke. Very robust, leaves a strong smoky aftertaste, oily, dense, milky texture. A very good example of what a porter should be. Makes me think and feel like I have a beard, mustache, and am sitting at a table in the wild west wearing snake skinned boots back in the 1800s. And what about two pistles in their holsters on both hips.... Thats it, a cowboy. Giddy up.

Bottle at the Bridgeville Beer tasting on 04/27/12. One of the best porters Ive had in a long time! Typical coffee scent, but with a sweet tinge on the end. Brown appearance with a tan head similar to other porters. Coffee fronted taste, strong and bold, with a bitter finish. Medium palate, smooth, smooth, smooth!

Dark pours, thin oily tan head.  Aroma of vanilla with some faint hops.  Full bodied palate gives way to some biting alcohol.  Taste is sweet vanilla, caramel with some cascading bitter hops.  Lacing slides down the glass.

Good robust porter. The aromas a chocolate with a touch of coffee and some floral hops. The beer is opaque black with a small tan head. The taste is back to coffee and chocolate, but a fair hop bitterness in the finish. The beer is thick and chewy but incredbly smooth. I would have toned down bitterness a tad and left the focus more on the malt flavors.

Bottle.  Pours black with a finger of brown head.  Aroma is major chocolate with some hoppy floral notes in the background.  Taste is full of dark chocolate and has some decent hop bite on the finish.  The palate is pretty full and creamy.  This may be my favorite porter and you have to love the price point.

The aroma is charred wood, black coffee, over roasted malt. The flavor base is much the same. The palate is smooth if not slightly watery. The finish is powerful and bitter, coating the mouth with an alcoholic roasted malt flavor. Some distant chocolate notes on the finish. A one dimensional porter, not horrible but there are much better out there. Over rated.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2016 Pours from the bottle a deep chocolate brown with a light brown, brief head.  The smell hints at chocolate and coffee, and the taste has more of the same with some tones of dark cherry.  This stuff is tasty.  Id drink it again.

Edit:  2016 revision ... I first reviewed this four years ago.  I drink it all the time now.  This beer is one of the reasons that porter is my favorite beer style.  Every time I think I understand the style, I revisit some porter that I like and find that not only do I not understand the style, I dont even understand individual good porters.  The best porters are like albums that still sound new years later.  This is such an album.

From a bottle to a nonic pint glass. Pours very dark brown with light ruby coloring. One finger tan head that quickly shrinks. Nice lacing.  Aroma is smoked malt, coffee, and roasted barley. Flavor is rich coffee and chocolate, smoke, roasted barley, and a slight hop balance. Medium mouthfeel and flavor clings to your tongue. This beer is in my top 3 porters easily.

Coffee smoked and chocolate aromas poured with very slight head that dissipated quickly otherwise pitch black.  Coffee and chocolate flavors pronounced light sweetness with a medium bitter very well balanced medium body somewhat sticky. Very good Porter that lives up to the hype

Pours a pitch black with a dark tan head.  Aroma is lighter of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is so much more sufficient than the first aroma impressions.  Coffee and chocolate abound with a very robust taste.  Very taste.  Extremely smooth, oily, and a bit bitter.  Lighter body.  It is actually a bit watery, but the flavors remain strong throughout drinking.  It all lasts very well in the aftertaste.  I really like this one.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2012 Aroma is rich coffee, roasted malts, cocoa, vanilla and some alcohol. Taste follows suit, but is much weaker than aroma. Predominantly a mild bitter coffee and roasted malts. Very easy to drink and smooth but I wanted more. Palate is thin with some carbonation I think. Overall a nice beer, very solid.

Bottle @ Olympen, Oslo Fall 2011. Dark pour with light tan head. Roasted malts and chocolate, most obvious, subtle vanilla. Dry, malty, bitter, high carbonation relative to style, decent body but feels like it could be meatier.

Tap. Very dark with thin cocoa-like head. Smells roasty with a chocolate note and perhaps coffee too. Nice roasty flavor with an almost herbaceous end note. Nice and dry. A bit carbonated- not as soft a some porters, but still pretty light.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012 Pitch black pour with a nice beige head.  Aroma is roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate.  Taste is amazing.  Lots of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and some vanilla.  Very nice thick mouthfeel.  A great spicy and slightly bitter finish makes it stand out from other porters.  Just great.  I really love this porter.

12 oz bottle from The Beerhive in Pittsburgh.  Discovered totally off-the-shelf and so pleased to have made the acquaintance of this nearly perfect porter.  Can Founders do anything wrong is my first thought and this tasting racks up another outstanding rating on my list.  If youre trying to introduce your friends to the wonderful world of porters and the dark side of beers, you may want to start here.

Chocolaty aroma and thin dark pour leads to a very balanced taste and satisfying mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

February 15, 2011. 12oz bottle courtesy of TomThompson, shared with blankboy and garthicus.  A long-time "want of mine, huge props John, sorry my backlog made me take so long to get this entered.  Thick looking black pour with a solid frothy light brown head.  Terrific simple dry roast aroma, not at all sweet or syrupy, just the right amount of herbal bitterness, maybe a whiff of lactose sourness in there, but not off-putting at all.  Taste - quintessential porter for me - solid mid-level roast, not sweet, very dry, crisp, well balanced against moderate alcohol, malt and bitterness - this one rides the center of the groove;  coffee, nutshell - just right.  Perfect mouthfeel, not thick or light, just a bit of acidity, appropriately light carbonation (I hate a fizzy porter), and a dry, nutty finish with an overlay of modest bitterness.  Want more.
Nice dark smoked chocolate aroma.  Really thick and rich and dark and malty with chocolate and coffee blend.  Bitter ending.  Good beer but not my favorite.

Bottle @ The Local Pub  
black pour with a strong brown head  strong coffee,chocolate and roasted malt aroma taste was sweet malty strong alcohol chocolate and coffee  medium to thick body with lively carbonation sweet chocolaty aftertaste puts a smile on my face every time :)
Dark brown colour with brown head.  Roasted malts aroma. This is full of dark chocolate and coffee, so its more bitter than some other porters. Unique.

Pours a dark brown with little head. Some nice aromas right off the bat, roastiness and a bit of chocolate notes. Medium bodied porter that is very smooth and easy to drink. Pretty good option if you are a fan of porters.

Pours out very dark brown, little tan head. Smells of chocolate and roasted coffee. This beer is as smooth as they come. Every drink makes you want to take another bigger, longer one. This is by far the best porter I have ever had. Purely perfect.

A: Pours a very dark (not quite pitch black) reddish black color. Theres a one finger tan colored head, and it doesnt have much retention, or lacing. Still looks nice, though.

S: This has a lot of chocolate on the nose. Theres some roasty coffee as well, but it almost smells like a melted chocolate bar to me.

T: Theres more coffee in the taste than there is on the nose; likewise, it isnt as chocolaty as the nose would suggest. Lots of coffee (not too much), hints of smoke and chocolate, roastiness, and a hint of a hoppy finish. It does a good job of not being overtly vegetal in its texture (usually my least favorite part of a porter), and has some nice complexity to it, as well.

M: Medium bodied, dry finish, low carbonation, smooth, hint of astringent coffee on the back end - basically, everything a good porter should feel like.

O: All things told, its quite good. Not my absolute favorite dark beer of all time, but its an excellent choice in the future when I dont feel like having a stout.

[Thanks to MatSciGuy]. 12fl. oz. bottle. Black colour wirth a moderate formation of a tan and creamy head, nice lacing and medium lasting. Aroma is toasty, strong dark coffee and slightly licorice. Flavour is toasty, roasty, ash could be present, wood and with a mild spicy flavour. The final is toasty with a decent duration in the aftertaste. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium to high. Texture is oily.

It poured a dark color with a tan head. The aroma was of roasted coffee and some cocoa. The taste was coffee and sweet malts at the start, with a bit of cocoa and cofee in the finish. A very good Porter.
Bottle. Pours very dark with a nice brown head. The smell is mostly that of malts. Taste is smooth with some chocolate and a lot of malt.  Damn fine porter.

Bottle/12oz - Pours a very dark black/brown in color with a small tan head that faded quickly to a thin covering over the beer. Aroma is malty with dark roasted malts prevalent.  Some chocolate and dark fruits.  Flavor matches with some nice dark chocolate bitterness filling in the gaps.  Awesome...

Bottle.  Dark brown pure with a an thick frothy head.  Aroma of roasted malt, earth and faint mocha.  Velvety mouthfeel and full bodied, almost the consistency of milk.  Lasting yet smooth finish.  Phenomenol!

355 ml bottle.
Rated on 20110325.
Pours black color with small head. Aroma clearly has some "danish vegetables", roasted malts, mild chocolate notes and ripe fruits. Flavor of ash dry chocolate, roasted malts and wood. Smooth palate, but something is a bit off. Not the best porter Ive tasted.
4336

Deep, deep brown...dark, oily-tan head.
Aroma is a subtle mix of coffee, chocolate, hop, smoke.
Taste is nicely smoky, all of the flavours balance smoothly, the chocolate,coffee, hops, roasts share the stage equally..... only the burnt wood/smoke stand out......and it works....perfectly.
An outstanding porter.
A cellar must-have.      Bravo.

Bottle shared by Maekchu. Black with an oily-ass head. Rich nose of coffee, chocolate, nuts, hops. Sweet and rich flavor, creamy coffee chocolate. Great body. Rich and tasty. Seems like a stout to me.

Probably my favorite porter.  A delightful, drinkable brew.  Aroma is excellent: Head is medium brown.   Coffee, chocolate, caramel, smoky, roasted malt.  Balanced.  A superior brew, not surprising for Founders.  If you like Porters, this one is a must.
Wow, this beer is sexy!  Pours black with no head. Awesome roasted malt aroma.  Has a nice smoked chocolate taste and is very smooth.  Clean dry finish. Good stuff!

aroma: More intense than in most porters. Bitter and burnt. Remniscent of raisins and cocoa and coffee.

body: Creamy and smooth. Full-bodied.

Taste: Begins surprisingly sweetish. Some tart fruit around the edges. Burnt coffee and a bit of chocolate.
 
finish: Espresso and citrus fruit. Long lasting bitterness and dryness (a bit metallic?).

overall: Excellent! A balanced, very drinkable stuff. Not very refreshing, but rich in texture and flavour.
Standard for style. Off white beige head. Nice chocolate malt expression.good roast. All the classic flavors are there. And its just done better than others do it

Not the MOST perfect porter but very very close. A little smokey, very dark, creamy, rich, and still smooth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle. dark dark brown colour with a tan head. aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, coffee. Flavour is smoked, coffee, roasted malt, chocolate. Round nice beer.
Pours a very dark brown with a medium-sized, light brown head. Rich and flavorful, with a roasty, nutty taste and coffee notes.

Served on-tap at Shady McGradys during a recent Happy Hour trip.

A - Pours dark brown, bordering on black, with a nice one and a half finger tall tan head leaving spotty patches of lace down most of the glass.

S - Smells of robust dark roasted malts, bittersweet chocolate, coffee grounds, dark fruits and some black licorice. Nothing too over the top here, very nice balance.

T - Starts off with plenty of dark roast - both from the malt and the coffee - slowly giving way to some sweetness from the chocolate and dark fruits. The balance of sweet to roast is fairly well done, the roast does become a bit overbearing as it warms but not too bad. Finish is roasty, lingering on the pallet long after consumption.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. The dark flavors are strong in this one, lingering on the pallet long after the finish.

O - Definitely one of the better American Porters out there. This one packs plenty of flavor and was very easy to drink. Glad I got this one.

Its like someone perfectly unified the most rich, velvety chocolate milk youve ever had with beer. Maybe the most amazing mouthfeel of any beer Ive ever had. The chocolate flavors seem dominant, but if its not quite as complex as some porters Ive ever had -- I simply didnt care. It was so flavorful, balanced and palate-pleasing. Amazing stuff.

This is certainly a very rich and satisfying porter.   Roasty malts and subtle smoke tease your taste buds.  The finish is pretty clean and well balanced.  A healthy amount of hoppiness accompanies the swallow, as is the case for most American micro porters.

Inky black/brown body under a slow, thick mocha head. Deep, lush aromas... cocoa, smoky malt, burnt matchsticks, coffee roasts, then more sweet chocolate syrup (enticing to the point where I had to stop sniffing and start drinking). Thick, luscious mouthfeel, "full bodied" in every last sense of the phrase. Flavor blows me away like every other component thus far: Milk chocolate, dark chocolate, char... incredible bittersweet deliciousness. ~~~~~~~ Purchased a few weeks ago in a mix-a-six from Woodmans in Carpentersville, IL.

Interesting take on a porter. Alcohol aroma and a deep rich, bittersweet chocolate taste with a syrupy mouth feel that lingersin your mouth. Expected this to be alot roastier but it took the sweeter route.
36cl, American brew, from Brouwerij de Molen Bodegraven, very complex Porter, roasted/malty and slightly bitter/woody, balanced, clear, rocky head, very good brew

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2012 Tasted from bottle into snifter. Poured an opaque, very, very dark reddish brown color with lasting tan foam and excellent lace. Aromas of husky grains, dark toast, coffee, fruity ale yeast esters, strong doses of perfumey hops and alcohol. The flavor was a dark, dry, tart maltiness suggestive of brown bread, coffee cake, toffee, almost burnt caramel, citrus rinds, raisins, plums, blackberry cordial. An American hops-forward interpretation of porter, in a good way, and thank god not overly grapefruity. Strong carbonation, medium body, mouthfeel was almost syrupy but drier than that, and not at all sticky. I couldnt taste the alcohol, but I definitely felt it a minute later. A magnificently balanced masterpiece of a beer.

Poured from 12oz bottle dated 2/10/12 into porter glass
Aroma: chocolate and malt.  coffee is strongest scent.  can smell the alcohol a bit
Appearance:  very dark pour.  deep chocolate brown/black color.  hardly any head.  the thin layer that is there is a milk chocolate brown and faded quickly
Taste:  sweet at first followed by bitter
Palate: lighter than expected in the body.  a little thin.  average carbonation. slightly bitter finish
Overall:  one of the lower ABV beers from Founders.  I like this alot.  i was able to swirl the glass to get more head to form.  the chocolate came out a bit more after that.  i may have drank this too cold as it was straight from the fridge.

Very inviting aromas. A lovely bouquet of chocolate, some coffee, a little caramel and nuts too. Maybe a little resin aromas from the hops. Dark (black) but thin appearance with a short lasting creamy tan head. Flavor has a roast-like bite to it but is still a little sweet. Balance is toward the bitterness from hops and dark malts which suits me just fine. It reminds me of eating some burnt toast but in a really good way. The nice medium body really gives this beer a fuller feeling. Its a bit slick and a little astringent but it really stays with you.
Overall this is an excellent porter. A little darker and roastier than I might prefer, but it hits the spot and is extremely drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2012 Pint pour In Urbana, IL.  This is the best porter I can remember.  It pours a pitch black and has a dark brown foam at top.  It was like a rich, dark, slightly sweet beer version of Whoppers. Very smooth and filling.

This one was probably an aging bottle at Binnys, but still appeared to pour with good subtle carbonation and head.  The malt profile was of the border between chocolate and coffee, with a balance of sprucelike hops.  Nothing real un-expected here, but a good solid rich porter.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Deep dry chocolate malt with great subtle finish and nice after taste makes this porter a great choice.

Havent had a beer this good in a long time.  Forgot how much I loved this style.  A nice dark brown body, completely opaque. A nice tan to medium brown head the had good retention and nice lacing.  Aroma had many complex layers.  Smoke, chocolate, roasted coffee and hops.  Smoke note pared well with both the chocolate and coffee notes and the slightly citrus hops was a nice surprise in the background.  Flavor was velvety smooth nice a bittersweet chocolate flavor upfront.  Coffee notes was an assertive bitterness that cut through the chocolates sweetness.  Some smoke and slightly bitter hops in the finish.  Very dry on the palate and the body certainly was full.  You dont need a spoon but its close.

Bottle (in the category of Howd I miss this?").  Woody chocolate malt and hay aroma.  Opaque black-brown color with small head.  Sweet chocolate malt and lightly bitter herbal hops flavor.  Delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2015 Deeply dark beer with a foamy, off-tan head. No red hue on the edges, no light coming throughthis is almost stout territory. The aroma is enticing, with notes of dark chocolate and coffee; very grainy and crisp. The body is medium, carbonation is prickly, and the alcohol goes down unnoticed. The taste is great, with cocoa and coffee making big appearances, and subtle hops also showing up. This is a simple and straightforward porter that just works. Its incredibly drinkable and uncomplicated, but its also assertive and flavorful.

Bottle. Aroma is strong smoky cocoa w/ some anise and slight herbal notes. Really more like a stout that a porter. Black w/ with a beautiful inch of tan foam. Flavors of sweet cocoa balanced by deep, dark hops. A bit full bodied for a porter. Creamy soft mouth feel and a smooth slowly diminishing tail. Tastes like a stout w/o a heavy body. Truly delicious.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2016 Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, earthy hops, really nice. Appearance is dark dark brown, light brown head, poured thick. Taste is rich roasted malt, chocolate, dark chocolate, earthy hops, great. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy body, soft light carbonation, roasty aftertaste. Overall, this is the best porter around.

[4268-20120122] 355mL bottle. Roasted bready malt aroma. Black brown body with a quick foamy brown head. Roasted coffee malt flavour has a light sweet roast aftertaste. Medium-full body. Quite tasty and drinkable. (7/3/8/3/16) 3.7
(w/ jerc)

bottle pored into a pint glass

a: deep brown color, slight ruby edges. Off white 1/2" head with nice retention

s: roasted malt, slight semi-sweet chocolate

t: rich complex flavor of roasted malt, caramelized malt, and chocolate malt. slight bitterness to keep it all balanced. excellent

m&d: slightly creamy mouth, does finish slightly dry.

Pours an opaque very dark brown with a modest dark tan head and decent spiderweb lacing.  Im not able to figure out the great accolades for this porter.  The taste starts big with black coffee and bittersweet roasted malt.  It never moves from that base.  No turning over with bittering or with dried fruits, or with spices, or with....  The finish is disappointing - it leaves a lingering coating on the tongue and the roof of the mouth.  Also very heavy for a 6.5%abv.  It isnt bad,...there are just other porters that are much better (lets start with Olfabrikken from Denmark, or Koff from Finland, or even Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter from England).

Bottled 01.13.12.  Pours dark red and brown, opaque in the glass, with a small brown head.  Aromas of cocoa, milk chocolate, and caramel, with some coffee and cream, as well as mild berry.  The flavor is espresso, mildly bitter at first, with bittersweet cocoa and mocha.  The finish is coffee and cream, with lingering bitter espresso.  Medium carbonation and body; rich, with a dry finish.  Very nice.  [988]

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2013 When you take your first sip you realize you have hit the "jackpot".  What a wonderful experience.  The porter poured a deep black with a modest head that dissapated.  The coffee and burnt malts assault your tastebuds.  There is a hint of chocolate.  The higher alcohol and IBUs make for a special experience.  This is my fifth beer from Founders.  I will look for more.  The medium body and soft carbonation end very smoothly.  Porters are Gods gift to beer drinkers.
Poured black with a one-finger brown head. Roasty with nice bitter dark chocolate notes. Full body and easy drinking.

Bottle: Dark brown with a tan head and sticky lacing toward the top.  Sweet malty aroma of cocoa powder and Whoppers candy.  The taste is a perfect balance of sweetness and biter charcoal.  The best thing about this is thick rich and creamy like a chocolate milkshake.  Extremely good all around porter.  Quite tasty!

12 ounce bottle from Founders brewery.  Pours black with a small brown head.  Aroma is great; a little chocolate and a lot of roast.  Taste is really chocolatey and smooth, with a lingering roasty bitterness.  A surprising little taste of hops in the finish, too.  A wonderful porter!

Pours an opaque darkest brown almost black.  Quickly gone half finger tan head, but think the pour wasnt exactly spot on.  Very little lacing, spotty.  Getting dark coffee in the nose and something reminding me of Belgian ales I have not liked in the past.  The aroma pretty much ends there...maybe some earthiness but that may be something on my fingers.  

	Im getting like a sort of nutty earth and rubbery cheap candybar in the taste, super thin in the mouth, little oily, sticks around too long with that peanut butter aftertaste thing going on.  And on third/fourth sip Im getting like a heavy sharp dose of medicinal alcohol and is that a dark fruit creeping in?  Not bad, not great, a porter, but not what Im looking for in a porter.  Founders has yet to impress me, the Dirty Bastard Scotch Ale was much on the same level.  Meh.
Pours dark brown with small dark tan like head. Smells and tastes of chocolate malts...very smooth finish. Delightful

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2013 Updated 11/15/2013:
Rich, roasty, chocolatey malts lean against the dry yeast profile.  Bitterness from coffee and the bittersweet chocolate on the back end.  Fresh and delicious.  One of the best widely-available porters on the shelves today.

Original rating:
Bottled 3/20/2011, so its almost a year old. Deep, dark brown pour with dark tan head and sticky lace. Dry roasted malts, strong notes of tobacco, and hops in the nose. Everything from the aroma plus chocolate malts hit my tastebuds. Dry finish. A clean, crisp porter that nails the style.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Deep black-brown body, one inch khaki head, great retention and good lacing coverage.

S: Bold roasted malts, rich bitter-sweet chocolate, mild coffee, and light citric bitterness.

T: Bitter-sweet chocolate, roasted coffee, hint of smoke, citric hops in the back end.

M: Medium-full bodied.  Even, pleasant carbonation, mild bitterness in the finish.

O: A top tier porter that pushes the boundaries of flavor in a respectable 6.5% ABV package.

Bottle at Marie Laveau, Stockholm, February 2012. 

Black with a medium tan head. Aroma and taste of roasted malt, coffee and a lot of dark chocolate. Finish was dry with some notes of hops. A very good and drinkable Porter.

12oz bottle into snifter.  Pours dark brown black.  Think head.  Big malt taste, a good bit of chocolate and a tiny bit of coffee and smoke to it.  Borderline Imperial Stout, pretty much a lighter version of their Imperial Stout.  Overall it is a very good beer but for the price and availability I dont think you can beat this.  Might be the best $10 six pack out there.

Usually the descriptions that they give you on the carrier are total BS, but Founders has actually described their beer exquisitely.  I sometimes find porters to be too thin to stand up to ISs but this one is super rich and full.  Its wonderful to find a great porter that isnt some limited/special edition type beer.  Easy to get and enjoy.

got on tap at gus oconners in rochester.pours black with a nice brown head.very nice lacing on the glass.aroma is very roasty,coffee and malt with some smoke.flavor is right on line with aroma.full bodied with an long bitter finish of roasted coffee and smoke.superb

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head. The aroma is roasted malts and chocolate. Thin mouthfeel with chocolate an light hop with a nice syrupy finish. Easy to drink a very impressive porter from Founders.

Picked this up at Whole Foods in Fairfax, VA. Poured at room temp into a Riedel Snifter

A - 1- Finger head full of leather colors. The beer itself was a dark brown to black. No light showing through at all.

S - Nutmeg, vanilla, chocolate and coffee

T - tons of chocolate. 

M - Very dry but lots of bubbles, medium-bodied

O - Im not sure if this bottle was just old or what but the beer was dry, lacked a lo tof flavor and overall, pretty disappointing.

Pours rich chocolate brown with a thick tan head and lots of sticky lace. Big chocolate and malt aroma. Flavor of dark brown sugar, big roast character,  almost savory cocoa that becomes lightly sweet. Medium body makes it an easy drinker.
12 oz bottle.  Pours deep, deep brown, with caramel coloured head.  Big roasty malt aroma and taste. Great example of the style!

Pours essentially black with a thin off-white head.  The head sustains nicely and leaves some elegant lacing on the glass.  The nose is filled with lots of roasty malts and dark chocolate.  The flavor is just as good and reveals notes of caramel, chocolate and roasted malt.  Carbonation is right on and the body has some nice weight to it.  One of the best off the shelf porters you can pick up.  Highly recommended.

Serving type: bottle. Pours black and thick (opaque).  One finger brown head with moderate lacing. Smells heavily of chocolate and dark roast coffee. Taste is sticky sweet with a nice compliment of a little hop bitterness. This is borderline imperial porter/stout.  One of the best porters I have had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep dark brown pretty much opaque.Light brown head disapating quick.
 Very nice malt aroma with chocolate some buttery sweetness (carmel undertone maybe)
 nice smooth carmel chocolate malt some roast,light coffee The hops pair well with an earthy,herbal character which is smooth and refined
 Nice herbal light pine bitter with a roast and chocolate and coffe/dark malt finish.

Bottle. The pour was a pitch black with a slight ruby hue and an average sized (1-2 finger) medium brown creamy head that totally lasted throughout and produced excellent streaks of lacing.

The aroma was of a roasted chocolate malts and a mildly sweet leathery yeast with notes of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, a bit of caramel and a touch of dark fruit.

The taste was lightly sweet with a hint of chocolate and some dark fruit in the beginning and finished a nice bitter sweet with a healthy dose of coffee and a mild caramel sweetness at the end. The flavor lasted an average amount of time proceeding the swallow, with a mild bitter sweet coffee taste that was left to linger.

Mouthfeel was just about full in body and absolutely creamy in texture with a soft carbonation.

Overall an outstanding Porter. Not to surprising though, seems everything this brewer puts out is just incredible.
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2012 12 oz bottle pours black with a nice tan head.  I love the coffee and chocolate aroma and taste.
From bottle. Black with tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Heavy cocolate and coffee taste. Dry finish, well balanced. Delish.

Bottle:
A big and loud "shhhh" when opening the bottle. No gusher but and explosive vast but with holes/gates (like cheese holes) brown head. The glass is entirely filled with this brown foam. Just one small pour and the head explosively grows again! This foam/head changes really slow, leaves a complete black beer (again with each pour a huge head). Exciting!
Smell coffee, roasted coffee, roasted malts, some dark chocolate, roasted barley, some smoke and tar. Good deep dark roasty smell. Yummi!
Taste is really good roasty, deep, intense. Lovely roasted coffee, good bitter, roasted malts, roasted barleys, roasted herbs, dark chocolate, chocolate bitter, hop bitter, tar, burned wood/coal, hint of (bitter) liquorice. Very tasty, very balanced!
Nice roasted, bitter and herby aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a airy/creamy texture.
Absolutely worth its score this beer gets on ratebeer. Complexity of many of the regular imperial stouts. Supremely balanced and Delicious with a capital D!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: On tap, shared with quiznoaz. Dont get me wrong on this one. I like porters. Sometimes, but this was more of a smoked stout. Maybe. I really cant make up my mind. But you dont really care, do you?
Shared with Holy.  Looks like a porter.  Has a smoky flavor and bitter finish.  More body than typical porters Ive had.  Not bad.
Love this stuff, has a nice thick head, smooth rich flavor. An all around good  beer.

12oz bottle, bottled 11/08/11. Black color, thin tan head. Good lace. Pronounced, sharp carbonation. Very nice distinctly dark and supremely roasty finish. Some nice bitterness. Really nice to pair with my leftover Outback ribs. The carbonation is much more appreciated with a meal. Some chocolate aroma, here. Good amount of hoppiness, here. Nice dryness and drinkability. Really, a great porter. Rich is the key word here, although dark and sexy are appropriate as well.
Huge thick porter, dark brown with a beige head. Aroma has roasted fruirs and barley. Taste is thick with coffee and roasted fruits. It has smokiness and a little bitterness. Great finish.

355 ml bottle bought @ Ölbutikken. Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a small creamy mocha head. That leaves some trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is slightly sweet, malty and full-bodied with roasted malts and lots of quality chocolate in it. Taste is very malty, slightly sweet and slightly bitter with roasted malts and tons of quality chocolate and coffee. Finish is slightly sweet and bitter with roasted malts and coffee. Very impressive and full-bodied for a regular porter. could drink a lot of this...

Bottle @ tasting. Aroma is deep roast, liquorice, chocolate, molasses and more. Flavour is deep roasty malt which hands out a long lingering bitterness followed by sidenotes like chocolate, liquorice, etc.. Very nice.

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Inky dark brew with tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee, some cocoa. Taste is coffee and sweet malts at the start, with a bit of cocoa and cofee in the finish. A little dryness in the finish. Very nice and very good.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2014 Aroma is coffee, dark roasted malts and a hint of hops.  The flavor is coffee, a pretty good amount of cocoa in the middle and a decent hoppiness in finish.  In all areas, this was a great porter.
Pours a rich brown color with a almond color head. Rich toasty flavors with some bright hops light roasted coffee. Feels warm. One of the better porters Ive had.

12oz bottle to a Duvel tulip.  This is my favorite porter to date.  The aroma is roasted malts, and a hint of cocoa.  Appearance dark black, thin mocha head, and decent lacing.  Taste is roasted malts, with chocolate, and coffee notes.  The palate for this is medium-bodied, with a dry finish.  Overall its an exceptional porter.  I would call it my go to porter if it was available here.  Quality.

12oz bottle.  One of my favorite porters.  Pours a nice dark brown/black hue, off white head, decent carbonation.  Aromas are quite delicate, cocoa, malty, but not overly sweet.  Smells more robust than the abv might be letting on.   Palate is quite smooth up front to mid a dusty cocoa and light coffee.  Coffee moves a bit stronger to the mid to finish with a slight bitterness.  Really decent straight froward porter, and for its accessibilty, one of the better on the market.

12oz bottle pours pitch black with a slight reddish brown head.  Aromas of roasted malts, chcoclate and carmel malts, a bit of bread and very slight roasted coffee. Flavor is mildly bitter slight chocolate nib up front and a bit of roasted malts and slight vanilla to balance.  Body is suprisingly smooth and finish lingers a bit

2012-01-22. Black body, small tan head. 3+ Aroma of lightly tangy dark malt typical of many porters, malty core, light roast.  Flavour has rich dark malt core, modest roast highlights, fruity sort of tangy porter character. Muted chocolate undertones. 7+ Average plus to medium bodied palate. Simple and straightforward but quite a tasty porter. Bottle 8 months old, via trade with sprinkle

Bottle- Pours a virtual black color with a off-white head and nice lacing.
 Aroma of roasted malt with coffee and a hint of caramel. Taste of roasted malt and coffee with some bittersweet chocolate. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body, smooth and creamy. Good porter, nice example of the style.
Looks like fresh motor oil in the glass, with little head.  And gives a spirited tumble down the throat.  I could drink this regularly.

I dont know how this one fell through the cracks until now.  Bottle.  Black with a thick creamy tan head.  Milk chocolate aroma and taste with some subtle citrus notes and tastes of roasted grain and drip coffee on the back end.  Silky slightly bright palate makes this an enjoyable beer to drink.

Bottle.Pours a perfect ritmo de la noche with an aroma of chestnutts roasting on an open fire.  Too bad Jack Frost cant nip at my nose right now... Lots of roasted character in this beer.  Flavor follows suit; roasted nuts galore, with a slight coffee addition.  Thick on the tongue.  Fantastic beer.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is black (non-opaque, flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate, husks), lightly hoppy (apricot), with notes of vanilla and alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, slightly husky.

Medium to full body, creamy/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Its just a bit rough, and not terribly deep, but overall a pretty decent porter.  Heavier than most.

Could this be the perfect porter? Everything you want out of the style is here. A light roastyness and mild sweetness with notes of chocolate, coffee, caramel, and burnt malts. I love this beer and always like having some around.

Cheers JoeMcPhee. Thick black, silky pour. Thin tan dirty head. Strong roasted malt, coffee with chocolate aroma. Roasted malt flavour follows through. Chocolate finish with a silky texture. Strong alcoholic notes in the finish.

Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is tons of roast, bitter chocolate and some earthy hops. Flavor is bold chocolate, roasted malts and some coffee leading into a slight bitter finish. Medium full bodied and delicious.
draft at dba brooklyn. Dark pour. wonderful aroma of chocolate & roast. flavor was big roasty delicious chocolatey porter. Medium to bigger mouthfeel. Great porter

Pours black with a huge brown and rocky head.  Nose is spruce sap and chocolate.  Tastes sweet, chocolate sweet with a good amount of hop bitterness to balance.   Crisp, clean and super fizzy.  While the carbonation is excessive in the brew I doesnt necessarily detract from it.  Great porter.

Black beer with huge head that fades fast. Aroma is great with a lot of chocolate and roasted malts. They do come back in the taste, but because the beer is highly over-carbonated, they are far less present than in the nose. Which really is a shame. Would the carbonation have been better, this porter would surely deserve a 4+ rating.

Ah, now thats a porter! Pours oily brown with a bit of head that leaves tons of lacing. Lots of roasted coffee  and a little chocolate and smoke in the nose. Taste is similar with a nicely bitter finish.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2014 Black with a bubbly, soapy head. Coffee - loads of it -, some coffee, cream. Sharp hoppy dark taste with some roasted nuts. Nice tingling mouthfeel. Tasty! (At the De Molen brewery tasting.) 

Re-rate. Pitch black, stable brown frothy head. Aromatic with herbal hops and luscious toasty and roasted malts. Lots of coffee too. Taste is more pronounced overall though, with creamy and milk chocolate malts, roasted bitterness and smoothing sweetness to round off. Nice brew, very high quality and very easy to drink. (On tap at Easy Tiger Austin)

Bottle at monthly tasting @ De Molen. Black pour, foamy tan head. Aroma is roasty, coffee, chocolate, somewhat burnt and a hint of fruits and alcohol. Flavor is roasty, coffee, caramel and some licorice. Overly carbonated.

12oz bottle.  Pitch black pour with razor thin head but a little cling to the glass.  Nose is not very strong but ample in roasted malts, coffee and a touch of vanilla.  Taste is basically roasted malts and coffee.  Very well balanced and none if that metallic taste I find in many porters.  Fairly light on the palate for a porter.  Good stuff.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a nice dark brown color with a small brown head. Tastes of, chocolate, coffee, roasty. Palate, roasty, chocolate, coffee. Overall a terrific porter!
Creamy chocolate taste with coffee and hop notes.  Wow, really nice, especially for a lower abv beer.

(Bottle) Pours black with a creamy light brown head. The aroma is very chocolaty with undertones of blackberries, blueberry jam, subtle dark fruits, asphalt and mild coffee roast. Wow  the malt profile is just fantastic. Perfectly balanced aroma-hops on the nose. A light milkiness also present. The flavour is light to medium sweet and light to medium bitter. A light acidic sting is notable just as the beer hits the tongue. Lots of smooth roast and creamy chocolate. Nice hoppy finish with some roast. The mouthfeel is velvety and round with a light to medium carbonation. Medium bitter ending. Fantastic malt profile in the flavour as well. Medium bodied.

12 ounce bottle.
Aroma: caramel, roasted/chocolate malts, earthy hops
Appearance: dark black, thin off white head
Taste: chocolate, malty sweetness, earthy hops, fruity alcohol notes
Palate: creamy, medium bodied
Overall: The flavor of this beer is phenomenal. This porter was a real treat.

Draught. Pours black with a tan head. Smells of roasted coffee malt. Tastes a strong bitter, smoky, roasted malt, a slow hint of chocolate to sweeten it slightly. Very smooth and creamy. Finishes a bit dry and bitter. An ideal classic porter.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown color with a tiny tan head. The nose is filled with roasted malts, bitter chocolate, smoke, espresso.
