Bottle.Pitch black colour with creamy beige head.Aroma is creamy and rosted with taste of chocolate and coffee,nice well balanced and smooth good full body and rosted finish.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pour is utterly, completely black with a big, initially fizzy, settling, frothy, beige head. Mildly sweet aroma, some roasted malts, light chocolate, a hint of fruity hops. Low carbonation, lovely creamy and dry mouthfeel - impressive for the ABV. Flavour is elegant, lots of roasted malts, good malty dry- and bitterness balanced well by good sweet chocolate and well-used fruity hops. Light vinious even for its low ABV - perhaps thats because there is so much malty taste to it? Very good.
One of my favorite porters, hands down. Wonderfully balanced between chocolate and coffee, with a great head as well that provides that beautiful foam youve come to love.
Bottle @ Kungfu Necktie. Pours a pitch black. Delicious roast and chocolate in the aroma and flavor. The mouthfeel is smooth and well made.

from erzbierschof.ch - dark black coloured with a little dark beige foam left; nice lacework; a solid roasted nose with notes of licorice, vanilla, coffee and pine needles; a good malt body, very tasty, some sweetness and a decent bitterness; long roasted aftertaste of chocolate, nut and licorice - beautiful
Lovely beer. Pitch black, tan head. Very roasted nose and the flavor follows suit--espresso, dark chocolate, caramel. A slightly sweet finish. Soft carbonation. Excellent.

Bottled 355ml. Appearance: It pours a pitch black beer with a decent sized bubbly dark deep beige head. Good retention and average lacework. Aroma: licquorice allsorts, basil, ashes, fudge, vanilla and coffee showing up. Roasty and hoppy. Mint sneaking in. Rather inviting. Taste and palate: Full bodied with a good bitterness. Low carbonation. Faintly warming on the swallow. Impressive malt profile. Ashes are rather present. Chocolatey. Very dry finish which is reminiscent of eucalyptus, pine needles, strong coffee and basil. Overall impression: Full bodied; rather bitter for the style in my opinion and possesing strong flavors. A very powerful and quite pleasant porter.

Pours black with an appropriately sized chocolate colored head. Very nice lacing and slight carbonation. The aroma is very strong: chocolate, roasted barley, and a little bit of coffee. Taste is the same as the aroma except not as strong on the coffee and heavier on the chocolate and roasted malts. Im a huge fan of porters and stouts and this is one of the best ones Ive ever had.

Aroma of dark chocolate, fresh coffee and almonds. Appearance is black with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, but with some chicory flavors apparent as the beer warms. Smoked malt flavors in the finish. Palate is creamy and bubbly. Outstanding Porter.

Bottle. Pitch black pour with a creamy longlasting tan head. The aroma is very roasted with notes of coffee and chocolate. Some light smoky notes. The flavour is hard roasted malt, tobacco, coffee and light chocolate. Some dark bread too. The finish is dry and roasted. Full bodied.

Bottle purchased from Sicilianos market in Grand Rapids, Mich.  Poured into a pint glass.  Drank while brewing a Founders porter clone.  Fantastic aroma of chocolate, malt, cheese, coffee and molasses.  Taste-wise, this is one of the best beers Ive had.  Once again, Founders fails to disappoint.

Color is stout-like. Darkest, deepest brown. Thin, bubbly head. Quintessential porter aroma of chocolate and coffee. Roasty but smooth, it has a wonderful, comforting flavor, with bittersweet chocolate first and some roasted malt sweetness. Flavorful without heaviness. Bitterness lingers slightly. Light-bodied yet satisfying.

This is a wonderful beer, one of my favorite porters.  Flying Dog Gonzo Imperial used to be my favorite, but this might knock it off the top.  Pours a deep dark brown with a tan head that lasts.  Nice aromas of chocolate and toffee.  This is a very rich ale, but goes nicely with chocolate cake.  Enjoy this one!

Flaske: En af de største åbenbaringer jeg har fået længe. Kulsort øl med et flot mokkafarvet skumhoved. Sødlig porterduft med en masse frugt i. Smagen er sød frugtet men bestemt ikke overdrevent, slutter af med en godt fast brændthed. Perfekt afbalanceret. Verdensklasseøl.
Wonderful dark and rich porter with definite hints of chocolate malts and also slight caramel notes the smell is very appealing as well on this porter

Bottle from Archer Liquor. Pours pitch black with a massive brown head and a huge chocolate aroma. It took a while to pour this one, but once the head subsided a bit, I dove in. Well, its really full of chocolate, with a smooth dry bitter chocolate finish and a little carbonation. Its a pleasure to drink, and serves as a dessert as well as a beer.
Bottle at Strømcph in Enghave Parken while listening to Four Tet. Black - brown head. Roasted. Chocolate. Fruity. Light hoppy. Sweetness. Dark bread. Smooth body. A bit boring.

Bottle courtesy GT.  Viscous, shiny black beer with a sharply carbonated brown head. Aroma is dark roasted (almost slightly smokey) malt with bitter chocolate and maybe some slight expresso notes.  Layered chocolate and malt taste with the smoothest transition down into the creamy finish (touch of caramel?) - nothing out of place.  Such a treat to drink a big tasting, stunning beer thats only 6.5% - huge respect to the skill of the brewery.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2012 The sample I got fizzed like crazy, so have a towel handy if opening a bottle! It pours a beautiful midnight sable with a very thick, fluffy, persistent tan head. Smoky, oily aroma has tones of molasses, caramel and fine coffee. Rich flavor has firm smoky overtone and coffee, nutty, molasses and caramel components as well as a hint of hop bitterness. Texture is smooth with a subtle fizz and leaves a nice smoky and slightly sweet finish.
Black pour with a nice tan head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee and tastes similar with slight licorice sweetness. Thick yet drinkable, great example of style.

Pours a deep, deep brown, almost black, with a nice tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee and tastes more of the same.  Great balance and extremely drinkable.  This is the best porter I have had to date.

22 oz draft

Botella. Totally black colour. Pleasant aroma of roasted malt and chocolate, sweet. Good filling mouthfeel. Pleasant roasted maltiness and chocolate in the flavour with dark fruits and some liquorice. Tasty brew indeed.

Bottle at home.
Black coloured with a small beige head.
Light roasted aroma of caramel, roasted bread, chocolate amd liquorice.
Roasted flavour of caramel and liquorice with notes of chocolate and hops.
Light roasted and hoppy finish.

Bottle poured a translucent dark brown nearly black with a small lasting brown head. Aromas of dark chocolate, vanilla and coffee. Palate was medium to full bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of dark chocolate, coffee, vanilla and light carmel with a smooth dry lingering dark chocolate finish.
Deep brown pour with a brownish head. Smells of tar, dark wood and chocolate. Rosted flavours, tar, chocolate, wood and coffee. Very good!

The pour is black with a quickly diminishing tan head.  The aroma is dominated by a deep sense of chocolate and dark roast coffee beans.  Th flavor is very robust with a significant amount of dark roast coffee and unsweetened cocoa.  The finish is wonderful with a strong presence of coffee.  Deep dark roast is easily thw most prominate flavors here.  The mouthfeel is a little heavy and chewy.  Im a little surprised this is a porter and not a stout, even though there isnt a definitive answer to the difference between the two.

Black, black, black with thin tan head.  Roasty malts in the aroma.  Rich and malty flavor followed by roasty and burnt notes.  Very creamy and satisfying.  Well balanced between roast and sweeter malts.

Bottle.  Pours a sexy thick black with moderate brown head.  Dark chocolate, coffee, roasty chocolate malts dominate the nose.  Taste starts sweet and finishes with a light coffee bitterness.  Nice medium-heavy mouthfeel.  Dark, rich, and sexy indeed.

From bottle. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, light smoke, molasses, and licorice. Rich and roasty and sweet. Dark brown-black with thin tan head. Medium chewy body with medium-high carbonation. Starts with rich sweetness, roasted with light bitterness. Chocolate and molasses, carbonic tang with mild alcohol. Bittersweet chocolate finish, light smoke. Sweet after. A nice porter.

Tap at bar Louie, Great lakes crossing mall. Pours deep black-brown with nice tan head. Aromas of light chocolate, mocha and hazelnuts. Medium to full bodied, hop flavours and bitterness though prevalent are overshadowed by the medium-full body of chocolate, caramel-burnt toffee and roasted malts. Medium carbonation, the finish of this beer showcases the continuation of the rich roasty malt flavours (increasingly, more burnt toffee) with some minor bitterness on the finish. A reflective, rich porter.

12oz bottle in a stem glass.  Pours very dark brown with a thick, lingering, tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts, and some earthy/grass flavors for the hops.  Flavor at first of roasted malts, followed by a long chocolate note and some smokiness/hops at the finish.  Thick texture.  An incredible porter.
Bottle - from sampler pack. Very dark and opaque.  Rich, roasty aroma. Really good. Strong malty, roasty and hoppy flavors. An excellent porter.

Lone bottle in a variety 6-pack received as a gift. Unknown age. Poured opaque black-brown into a wide-mouth glass with a 3/8 thick mocha-colored head that dissipated rapidly into dense lacing. Great aroma of roasted pumpernickel. After the huge aroma, surprisingly thin on the tongue. Medium body. After-taste of sharp, slightly acidic carbonation. No sense of alcohol. Labels claim of "Dark, rich & sexy" was achieved. This would be a great beer to have with a hot pastrami sandwich or anything else on a dark rye bread. Very drinkable by its lonesome, probably even better with food. Very nice.
Oh yeah, this will do. A real nice Porter, nearly perfect, with a sexy lady on the label.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a small brown head.   Aroma is of chocolate, bread dough and pralines.  The flavor is sweet and smooth with more chocolate, roasty and earthy flavors, smoke and dirt.  Bitter finish.  This makes the porters from a lot of other brewers look like clumsy imitations of what the style should be.

Bottle thanks to Papat44. Beautiful dark pour with rich creamy moka head. Aroma is delighting, burnt toast with lots of chocolatey-vanilla sweetness and a bit of hops coming through all that as well. Taste started off pretty good, rich and sweet, but fell pretty short in a sort of light lactic sourness, possibly signs of it losing freshness. Palate is creamy, has light carbonation and suits me. I would love to try a very fresh bottle or a tap of this.
One of the better porters I have had.  Smooth and not too overbearing.  Try it if you can find it.

Bottle, poured into my brandy snifter.  Pours jet black with a stunning dark brown head.  I wish it would have retained better, faded quickly.  Aroma was of lots of roasty chocolate malts, actual chocolate and some coffee.  The aroma was almost warming.  First sip unveils some excellent roast flavors.  Big chocolate, drinks super smooth.  Nice creamy mouthfeel, good carbonation.  Finishes dry with little bitterness, extremely smooth.  I could drink this all day.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a dark brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt with an edge of burnt malt combined with light notes of soy sauce. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of caramel and roasted malt as well as lighter notes of soy sauce and wood. The alcohol leaves a slight burn in the mouth.

Black body with a small long lasting brown head. Aroma is chocolate, hops, roasted malt. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, hops and roasted malt. Medium carbonated.

All that a porter should be. Rich chocolate and coffee in a perfect combination. Roastiness with a full mouth feel. If you cant get the breakfast stout this is the closest thing. Quite possibly the best porter I have had.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2010 It has the classic aroma of blended crystal malt and roasted malt. no roasted barley.  some American green citrus hop aroma.  chocolate and just slight coffee.  Overall the aroma is very strong.  very nice.  Almost no carbonation of which produced a very small tan head when poured vigorously! Taste is much the same.  I detect some cold brewed coffee beans.  Maybe just some slight fruits-cant tell for sure, could be the crystal.  The bitterness hangs around for a little while after the swallow.  just enough to float my boat.  A great brew.  Probably better in the winter and if I smoked cigars.

Pours a dark thick black color with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and hops. Intense and well-balanced flavor of chocolate, hops, coffee, and some roasted malts.  Slight hop bitterness. Great porter!  Thanks for the trade JB.

12 oz. Tried as part of a porter tasting.

A: Jet black with minimal lacing.
S: Dark chocolate and coffee.
T: Coffee and dark chocolate notes pervade this brew.
M: Medium body and no carbonation - perhaps a bit too smooth.
Black with a tan head. Aroma is roasted with strong chocolate. Flavor is roasted coffee with a slight chocolate aftertaste. Very well balanced, excellent porter.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2013 Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours opaque black with a slight highlight of dark brown and pretty good lacing.  Head is medium brown, thick body. and creamy smooth texture.  Taste is roasted malt, nut, some mocha/chocolate, and some herbal hops.  Had this back to back with smuttynose robust  porter; and this one looks better, has a better palate, but the aroma and taste of both are good in different ways.

12 oz bottle.  Pours super dark brown, almost black.  Light mocha head.  Aroma is super dark roasted coffee and burnt nuts, in a good way.  Only hints of something sweet, but just faint.  Little sweetness then a great roasty bitter finish.  This is not harsh by any means and is a great example of how to get dark roasted flavors into a beer while making it incredibly drinkable.

Bottled. Black with a large light brown head. Aroma is roasted nuts and coffee and a ton of vanilla. Flavor is also roasty, in a very smooth brew that has notes of chocolate, buts and coffee...well done and straightforward.

Bottle. Black pour with some tan head. Coffee, and dark malts with some light bitter hop aromas. Caramel, chocolate and roasted malt flavors are slightly sweet, but not overly, not so much hop presence and the texture is very nice for a porter.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2010 best porter. very roasty, chocolate, hops. how is this even a porter? i would rate this with the very best stouts ive had.
An amazing porter. This is by far my favorite porter. Big, roasted, chocolate, goodness. Amazing porter.

Pours a deep, opaque brown with swirls of black and a milk chocolate mocha head. Lots of small bubbles. Very nutty on the nose -- almonds, I think -- as well as toffee, darkish (but not too bitter) chocolate, and roasted malts. Carbonation is nice but a bit much on the back of the mouth -- one of my few complaints. More complex than most porters Ive had -- develops a bitter dark chocolate/almond aftertaste due to the hops used. Really nice -- creamy in the mouth, except for the back of the throat carbonation, which interrupts the smooth experience like some sort of jealous bully. At this point, thats my only complaint.

12 ounce bottle - $1.79 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Dispenses an onyx black body sporting a tall, proud-looking, dark tan head with plenty of staying power and substantial lacing.

Smell: Rich malty nose of bold, roasty coffee beans, melty bittersweet chocolate bars, licorice sticks, and moist dark fruits. A delightfully sultry scent, indeed.

Taste: The firm roastiness leads in the taste, with a flavor of strong coffee unabashedly laced with chocolate sauce, licorice, and a hint of real vanilla bean. Amply sweet throughout. Dark fruitiness buried within the heady maltiness. Roasty, earthy bitterness. Shot of cream. Long, leisurely, roasty finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Smooth, succulent creaminess to the mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Its really pushing at the boundary line between porters and stouts. A sterling, tasty robust porter from ole Founders and one I freely, even cheerfully recommend to others.

Draft at Cascarelliis in Homer, MI.  Pours a opaque black.  Tan head.  Good lacing.  Aroma of chocolate.  Taste of chocolate and coffee malts.  Nice balance between the sweet and bitter.  Medium to full bodied.  Very creamy and smooth.  Another excellent beer from Founders.

Solid and full of character. Chocolate and creamy goodness. A little toasty marshmallow in the flavor as well and you are left with a great sweetness. A real treat. Perfect desert drink that would pair nicely with plenty of sweet treats. Aroma reminds me of currants and has a bit of burned sugar in there as well.

$1.80/12 oz. Archer Liquors. Chicago,IL. Pours black with a good 1 inch head that fades. What a nice aroma, very big coffee roast. It smells like there really is coffee in here even though there isnt. The taste is nice good roast, more coffee, some chocolate and a creamy mouthfeel that can be almost gritty. I really like how this beer tastes like coffee. Does Founders make any bad beers?

Pours black with a thin brown head. Aroma is a deep mix of chocolate, roasted grain. Taste is impressive, light chocolate, malty, dark, with a perfect level of bitterness. Palate is rich and creamy. Overall this is an excellent porter, one of my favorites.
Bottle courtesy of Rando7. Black pour with a tan head. Nose is nutty chocolate. Taste is chocolate, malts, nuts and caramel.

Poured very dark brown, almost black with a hint of orange highlights as light passed through at the base of the glass. The head was tall and creamy and left a good amount of lacing throughout the glass. There was a good prominent aroma of dark chocolate and anise. The initial taste was slightly dry with a good amount of anise flavor and a bit of dark chocolate bitterness. The bitterness mellowed quite a bit leaving a nice slightly dry finish of anise and chocolate that faded away gradually. This is an excellent beer. Very easy drinking.

Drank from a pint glass from the taps at Rattle N Hum, NY,  Pours a jet black color with little carbonation and a slim whitish head. Nice dark chocolate flavor, some roasted malt, little bit of alcohol punch toward the end.

Pours black with minimal tan head. Head recedes quickly. Aroma of chocolate, sweet malt and a hint of hops. Flavor is very chocolaty. Bitterness is present throughout, but not overpowering. Strong coffee flavor. Silky smooth on the palate. Carbonation is slightly stingy, but blends well with the thick body. Overall, a great porter. Awsome body and well balances. Roasty and robust.

Bottle.  Pours almost black with minimal tan head.  Nose is more suggestive of a stout than a porter: dry with lots of toasted malts, some chocolate.  Medium-bodied, dry , roasty, chocolate.  Finishes long, bitter, chocolaty.  Overall a great porter.

Pours a very dark cola with a small foamy tan head that leaves lots of lacing. I found the aroma to be very smokey, with mesquite and tobacco, with a good amount of espresso roast, and some slight noble hops. The flavor is more roasty coffee, with a bit of tobacco, and a fair mix of coffee and hops. The mouthfeel is thick for a porter imo, but thats not really a bad thing. Soft carbonation and a biting bitter finish round this out. I traded a Kalamazoo Stout for this on Dark Lord Day and Im glad I did, THANKS! dude whose name I cant remember.

Tap at Founders.
Minimal head.  Lightly sweet, but rich enough that it wasnt sweet. One of the tastier porters Ive had.
Bottle at Andy and Maxs fantasy tasting.  Pours a hazy black to brown with a medium sized tan head.  Caramel, roast, toast.  Medium bodied, roast and chocolate.  Lingering roast.  Decent porter.

At Tylers Apex. Good aroma Sweet, malty nutty, chocolate, coffee, roasty. Brownish black color, Good head and lace. Bittersweet flavor. Chocolate and coffee. Medium body, lite creamy mouthfeel, dry bitter finish. Very tasty, really enjoyed both aroma and flavor, aroma stayed constant as it warmed and flavor was rich and never got dull.....Cant believe I went this long before rating this one....
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Black/brown with a small brown head. Aroma was mainly chocolate and coffee. Flavor was chocolate, coffee, something metallic, with a slight bitter roasted malt finish. Moderate body with a slight carbonated tingle.

(bottle) Opaque brown body, and big, thick dark brown head. Aroma is strong with chocolate and coffee, dark fruit, roasted malt, and underlying hops. Medium bodied.  Sweet, and somewhat acidic with a coffee and roasted malt flavor, and a dry, grassy hop finish. Very smooth and balanced.

Poured a dark, oily black with a thin brown lacy head.  Strong taste, but in a good way.  Not as bitter as I thought it was going to be, and has pretty strong coffee and chocolate flavors.  Good, complex palate with a good aftertaste.
Black pour tan head ... chocolately roasted malt aroma ..... taste of chocolate and roasted malts sweet  but not overly .... clean light hop finish ... an awesome porter rich and chocolatey

one of the last at the tasting.. Pours a basic dark brown .. satisfying foam .. . good roast level .. . a touch thin, but makes it very drinkable .. a good brew but for founders? .. . 

Hey! Now Ken, we all know that the moon is not made of green cheese.
Yes, thats true Harry.
But what if it were made of barbeque spare ribs, would you eat it then?
Tremendous taste of coca,  burnt oak, and a non-bitter, utterly smooth roasted coffee. Nice alcohol and grassy hop kick on the finish. Best porter Ive tasted.

We are lucky craft brewers still put so much effort into a "normal" beer style. Pours a dark espresso black with a thin head that fades to a thin ring. Aroma of toast malt and dark chocolate. Phenomenal body with a smooth dark chocolate, even a whiff of burnt chocolate. Thank you for a great porter.

aroma is mostly wet roast, perhaps a hint of pumpernickel.  body is dead opaque with wispy film head and touches of lacing.  flavor is giant juicy chocolate.  tiny hint of sweetness comes late but overall sweet and none my dismay.  java is completely absent but chocolate is more then worthwhile.

Rich black color with a mocha head. Rich chocolate aromas, earthy hops, roasty, dark malt. Flavor is coffee and coco, subdued bitterness, piquant and metallic. Silky and soft on the tongue, enveloping and extremely drinkable. This is a sultry, dark brew.

Growler fill from New Beer. Pours essentially black, slightly thin, with moderate cappuccino head. Aroma of coffee, vanilla bean, and currants. The vanilla is sharp and layers on top of the dark coffee aroma. Flavor is of wet coffee grounds, roasted malt, and a touch of smoke. The wet coffee grounds just keep coming. Earthy undertones that lead to a bitter coffee and nutty finish. Moderate to thin body with a slightly oily mouthfeel. This gets me more excited than ever to try the breakfast stouts from Founders.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2010 Considered one of the best porters in this world and available to me week in and week out and I havent tried this yet? Shame on me. Nice deep brown color with a tan head. Wonderful nose is thick and rich w/ coffee and chocolate--potent, smooth and inviting. Flavor is perhaps not quite at the same richness but is very much in the same territory. Medium bodied, slightly oily slick w/ perhaps a hair too much carbonation. But, so as not to end on a down note, I should mention this detracts very little from the overall presentation of this fine dark ale. I can see why this is so highly rated; its good.

Deep brown in color, brown head with large bubbles which dissipates but gathers around the edges and leaves good lacing. Clear roasted and chocolate malt in the nose, espresso and shoe polish. The body is full and rich, but there is a lightness that makes it slide right over the tongue. Flavors of chocolate and roasted malt (sweetness emerges at it warms); finishes with a lasting and puckering dry roasted bitterness.  The description on the bottle gets it just right: dark, rich and sexy. It would be easy to confuse it with an imperial stout in a blind taste test. Fantastic.

A great porter. How did it take so long? Anyway, bottle thanks to FlandersNed. Pours a pure black color with a very large thick beige/brown head. The aroma is sweet chocolates, roasted malts, sweet coffee, earthy. The flavor is charred chocolates, roasted malts, sweet milky flavors, light metallic hops linger in the background. A smooth milky flavor with ashy sides dominates. Just delicious, Reminds me a bit of Sam Smiths Oatmeal Stout- and I love that beer.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2011 Tap sample at New Beer Dist. Certainly deserves the praise. Pours pitch black with a strong, tan head. Big nose of coffee and chocolate. Flavor is rich and layered, sweet and bitter. Nice burnt malt character with adequate sweetness. Plenty of mocha. Tail holds some bitterness. Very roasty finish. Quite smooth and well-bodied. Delicious.

Update: Had a full pint at Mugs Ale House tonight. Yeah, just multiply everything above by three. This is the best porter I have ever had.

12 oz bottle @ Brickskellers in DC. Pours black, nice brown head and nice lacing to boot. Aroma and flavor like any other porter- but better. Little hop at the end is a nice touch. Nice and creamy. Sadly I had to compare this to Bells Kalamazoo, which I drank just before this one... I guess Ive been in tougher predicaments before... Great beer.
Warm smoke and chocolate on the nose.  Subtle though.  Almost campfire like.  Dark with a medium flat and lasting head.  Taste is of chocolate with bitterness biting.  Some smoke. A good porter.
This was an excellent beer.  NIce robust flavor with and smooth finish.  Glad I tried ths one

Yup, this is a beauty. Pours next to black with a creamy pancake floating on top. Nice lacing. Smells of crushed rock and roasted coffee beans. Full and chewy on the palate with creamy carbonation. This is a meal unto itself. This drinks more like a Foreign Stout.

12oz bottle. Pours very dark brown - almost black - with a moderate but short-lived tan head that leaves huge swaths of lace all over the glass. The aroma is a wonderfully deep chocolate with notes of fresh toasted bread (like freshly ground light roast coffee beans) and an subtle and sublime earthiness. The flavor starts full of chocolate with bittersweet notes that include vinous barley malt tang as well as heavily sweetened dark roasted coffee - vaguely reminiscent of espresso sweetened with Frangelico (though not really so hazelnutty). The finish is full towards the back of the palate and then turns to dryness as it finally rolls into the gullet. Lots of chocolate character, but no burnt or acrid character at all - very smooth and fairly sweet as well, with some subtle bitter flavors of ethanol creeping in. The aftertaste is malty with lots of chocolate. The mouthfeel is quite creamy and full-bodied - luxurious but for notes of thinness around the edges of the mouth. The carbonation is fairly soft and provides just enough levity to make it feel fluffy and creamy. Overall, a very well-done porter - quite drinkable. Were it a little drier and a little less sweet, it would be even better.
Draught.  Poured dark with small tan head. More of a sweet stout almost.  Chocolate and malts etc.  Pretty good.

Pint at Rattle n Hum.  This is one big boy of a porter.  Many stouts are thinner and less robust than this sucker.  Pour is outstanding black with frothy beige head. Mouth feel is full, but thinly carbonated.  Loaded with espresso, dark chocolate and a nice hop sting in the finish.   This is probably the best porter Ive had, if not.. 2nd for sure.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2010 Re-rate.  The aroma is a chocolate, roasty, earthy.  The appearance is true to the style, deep brown, white head.  The flavor is chocolate, roasty, coffee.  Medium/thick in body, creamy mouthfeel.  Roasty finish.  Decent porter.
Amazing beer.  By far my favorite porter of all.  Had it on tap at the founders brewery in Grand Rapids.  Nice place as well.

Very dark brown, almost black color with a nice and thick light brown head.  Aroma is full of chocolate malts, dark chocolate, some roastiness, nuts, and coffee.  Flavor is full of dark chocolate and coffee.  Not too carbonated, just the right about of palate.  Leaves a nice dark chocolate finish.  Bravo Founders.  Bravo.

Very balanced. Nice coffee and chocolate flavor. Chocolate is bittersweet with nice coffee mild bitterness. Well flavored without being over the top. Full mouth without being sticky. I wanted another when it was finished. Really well done.

Pitcher at Winking Lizard in Mentor Ohio. I had 1 and my friend had 1. Two beautiful black Pitchers of Goodness . Nose is milky cocoa, smokey, nice malted milk character, some dark fruits & really dark caramel. Flavor is sweet roasty malt,   rich dark fruits. A touch of burnt in the slightly smokey & malty finish, along with a bit of hop that balances things perfectly. 1 of my favorite Porters "Ever" along with a Founders Breakfast Stout.....mmm Good.

A deep dark porter with a thin moka head. A pungeant aroma of chocolate, some light boiled veggies. In mouth, a lightish porter with smooth powdered chocolate, medium bodied. On tap at Afterwords Café, Feb. 2010.

Pours a dark opaque coffee color with a thick dark beige head.  Aroma is a mix of roasted malts heavy on cocoa/bittersweet chocolate.  Taste was the same as the aroma, although there was a little kick to it.  The beer was really thick, reminded me of an expedition stout from Bells when pouring.  However, the carbonation was pretty weak, so it felt like i was drinking a thin syrup rather than a beer.  However, given its taste and price, a great drinkable beer.
probably one of the best porters ever. a lot of chocolate and coffee, perfect mouthfeel and carbonation, and perfect black color. awesome!

My reward for 500 miles driving today was scoring a couple sixes of Founders products.  Oh my, this is a porter?  Looks like a baltic, pours out a thick black, ends with a thick tan head.  Nose is rich cocoa and roasted and toasted malt.  Palate is medium thick but very heavy for a porter.  Very sweet but tons of hops in there too balance out the chocolate malt.   Almost too sweet.    Very oily mouthfeel too, surprisingly good stuff, well not so surprising I love this brewer.

Pours a dark thick black color with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and hops.  Intense and well-balanced flavor of chocolate, hops, coffee, and some roasted malts.  Exceptional porter!
UPDATED: DEC 29, 2013 Bottle. Thick dark pour with a tan head. Nose is chocolate and roasty. Taste is semi-creamy, big roastiness, and sweet chocolate. Nice hop bitterness. Excellent porter.

Dark, Rich, and Sexy? Yes yes yes. Pours black with a nice big cappuccino colored head. A full nose of milk chocolate and bitter coffee with some earthy hops in the background. As the head settles a transfixing lace lays. Doesnt get much better pre sip. This is a wonderful porter. Black malts pack a punch with silky dark chocolate, and some smoky highlights. At 45 IBUs, hoppy bitterness completes this robust flavor. Intensely dry finish, like I need water. Full bodied, great feel and carbonation. Another excellent beer from Founders, who are no doubt a top 3 favorite brewery of mine. I am left to ponder, who is the woman on the label?
UPDATED: MAY 11, 2010 12 oz bottle into pilsner glass.   Pours thick and almost black, one-finger head.  Taste is chocolate and coffee with a mild-moderate hoppy finish.  Really good.
Pours a dark black.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, smoke.  Taste is bitter and dry.  Flavor is chocolate, earth, coffee.  Very intensely flavored.  Finish is earthy and dry.

12 oz. bottle to snifter. poured dark brown with thin tan head. Aroma was coffee and malt with faint chocolate. Taste was chocolate and malt with malty after tones. Palate has thin to medium feel which feels slick yet finishes somewhat dry. Overall one of the best porters that I have had!

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2010 12oz bottled Feb 2, 2010, this is quite fresh.  Served cool room temp into a Duvel tulip.  Pours thick very dark brown/black with a one and a half finger dense brown head that maintains a light cap and leaves some spotty lacing.  Aroma is very very roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, some smoke, roasty toasty.  Can pick up a touch of earthy hops.  Flavor is smooth milk chocolate, dark roasted malts, coffee, some bitterness on the finish along with some lingering sweetness.  Mouthfeel is full, velvety, and rich, medium carbonation.  Thicker and richer than many other regular porters.  This is one of the best, if not the best porter out there.  Excellent.

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours very dark brown, almost like motor oil out of the bottle, but not quite black.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, earthy hops, dark fruits, burnt sugar, and oats.  Flavor of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, dark fruits (cherries, plum, and figs), burnt sugar, and earthy hops.  Medium-full bodied, with light carbonation and an oily mouthfeel.  So smooth.  Rich and robust.  Finish is lightly roasted, tart, and earthy.  What a cool beer.  This is a great standard for porters.
Black pour -mocha head.Taste of chocolate, coffee, mocha.Has a oily sweet bitter coffe finish.GReat porter will drink again and again.

Pour from bottle.  Deep black with tan, creamy head that laces very well.  Chocolate comes through strong in the aroma with hints of coffee and a trace of smoke.  Moderately sweet and bitter.  Full body that starts creamy and ends dry with medium finish.  Best porter Ive tried.

On tap at Trappeze.  Pours dark brown with a brown head, lots of lace. Aroma is chocolate and roasty, some nut.  Taset is also roasty and sweet, with lots of chocolate, some light hop notes, and lots of malt sweetness.  Mouth is creamy and full. Overall, a nice porter.

Rating 501 of this brew.  Got it in a trade.  Beersommelier maybe? MrChopin maybe?  Either way, its yummy.  12 oz bottle.  Dark to black with brown persistent head.  Heavy lace, ala burlap, and fit ring, like around a latte or mocha.  Nose is super sweet with malt.  Taste is bonk of sweet that takes a long time to work itself out.  Flat and tart in the front moving round as it goes back.  Full mouth at the end.  Creamy end, with a bite of chocolate leftovers, like the gooey bitterness left over after chocolate milk.  Nice beer!
I dont like porters. This is no porter. Black and chocolate, but dry like a porter. Its more of a really good, dry stout.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2014 Pours dark black with off white head, aroma is full of dark coffee and chocolate notes.  Taste is rich with chocolate, smoke, and some floral notes, ending smoky and chocolatey with a nice thick mouthfeel.  Excellent porter!

another fine founders offering... pours fairly thich and very dark, almost stout-like.  thick tan head and heavy, heavy lacing.  nose is dark roast and dark chocolate with raisen and vanilla and hints of smoke and coffee.  taste is superb, as are most of the founders beers.  certainly one of the better porters available.

A thick opaque brown brew.  Minimal tan head.  A grassy chocolate aroma.  Rich bitter taste, long lasting, making it seem more stout like as the chocolate sweetness and balance is lost, which I like in a porter.  Still, this is a memorable beer.

The aroma is not as boisterous as I hoped.  The roast is the predominant feature, with a little bit of dark chocolate and nuttiness.  The initial pour is wonderful.  The head waits to set until the entire bottle is emptied.  The color is a very dark lovibond 20, lovely dark black-brown.  The head that appears is initially nice and level, about an inch thick, and tan.  Nice lacing develops as the beer disappears.  The taste is rich with lots of very good roasted sugars and coffee.  The taste of nuts also appears, but I presume that is only a suggestion.  On the palate the body is medium to full.  The texture is slick and creamy.  The carbonations is soft.  The finish is a bit bitter and last for a long time.

Bottle from a trade from RCL. Pours dark brown with light tan head. Aromas of lightly roasted malts and chocolate. Flavors of roasty malts and bittersweet chocolate. Medium to full body with moderate carbonation. A well done porter. Thanks Ray.

-Date Tasted : 1-29-10
-Rating : 4
-Brew Date/Batch# : N/A
-Mode/Price : 12oz. bottle
-Source : St. Louis area grocery
-Appearance : black with excellent chocolaty color head, great pour
-Aroma : milk chocolate aroma with fine hops hiding in this brew
-Flavor : everything you want in a porter including nicely balanced chocolate & coffee flavor that isnt too sweet. I really like the hops in this porter.
-Overall : Smooth way above average porter. Great find Ill be looking for this one again.

Bottle. Pours near black with a tan head. Nice roasted malt aroma with light notes of coffee and a hint of creamy chocolate. The flavor has roasted malts, dark chocolate and a light hoppy hint on the back end. Wonderfully smooth.

12oz bottle.  black with no bubbles.  small, creamy, brown head.  coffee, milk chocolate aroma.  a medium bodied porter with a silky palate.  flavor is heavy on the creamed coffee and milk chocolate.  leaves a nice long, lingering roast flavor.  a realy nice go-to porter from founders.  supposedly it stays stocked year round.  hope so.  i wish the palate was just a bit fuller though.

Founders Porter has to be the best porter Ive ever laid lips to.  When I first tasted it, it compared very closely with Victorys Storm King Stout.  The beer poured pitch black with a very minimal dark brown head.  There wasnt much lacing left around the glass, either.  The nose was full of hops, dark chocolate and earth.  The body was fairly heavy, but smooth and drinkable.  The flavors were very bitter and hoppy, especially in the finish.  Other flavors noted were of a milky but dark chocolate, red grapes and alcohol.

A - Pours think and black. Or should I say dark, rich and sexy? Nice dark brown head. Beautiful.

S - That is so nice. Roasted malt and coffee and that unmistakable "porter" smell.

T - Very, very roasty with bitter coffee and a bit of sweet. Some mild hop to compliment it. The lingering taste is a great mix of the roasted and sweet malt.

M - So smooth. It may just be that RIS is my favorite style but this is amazing going down.

D- I know that the %6+ ABV is too high for the sessionable police but Id say this is the most sessionable beer Ive ever had.

12 oz. bottle via trade with ksurkin - Pours a dark brown color with a one finger thick tan head.   Faint lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, and dark esters.  Flavor is dark malts and coffee.  Finish is slightly bitter do to the dark malts.  Medium body.  Very roasty.   Nice beer.  Thanks Ken.

This has become my favorite porter. This beer a true golden example of what porters should be. Pours a small dark brown head with a very very dark brown body. The flavors of dark chocolate, coffee, and toffee. Its a beautiful beer by one of my favorite breweries. Great great job guys.

12 oz bottle. About time I got to this one. Pours like ebony, perfectly dark with a large soft tan head that laces all the way down the glass. Aroma is of fresh roasted coffee and cocoa powder, like walking into a coffee shop. Tastes strongly of bittersweet chocolate, sweetness of the malt comes through first with some spiciness, but is nicely offset by the hop bitterness, very well balanced. Finishes sweet, with a a little more bitterness on the tongue (like chewing a mint leaf). A wonderful porter.

Poured out the bottle with a deep, dark molasses body with a deep caramel, tan head that did not dissipate. Sweet malty aroma and very roasty flavor with chocolate and roasted coffee bean overtones. A very warm mouthfeel with a dry aftertaste isnt overwhelming on the palate. A good, hardy beer.

Pours black with a medium mocha head which settles quickly.  Subdued aromas of dark chocolate, coffee, and smoke.  Taste is burnt roasted dark chocolate, black coffee, tiny hint of hops, burnt malt bitterness in the finish. Decent porter.  Still like Edmund Fitz Great Lakes better.

Black hole pour with medium head of deep tan, frothy head.  Aroma is strong with roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor is on par with aroma plus 90% cocoa chocolate swirling around in the midst.  Potent porter.
(bottle) black with no head. Aroma of coffee, roatsted malt. Flavor is sweet, coffee, slightly sweet malt, raisins
Bottle. Pours motoroil black with about the same viscosity. Small creamy light brown head. Flavor is lots of coffee and dark chocolate. This beer is pretty close to a meal in liquid form.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2013 Pours a viscous black, not much foam. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, maybe a hint of licorice. Creamy mouthfeel. Taste is a nice roasty coffee flavor, lots of dark chocolate. Fantastic.
Pours a thick, almost oily black with little to no head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, roasted nuts. Complex blend of flavors with a smooth finish. An excellent beer all around.,
Black with a large beige head. Sweet aroma with burned malt, coffee and chocolate notes. Flavour was sweet with chocolate and burned malt. Finished sweet. Nice one.
Another excellent beer from Founders.  Great Porter with strong hops, rich, and smooth.  Not too heavy, but what you expect from a proper porter.
Thick, rich, bitter, sweet, dark. A meal in the making. This one deserves further research.

Pour is quite black with a frothy tan head that recedes slowly. Aroma is loaded with roasted barley, chocolate, coffee, and cream. Quite a surprising roast component considering the style- the nose skirts the line with a sweet stout. Flavor is a malt heavy torrent of roasted barley, lactic sugar, bakers chocolate, dark roasted coffee, and molasses. Mouthfeel is thick, rich, creamy, and with pillowy effervescence and a roast-dry chalky finish. The complexity is such that the flavors that are present in the most excellent proportions, Well done.

Pour is black and oily with a small tan head.  ARoma is nicely roasted coffee with some chalky creaminess.  Some light hints of anise, chocolate and some doughiness.  Mouthfeel is silky and creamy,  Flavor is immediately roasty with coffee bean, bakers chocolate, bitter notes as well.  Wonderfully flavorful and top notch mouthfeel.

Pours pitch black with a small tan head- really dark, like a stout. Aroma holds lots of roasted malt, coffee, anise, dark chocolate, and some definite creamy and lactic notes. Flavor is very nice; more roasted malt, lactic sugars, bitter chocolate- really just an excellently crafted porter in flavor. Palate is rich and full, but also glides down really nicely. Excellent example of the style, another great brew from Founders.

pitch black pour with nice lacing khaki head.  The aroma and flavor are equally impressive.  Solid vanilla, dark bitter chocolate, roasted malt, tobacco, a bit of dark fruit, and a pleasant and balancing hop presence on the finish.  Medium to full body.  Overall:  $11 is a bit steep for a 6er normally, but this is worth it, no problem.

Pours nearly black with a thick dark tan head and great lacing.  Wonderful aroma that is a blend of  smoke, molasses, chocolate, and alcohol.  Each of these are very prevalent in the flavor, but well balanced by a nice bitterness.  Great Porter, might even be my favorite.  Founders does it again.

Bottle.  Pours thick, near black color with a very small light brown head.  Smokey aroma, with dark chocolate, vanilla and coffee also present.  Heavy roasted flavor with hints of coffee and cocoa.  Bitter finish with a slight trace of alcohol warmth.  While it is medium-full in body, its not as heavy as the appearance would lead you to believe.  Well carbonated with a creamy texture.  Very solid porter.

12oz bottle. This is perhaps the best porter I have tasted. It is similar in taste to an impy stout but without all the crazy alcohol. Pours dark black with a tan head and nice lacing. Packed with lots of malt and smoky goodness. Delicious.

Thick jet black pour with a small tan head. Wonderful roasty aroma, chocolate, coffee and a bit of alcohol. Nice creamy palate, semi-sweet chocolate flavor and a little bitterness from the right amount of hops. Absolutely fantastic porter, my favorite so far.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Wine and Beer Westpark, 12/10/09 


Aroma: Aroma is strong on roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate

Appearance: Pours a thick, dark brown color with a light brown head

Flavor: Flavor is roasted malts with a bit of earthy hops

Palate: The body is medium-full, thick, with soft carbonation

Overall Impression: 
Overall this is a pretty good Porter.  It has the thick, dark pour of a heavy stout.  Its pretty much what you would have expected from the style with its massive malt nose that leads to a massive malt (with a little hop) flavor.  Still though, it is pretty good, and certainly enjoyable, another nice beer from Founders.

Bottle. Stout-like black with a  foamy medium-dark tan head, with good retention. Nose of some dry malt, maybe a little hops. Flavor sweet up front and chocolaty, with maybe a tiny hint of coffee-like bitterness. Definitely let this one breathe a bit after pouring, because at first it had a somewhat acrid bitter flavor. It becomes fairly smooth and clean, but the bitter flavor doesnt really leave the aftertaste. Good porter, but not as fully dimensional as Black Butte, which is my standby porter. I suppose this is more of a British style porter, though, rather than a robust one.

Pours a black brown with a half a finger of dark beige head.  Dark rich odor of chocolate and some toast.  Great flavor, starts off soft and builds steadily.  Hints of Caramel, vanilla, and chocolate, and ends with a nice burnt toast aftertaste.  This is a really solid porter
thanks whoever gave me this! excellent basic session porter, wow! super nice taste and palate on this, ubercreamy and rich, not too much alcohol, a real winner for a DD(daily drinker)!

From a 12oz bottle into a pint glass. Pours with an inch of gray/brown head which dissipates quickly leaving a decent amount of lacing.  Aroma is of dark coffee.  Taste is of hard core coffee and chocolate.  Kinda that taste of over roasted Starbucks coffee.  Chocolate is also very prevalent.  Mouthfeel is very thick, almost bordering on a stout (but hey, whats the difference).  Overall, this really is the stepson of Founders Breakfast stout, but without the chocolate flavor.  I very much liked this beer although it was on the thick side for a porter.  The flavor was also too biased towards coffee and without any other flavors.  I would happily drink again.

Bottle. Pours black with a decent tan head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee and nuts. Full bodied with mildly creamy carbonation. Flavors of chocolate, hazel nuts, and vanilla? Neither sweet nor bitter. Really good finish of coffee/chocolate. Quite tasty.

While I am somewhat knew at beer tasting, so far this is my favorite beer.  Stouts and Porters are my favorite types though.  Full bodied porter with smoky flavor and somewhat dry with a nice but not overwhelming bitterness to it.  Very nice dark color.  A great beer overall and now I cant wait to taste the Founders Breakfast Stout this weekend and find out what all the raving is about.
Bottle: Falkenstein brought it from MO; a solid Porter, but my preferred style. Food Pairing: Pastel Chocolate Tóxico from Chef Andre.
gracias david, con el gordo y el aleman.  esta birria me gusto, va mas con mi estilo, la mejor de la noche por no ser tan dulce y por tener cuerpo y maltosa oscura.  buen balance con hops; yummy
Deep brown almost black with tan head and lace. Aroma of toasted malt and coffee. Chocolate, medium coffee, with a nice malt bitter. Medium/full bodied with good carbonation, and a hint of thin.

Opaque black body topped by a massive creamy khaki colored head that leaves some lovely lacing all the way down the glass. Rich aroma of roasted barley cocoa powder and espresso. Bitter dark chocolate with undertones of licorice, and roasted coffee flavors. Full bodied with a smooth and creamy texture. Very well done.

This porter is highly rated on this site but Ive tasted far better porters.  This ale is too roasted, too bitter, too metallic.   The overly roasted malts dont allow for the smoothness or sweetness of superior porters like Samual Smiths Taddy Porter.

Extremely drinkable, dark brown verging on black pour with minimal off white frothy head.  Aroma of robust coffee, dark chocolates, and heavier malts.   Goes down very smooth, and at 6.5 alc I think Ill have another.

tle from the brewer 3 months ago. Pours jet black with lots of brown foam in head, that leaves a spider lace trail. Aroma of roasted malts, and a hint of mollasses. As we drink through the pint, chocolate malts are noticed in aroma as well as taste. Carbonation is right there, and refreshing. Anise and chocolate in residual.Great porter.Average mouthfeel, smooth drinking.
From a bottle poured dark brown with almost no head.  Nice sweet toasted malty flavor with a lingering finish.
Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma with hints of coffee. Roasted malty chocolate and coffee flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.
Strong coffee flavor with slight bitter finish. Pretty good porter overall but not the best ive ever had.
Thick oil like dark pour.  Dark tan head.  Toffee cream malt aroma.  Some roast and chocolate.  Bitter flavor.  Creamy with a roasted hop finish.

Aroma-burnt malt is first smell, then a slight alcohol smell.  Not an awful aroma but not good either.
Appearance-head is too think.  Not a good example of Porter but average.
Flavor-the roasted malt dominates the flavor but not a bad flavor.  Slightly above average.
Palate-bitterness lingers but so does alcohol taste.  Slightly better than average.
Overall-Probably would not drink again but if I had to, I could.  Not a bad beer but not a very good one either.
On tap.  Very black with tan head.  Taste of roasted malts and coffee very well blended together.  Bitter as well, but not too much.
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2010 Excellent porter!  Duh...its rated tops in category for a reason.  Reminds me the equally formidable Bells porter.  Cant ask much more than what Founders is delivering here.

Outstanding Porter.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, and sterile metal.  Flavor is a big hit of very bitter dark chocolate with some cola taste.  The only thing better than its flavor is the synchronization of aroma, flavor, and feel...together.  Wow.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark viscous black with a thick creamy tan head.  Aroma is an excellent blend of roasted malts and chocolate with a light smokiness and some burnt toast and rich and sharp dark malt crispness. Flavor has a robust chocolate and creamy burnt sugar character and coffee bitterness. Nice bitter finish but not astringent or harsh, just pleasant and much like the bitterness in dark chocolate. Medium full body and a soft carbonation. Excellent porter.

12 oz bottle.Pours dark oily black with a mountain of tan head that is built to last.  Nose is all roasted malts and brown sugar.  Flavor is dark, rich, and smooth - chocolate and smoke, with just a touch of cinnamon lightening at the end.  Really interesting spriteliness to this porter, balancing the bitterness until the finish.  Nice job Founders

12oz bottle from Charleston Beer Exchange.  black pour with a finger sturdy looking tan head that disappears quicker than I wouldve expected.  soft but strong aroma of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate and some earthy spiced hops.  taste is fairly sharp candy sweetness backed up by a chalky bitterness.  the caramel, coffee, roastiness comes through in the finish.  nothing over the top here - just an all around great porter.
Pours dark and oily. Big smells of roasted malts, bitter chocolate and sugar. Taste is smokey, smooth, thick and so good. Not a real porter guy but this changed my mind. Nice job.

This is about as good as it gets.  Rich, Dark, malty with a chewiness that really is in the mix with some of the best robust porters on the market.  The chocolatiness slightly overpowers the grainy burntess, and the aggressive bitterness is on the back end.  Just a top notch beer.
This was a very nice porter.  Roasted malt, smoke, milk chocolate, roasted coffee, and licorice.  Nice silky mouthfeel.  Tasty!
Pours a rich, dark brown with a generous head.  Rich, smokey taste gives way to more complex malt flavors.  Has a hint of cherry and coffee notes.  Finishes well.
Also another beer I was shocked I hadnt yet rated.  Pour black with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, touch of coffee.  Great flavor of chocolate and roasted malt.  Solid Porter.

Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Pure black (the blackest Porter I have ever seen), with very thin tan head and just a touch of lacing.

The aroma is chocolate galore, with some licorice, roasted malt and coffee. 

Very chocolaty and rich. Noticeable licorice and maybe some fruitiness. Somewhat bitter finish, seems to be more from roasted malts than hops.

Exceedingly smooth full body, slightly chewy, low carbonation (almost flat). Love the smoothness, but not the flatness.

Despite the richness of the beer, it is quite easy to sip. Delectable.

The body definitely seems more like a Stout, but I guess the lower levels of roasted barley keeps things in Porter territory. Kind of a hybrid, as if there wasnt enough confusion between Porters and Stouts already.
12oz bottle. Poured deep brown, almost black with dark tan head.  Malt aroma with hints of coffee.  Good taste, not overly strong.  Pleasant to drink.  Good porter.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a deep brown color with a sizable tan to light brown head.  The nose gives strong hints of roasted malt, with a nod especially to what seems to be  a relatively low lovibond chocolate malt.  The palate is distinctly roasted and malty up front, showing dark chocolate notes.  The mid-palate shows a nice west coast hop presence.  It stops short of having the assertive character of an American stout, but is far more than what would be seen in a standard English robust porter.  One thing that could further improve what is a fairly complex palate would be the increased use of mid-range crystal malts.  Overall, not life-changing, but nicely done.

Bottle - pours a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of dark roasted coffee, chocolate, and malt.  Delicious taste of chocolate malt and roasted coffee along with some nuttiness and a nice creamy mouthfeel.  These guys dont put out a bad beer for sure - PERFECT way to end a Monday... or any day for that matter.

bottle, pours black with a medium light brown head.  Roasty milk chocolate aroma.  Bitter dark malts, bakers chocolate and some hop bitterness mix for an excellent porter with just the right amount of subtle carbonation.  I like it.
bottle.  Pours thick and black with a light-brown head.  Nose is of coffee grounds.  Taste is of harsh coffee grounds.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin and dry.
bottle. pours a thick black with a thin tan head. has an aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. has a bitter flavor of dark chocolate. finish is that of coffee and nuts.

Pours a thick black with a medium brown head. Medium body with low carbonation levels. Roasty chocolate aroma with hints of smoke and vanilla. Flavor is very roasty with prominant chocolate flavors and hints of malts, coffee, caramel, and nuts. Good bite on the finish. Probably my favorite stout.

pours thick black very little brown head. 
Aroma is coffee, smoke and malt. 
Flavor is a hard bit of coffee and ashes, some vanilla and chocolate. Lots of flavor.
A bit bitter for a porter. You can tell its an American porter. Strong thick and a little over the top. Still an OK beer.

12oz bottle from VBM. Pours an opaque black body, kinda like flat cola, with a very thin brown head. Great aroma of milk chocolate, mocha, vanilla with some light smokey notes. Nice roasted coffee and chocolate. Decent sweetness. Medium to thin, slightly tingly mouthfeel. Good porter, just not as great as expected.

My new benchmark porter. Dark and tasty: coffee, dark chocolate, very rich but not overwhelming. More flavor and more bite than mainstream stouts. A great winter beer for when not feeling up to an Imperial Stout.

Thick jet black pour with an off white head. Aroma is rich, sweet, coffee, dark chocolate. Really nice overall. Flavor is nice and sweet. Roasted malts and coffee, really nice and creamy and pretty big. Solid porter.

Bottle. Poured a jet black with a two finger creamy tan head. Aroma was coffee, roasted malts, sweet malts, and dark chocolate. Flavor was burnt coffee, chocolate. Very rich and great. This is a very robust porter. Give me one of these any day!
great beer I really enjoyed it the mouth feel is perfect creamy though not cloying or syrupy. chocolate light hint of coffee.

Bottle courtesy of DA from Fever.  Thanks!  Dark opaque brown pour and a tan head.  Definite roast and coffee scents.  Not much sweetness here....nice black coffee and dark bitter chocolate flavors.  Slightly a little more watery than I would have hoped, but still a sensational beer.

Thanks Ucusty! Pours very dark brown with no light passing through. It has a minimal disappearing brown head. The aroma is chocolaty and lactic with hints of roasted malt. The flavor is rich with milk chocolate, nuts, very subtle fruitiness, and ends very roasted and bitter. I especially liked the finish. Overall a very good strong porter. Milky and not too sweet.

Beautiful dark pour with a creamy brown head.  Nose is heavy with dark chocolate and coffee.  Nice roast and then a hint of sweet.  Smoky, creamy and a nice dollop of dark chocolate on the palate.  Smooth with just enough bitter on the finish.  This beer and I shall be good friends this winter.

Bottle; wonderful dark chocolate body with a moderate tan head. Aroma of bittersweet chocolate, strongly smokey and roasted, and slightly licorice. Flavor is strongly dominated by roasted barley, toffee sweetness, coffee and chocolate everywhere, slightly caramel, smokey, and the hops are indistiguishable. Palate is fantastic as well: almost creamy, just-right carbonation, not overly intoxicating. A life changing porter.

Bottle shared by DuffmanSW.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is coffee, cinnamon, cooked fruits, and roast.  Flavor is Roasty coffee, dust, hints of fruit and vanilla.  Medium to full bodied with somewhat low carbonation.

Pours a beautiful dark black with a nice layer of foamy tan head that lasts.  Aroma is really really roasty with a tad bit of caramel chocolate sweetness.  Flavor is very bitter and roasty, a lot like a good cup of double shot expresso late with a nice dollop of vanilla.  Overall, very very good beer.
Small tan head, dark chocolate color with a hint of ruby.  Roasted, chocolate, coffee flavor. Palate was surprisingly light, like a cola.  Interesting and good!

Bottle shared by largadeer on BA.  Pours black with a nice foamy tan head that lasts.  Lots of chocolate as well as coffee and roast on the aroma.  Flavor is rich milk chocolate along with roasted malt, coffee, and a little vanilla.  Balanced, very flavorful, and awesome.  Smooth, creamy palate with medium body.  Drinkability pretty high.  This beer rocks and Founders has really impressed me overall.

12oz bottle: Deep black pour with a tan head. As most porters do for me it looks sexy.  The aroma is complex and I seem to get a little more with each whiff.  Coffee starts things off, with brownies and sweet chocolate cutting through the deep roast of the brew.  Taste is a mix of the same, but with an extra touch of nuts and vanilla and less of the brownies.  Very creamy and full on the tongue. A very nice Porter if you are look for that style.

12 oz bottle. Love Founders, Love porters, ought to love this. Pours a nearly opaque black with a half finger high brown head that goes down slowly. Smells of delicious chocolate, hints of roasted coffee, some malt, and maybe a dash of hops. Truly a powerful and great smell. The taste is of malt, light smooth chocolate, the coffee kinda disappears, and the hops taste a little funky. I wish the hops werent there and the coffee smell came back. Goes down pretty well, but only medium-bodied. Still a very very good porter, but I would strongly recommend Ølfabrikken Porter instead.

Bottle - Pours black with tan head that goes away quickly. Smells of light coffee, milk, and cinammon. Tastes of light roast with a sour and milky finish. Aftertaste is coffee grounds in a good way. Feels like it looks -- creamy, medium/full-bodied, and smooth. Nice porter, but expected a little more.

A simply marvelous roasted aroma,displaying all thats wonderful about roasted barley,all that distinct hot chocolate and coffee bean texture,a delight to just smell and enjoy. Bold aggressive chocolate brownie with a slurp of coffee in your mouth flavor,satisfying bitterness in the finish. Seems like it wants to go slightly sweet ,but doesnt get thereOne of the best porters Ive ever tasted. I dont see much room for improvement. A near masterpiece

Yummmm! Killer beer! Poured with a thick, foamy, frothy, tan head that didnt last too long and some lace. Color is an opaque brown. Aroma is rich, malty, roasty, chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Flavors bout the same but more intense. Excellent body and carbonation. Finish is surprisingly clean & short for whats here with just a little bitterness, ripe fruit, and leather. Sounds weird, but it works. Bit rich for a session.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2014 Pours dark like an imp stout. Really a superb porter. Great palate that some stouts could learn from. Good interesting variety of flavors from a little fruity to roasty to coffee to chocolate. Not overdone w/ bitter hops. Shit, I wish I could get this regularly.

Pours a clean black  with an average tan head and that leaves some lacing on the glass. Aroma has a light burnt note but a heavy chocolate, coffee and toasted malt nose. Flavor has lots of roasted malt notes, chocolate, coffee and a light acidic, dryness to it. Modest body, with a thin sticky feeling and very low carbonation. All of this combines to make a very tasty porter and one that I will make sure is hanging around my house a bit. Very good and well balanced and really epitomizes the style.

Bottle pours a pure opaque black with a perfect chocolate-milk dense head that dissipates quickly but laces beautifully.

Smells of dark chocolate, tiny twist of coffee, and toffee.  Great flavor of roasted almonds, toffee chips with some hoppy bite up front, bitter coffee near the end.  Chocolaty malts throughout and a bit of an astringent alcohol twinge at the very back.

Very good, deserving of a spot next to Olfab, but Id need to re-rate side-by-side to see if it can truly hang.

Dark brown, nearly black beer with a dark brown heads.  Leaves nice lacing.  Coffee aroma and flavor.  Biting coffee finish.  Some alcohol in the flavor.  Medium bodied, very nice beer, not very complex, but very enjoyable.
Bottle split by nbutler11.  A great favor.  Nose is full toffee with a mild whiff of Danish dirt.  Flavor is more of that with creamy chocolate butter and roast.  Among the greats of Porter.

The platonic ideal of beer.


(Filling in characters so it lets me most this rating. Seriously, perfect. Even if my girlfriend doesnt like it.)

Bottle at Pinhook. Pours a black hue with quickly dissipating head and no lacing. Nose is roasty sweet malt goodness with big dark chocolate presence. Flavor hits the palate with a choco-hammer followed by a touch of roast and lightly bitter hops for balance, followed by a milky sweet malt finish. Full-bodied with velvety texture, a great specimen of rich Porter flavor and balance, another megahit from Founders!

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2009 Room Temp: Black pour. Big tightly,beaded head with a lovely creamy foam atop. Clingy lace. Great aroma of  a mixture of roast and hops with underlying cocoa and vanilla. Light,oily texture. Very creamy. Upfront a good mixture of chocolate malt and hops. Tasteful roastiness,and more slick malts follow. Finsih is sweet,with roasty notes,then lingering hop,chocolate,mocha,notes. Little under mid glass this has lost a little body. Overall though,a great mixture of hop,chocolate,and mocha flavors.  Spotty lace all over the empty glass. Tasty stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2010 12 oz bottle pours blackish-brown with a small but persistent beige head.  Aroma is bitter chocolate.  Taste is bitter chocolate, coffee, a bit of hoppiness, but really well-balanced and tasty.  Excellent.

Bottle. Pours deep black with nice beige head, heavy lacing.  Aroma is mostly bitter chocolate, almost creamy.  Chocolate, coffee, and a slight almond flavor, some hoppy bitterness hiding underneath.  Very thick and sticky, this one is heavy but smooth. Outstanding.

Bottle courtesy of drowland.  Pure black pour.  Light brown head that sticks around for a bit.  Aroma is soft chocolate.  The same scent that would waft in from grandmas kitchen on the weekends.  Coffee notes are very apparent as well.  Dry roast flavor is tasted first with a dark chocolate bitter on the finish.  Has almost a nutty quality to it as well.  Nice porter, not overthetop flavors that are in the extreme styles, but it is a pretty nice mix.

I havent yet had a founders brew that I havent liked, and their maltier lineup is the stuff of legends.  First time trying this one, looks good with a thin but lasting brown head over a very dark brown liquid.  Scent is roasted coffee, chocolate, very similar to the Imperial stout, not quite as coffee centric as the breakfast stout, and molasses.  Quite phenomenal nose.  Flavor unfortunately isnt the slam dunk that the nose is, as we have a good solid porter, but it misses the perfect nuanced taste of its bigger brothers.  There is certainly more hop presence than in the stouts, but not nearly as much as a Yeti or Rasputin.  I like that the body is slightly thicker than when I usually think of porter but this is much thinner than the stouts.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a beautiful black, with a small but lasting brown head. Aroma is an enticing blend of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. Flavor is very balanced. Smooth. Tastes strongly of coffee and cocoa, with a nice dry bitter finish. A fantastic Porter.

Bottle acquired via trade with belgiumtripel...THANKS MIKE!!!  Nice cocoa and molasses aroma with a bit of ash and brown sugar.  Flavor includes roasted chocolate-covered kona coffee beans, some nuttiness, and even dark fruits.  More body than is typical of the style.  Solid.
12oz bottle pours dark black, slight caramel colored head.  Aroma is chocolate and malt.  Flavor is the same and very smooth. Overall a great porter and what you would expect from Founders.

Bottle from Gomers in Lees Summit, MO.  Smells nice, very dark standard porter aromas but i still wasnt prepared for what i tasted- WOW.  Dark roasted malts, creamy chocolate, and a hint of smoke, everything i love in a porter and tons of stuff going on with hops, coffee, and more peeking through the background.  Incredible palate, perfect creamy thickness.  Cant believe this is only $9 for a sixer.  Anchor Porter and Fullers London Porter are great for the price but this is my new go-to affordable porter.  With price as no object, only Olfabrikken is better even taking imperial porters into account.  Why did it take me so long to try this?  Thanks to Founders for distributing in MO now.

On Tap at Shallos. Pours dark brown, black with foamy tan head that fades to creamy thin layer cover. Dark roasted chocolate, coffee notes on the nose. Flavor follows with some smokiness, and nice bitter roasty malt profile. Very smooth finish with slight alcohol touch. Very, very tasty! Loads of chocolate and coffee malts as it warms. This is excellent...only difference I see from this and the Olfabrikken is this has a little more smokiness to it. Id put it up to Olfa any day though.

Served in an imperial pint from a tap at 3 Floyds, there was not much of a head atop this deep brownish black brew.  Whiffs of roasted coffee and chocolate invite a sip which confirms my nostrils findings.  While the malts dominate, the hops keep it balanced and enjoyable.

Aroma is chocolate, a touch of smoke, dark malts, cocoa, and sugar.
Appearance is rich mahogany with no real head to speak of.
Taste is thin chocolate, some maltiness, sourness, and smoke (also umami).
Finish is sweet and smooth.  Very faint hop presence.
Drinkable and true to style
Taste like bitting into a herseys bar and taking a sip of starbucks pikes peak black.  I like.

Compliments of DuffmanSW also enjoyed with mspindler. Dark black with brown tasty head. Aroma of coffee and cinnamon. Taste is smokey, roasted coffee, dusty, sweet fruits. Medium body thats very nice. Most porters I have had are usually really thin. Overall very good porter, one of the best Ive had.

I had this at Bar Louie in Novi with BeerBaron617 the other night.  It was from a pretty fresh keg, so it was especially tasty.  I am slowly growing in to porters and stouts, and this one proves to make the grade for me at this time.

A great black pour with a medium tan head that leaves quickly.  Its got a great aroma of chocolate and coffee, typical of porters, and the nose translated to the taste.  Very great body/mouth feel, not too thick, not too thin, just right.  Its got a great flavor.
Had this at the Pinhook, Durham, NC. Very roasted taste and aroma. Flavour held many classic Porter elements in place and conducted its execution on my tastebuds in style.

bottle 12o oz. - Poured dark brown almost black with medium beige head that faded.
Aroma - roasted chocolate malt, smokey and also mild coffee scent.
Flavor - Roasted smokey coco taste. Some roasted almonds and coffee grounds!
Palate - medium mouthfeel with good carbonation. Finish is dry and has aftertaste!(ashy)
Overall - OK Porter but not what I expected. Fullers London Porter is far superior!!

Bottle 355 ml 
Appearance:  thick dark brown ale with mid plus dark tanned top , some lace. 3+Nose:  Aromatic , clean black roast with fresh hops. Nice blend. Sweet dark ash with chocolate and walnuts.Flavor/Palate :Mid full bodied. Roast but that quality checked , slight sourness on walls, smooth and balanced. Felt complete. Highly recommended well rounded strong porter.

(Draught at Chumleys) pours jet black, oily and nice creamy tan bubbles stick around a long time; lacing is great too. Nose of roasted toffee, chocolate, coffee, and even a little fruity. Taste is super roasty, creamy enough to balance it out, bakers chocolate and a nice roasted coffee finish. So creamy and delicious this is one of the best porters Ive had. Not too thick to even drink on a hot night.
Pours black with a big beige head. Aroma is roasted malt,coffee, and chocolate. Flavor is roasty malt and coffee, with a good bit of bitterness.

12oz bottle. Pours very deep brown, topped with a medium-sized tan head. Nice roasted chocolate malt aroma, vanilla, smoke, and some dark fruit. Flavor of chocolate, anise, licorice, vanilla, and coffee. Roasted coffee and hops provide a somewhat bitter finish. Smooth and delicious. Great porter.
Ive been eager to try this, because of its high rating.  Bottle from trade I opened at toncatchers T3 tasting.  Black.  Lots of chocolatey roastiness.  Leans dry.  A little to roasty for me.

Pour is thick, sinister black. Aroma of milk chocolate, malty sweetness and oats. Flavor is an outstanding balance of coffee, chocolate, grains, a hint of fresh hops and more oats and grainy goodness. Wow, this beer is balanced, but the milkshake mouthfeel really seals the deal! This rivals any Imperial/Strong Porter/Stout/Barleywine Ive ever had in terms of complexity, thickness and strength combined. Carbonation is low-medium. A coffee grind finish with a touch of round chocolatey sweetness really finishes this beer off. The flavor and mouthfeel are absolutely incredible. World-class and sexy-ass in every aspect.

Bottled sample shared with oakbluff. Just off black in colour with moderate carbonation. Aromas of dark chocolate, smoke, vanilla caramels, and mild fruit. More chocolate and caramel notes in the mouth, along with chalk and a hint of smoke and ash. Meduim to heavy bodied. This is  one fantastic porter!

Pours a dark brown with thin tan head. Nose is a malt bomb! tons of dark malt, toast, some smoke, mild hops. Flavor is full of chocolate malts, roast, toast, some hop bitterness, earth, some alcohol. Nice full mouthfeel. What a porter!

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2010 Pretty dark pour with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate malt. Flavor is of roasted malts and chocolate cafe coffee. The very balanced flavor leads to a potent palate -- initially creamy, which morphs into a lively, more interactive experience. It is very dark -- there is a minute hint of dark fruit against the dark chocolate coffee --, and its merit in being so is its exact balance. Smoky with some subtle hops. Very rich, very "sexy".
Bottle. Pours black wit ha brown head. Dark aromas, with roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is full of coffee with strong roasted malts. Slightly over carbonated.

I had this on tap at Bar Louie in Novi, MI. Really great stuff. All the proper porter qualities. Lots of coffee and dark chocolate on the nose, which was complimented by the taste. Really rich, and flavorful stout. Cheers!

12 oz. bottle - thanks riverside!!!  long been wanting to try this and alex hooked it up; pours rich, dark brown with thick chocolate head; nutty aromas of chocolate, roasty malts, thick and creamy goodness; tons of body and probably the richest porter ive ever had; tons of chocolate, but this is not a one dimensional chocolate porter by any means; everything is harmony and just perfection; midwest porters rock the house and this one easily tops them all; traded for a bunch more after trying this; simply put the best porter ive ever had

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2012 Pours jet black with a small dark brown head. This style is growing on me for sure! Roasted malts and dark chocolate are the smell and taste! The hops hit on the back and leave a dry finish, which meant i wanted more!

[Bottle] Pours a very dark brown color. A small amount of light brown head. Standard dark malts in the aroma. Taste is primarily dark, sweet malts. Notes of vanilla, hazelnut, bitter chocolate in there as well. Dry and burnt tasting coffee grounds in the finish. Creamy, thick, and at times oily mouthfeel. A good and balanced porter.

12oz bottle. Pours a mostly black body with a finger-width, foamy, dark brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a good amount of lacing. Immediately after taking the cap off I get a rush of hard roasted malts. After pouring this into a glass, the hard roasted malts are still abundant, but well balanced with plenty of milk chocolate, medium sweet caramels, and a light coffee and vanilla. Flavor is nice as well. Smooth chocolate and lots of hard roasted, chalky malts blend with a caramel sweetness up front. The middle has a bit of lactic acidity and is somewhat fudgey with plenty of hops. Finishes sweet and hoppy with plenty of lingering coffees and hard roasted, yet sweet malts. Medium bodied, slick, and dry. Overall, a really nice porter. Lots of hard roasted flavors, but very balanced and sweet at the same time.

Bottle in motel room in middle-of-nowhere Indiana.  Pours amazingly thick black with a small tan head- I had to check the bottle again to make sure this was just a porter.  Nose is roasty malts, chocolate, molasses, oatmeal, and a little smoke.  A little coffee in the taste.  Delicious.  Thick and ultra smooth- maybe the best "porter" Ive had.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Dark brown/nearly black with a thin brown head.  Mild coffe aroma, creamy, pleasant mouthfeel, tastes like chocolate coffee, smooth and drinkable.  A solid porter.

Sexy indeed.  Whipped dark chocolate mousse, creamy balance between light and dark chocolate.  Dense and rich and heavy and how I likes it.  Darkest brown, small tan head.  Really wish I had more of this.  The dusty baking chocolate really coats the palate for a long welcomed finish.  very thick and creamy, very impressive.
bottle, thanks to SS, dark brown color with no foam, aroma of roast coffee, chocolate milk, flavor is a good espresso with some plum, chocolate, finishes smooth and somewhat bitter

Blessed be the gifter of beer for ye brings a shine to my eye, a spring to my step, and giddy glee to my life. Such was the case not too long ago with the Founders Porter. I have had another Founders brew recently, an IPA, which I rather enjoyed, so I am looking forward to testing their porter. Porters in general are a very enjoyable beer style for me; smooth, rich, creamy, ripe with chocolate, coffee, and dark fruits to name a few. What is there not to like would be the better question.


Just as I imagined, she poured thick black like an oil field rupturing into my glass with a soft, puffy tan head. Rocky and unpretentious, she fades into large clumps of creamy tan beauty while lace cracks and crackles under the assault of dark coffee beans and earthy Belgian chocolates being roasted above a fire of charcoal, wood, and smoke. Divine inspiration, if I do say so myself. But wait, there is more. plump, juicy, decadent prunes, raisins, licorice root and heavy dark breads are there to sop it all up into one gooey mess which calls me for to dive in. whoever said dark fruits are for old folks obviously didnt know what they are missing. Not one to keep a good porter waiting, I draw deep for my first quaff and practically melt into my chair. Smooth and velvety with just a gentle whisper of fresh cream as she glides down my throat like the finest of silks. Vanilla, coconut, and soft wood ground while lemon zest tingles on top of my tongue. Melting into her creamy lactic currents are melted chocolates, prunes, raisins, and fresh espresso with the prunes and licorice root lingering longest. Finishing her palate is prune juice that quickly dries into charcoal and burnt wood. If that wasnt enough, long into her finish, chocolate blossoms exponentially, permeating my breath. Wow and Yum. Enough note taking; time to close my eyes as I savor the last few quaffs of my Founders Porter.


Chocolate may be the quickest way to some ladies hearts, but not mine. Ill take a Founders Porter any day, thank you very much. A solid porter and an easy recommend on my part. Many thanks to my blessed gifter of this fine brew, indeed.

12oz bottle into a pint glass

Smooth and sweet with slight creaminess and touches of chocolate and coffee. A solid porter that is almost a stout in some respects.
