First of this is on my list of all time favorite Founders beers as well as favorite beers of all time. Tastes more like a very strong stout than a porter. When poured it has a very dark brown head that shrinks quite rapidly. It is almost an opaque black in color. It is strong and bitter and is very delicious.

Time to catch up before BCTC.  Bottle at CL Rosso release.  Thanks to all the RBers and BAs that brought great beer.  I had wanting to try this.  Dark brown/black with head.  Coffee chocolate roasty aroma.  Bitter roasted chocolate coffee with bitter flavorful finish.  Awesome.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle. The aroma of coffee beans is prevalent with some chocolate as well. The body is quite full with a nice tan head. The after-taste lingers on the palate as if though you had a mouthful of ground up coffee beans, dark roast. An excellent example of a porter.

Bottle. Big upp to Freddie who brought me this one.
Pours totaly black. Nose is hit by pleasant aroma from dark chocolate, coffee and some small hint of hops. Flavor brings a balanced mix of chocolate malt, coffee, tar and some smoke. Palate is ok. Medium bodied.

12 oz bottle:  Aroma is dark chocolate, a little coffee, just a bit of noticable hops on the back end, and cake.  Appearance is pitch black with a medium sized dark tan head that diminishes into a creamy film.  Taste is nicely complex, dark chocolate and malt overtones, some nice hops notes that are not too overpowering, but are still a nice attribute.  Black Coffee, somewhat nutty, and vanilla notes.  Overall,  Founders has alway made really good beer and they dont disappoint with this one.  Cheers!

Pours black with a very thin tan head the disappears really quick. Aroma is coffee and vanilla with a little earthiness. Wow, the flavor is very intense and well balanced. Very enjoyable. I get coffee, a bit of chocolate, a touch of smoke, with a citrus and a little bitter in the finish. I agree with others that this is more like a top notch stout than most porters Ive had, but definitely enjoyable in its own right.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours pitch black with a small, creamy, brown head.  Big roasted notes in the nose with aromas of earth, oak, chocolate, and a bit of vinousness too.  Medium-low carbonation with a rich, slightly dry mouthfeel.  This stuff is thick for a porter.  Coffee and cocoa on the tongue.  A little smoke, oak, and a nice bitter background.  High IBUs for a porter, but still in balance with the malt.  Medium-long finish with some chocolate and roasted notes lingering.  Overall a great beer that stretches the limits of the porter style.

Wow! Its amazing how after drinking a ton of porters how one can stand so far out in front as this! This is a delicious beer! Aroma was deep dark malt and chocolate with a hint of nuts. Pour was a rich dark brown/near black with a one finger tan head. Taste was near perfect. Strong roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee in the front with an espresso bean bitter aftertaste. This is more like a stout due to the heavy flavors than a porter which is OK by me. Great beer!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle pours dark and thick. Looks like a big stout. Small khaki head drops into sheets of lace. Bold aroma of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, and roasted nuts. Thick and rich, with a velvety carbonation. Taste is rich, roasty, and bitter. Kenyan coffee, cocoa, dark chocolate, roasted almonds, dark fruits,(figs)...Citrusy and earthy hops add even more depth. Finishes with a lingering dark roasty bitterness. Very impressive porter!

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Trade by toncatcher ]. Clear dark brown color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, chocolate, coffee, vanilla. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, and dusty finish. Body is medium, texture is oily - creamy and smooth, carbonation is soft. [20090607]

Original review date 1/7/2009...

12 oz. into a Coronado Brewing Company pint glass...

Pours with a dark maple, root beer float-colored head - about 2 fingers thick but slims to 1 quickly with decent lacing. Body color is espresso dark with sparse carbonation at bottom. Enticing.

Slight bicarb and metallic tinge at first but it goes quickly and reveals a deep dark-roasted nuttiness - hazelnuts and peanuts mostly. Mild hoppiness of grass with a nuttier edge. Roasted malt really shines through.

Wow - nice slate-ish BBQ char up along with some mild licorice - bitter French roasted coffee brings about some nice cinnamon/brown sugar sweetness. Finish is very slatish with big chicory bitterness and hop grass.

Theres a fair amount of cleanliness to this even though its so damn robust. Smooth dark-roasted malt works well with the bitter coffee notes and quiet hop grass as well as the good slate an char. Slight alcohol sweetness - nice finish.

Some Porter examples feel too thin and metallic compared to a session stout. Not this one - this one can pee in the tall weeds with the big dogs - it stands well on its own with great flavor and depth, and it sessions up nicely.

Really tasty stuff. Pours a deep black with a small but thick tan head. The aroma is smoky with coffee chocolate and vanilla with some fresh hops playing in the background. Flavor is strong with the chocolate and vanilla with some deep roasted coffee. Deliciously sweet, but not cloying!

120z bottle. didnt even know they had a bottled porter! new to the metro east and very welcome indeed. a black/ brown color with a short tan head.  nose is brownies and freshly ground coffee with chocolate syrup on top. the fell is rich and chewy but not too thick. sweet with lots of chocolate and a hint of blackberry just before the assertive roasty finish rushes in. delightful and well crafted american porter.

Bottle. Black colored body with a light brown colored head. The aroma was nutty with some dark chocolate and black bread. Lots of that bread dough was a pleasure. The taste was strongly roasted with some sweet hazelnuts. There was also some raspberry hinted dark chocolate. Almost tart. Well made, but not great.

Wow.  Never is a long time, but thats the last time I had a bad Founders beer.  And this has got to be one of the best, if not THE best.  Tons of roasty chocolately flavor, full body, great aroma... just perfect.

Wow. Deep Black. Sharp coffee grounds and a hint of clean soap aroma. Oh the flavor is good. Dark roasted coffee, smoke, sweet malt, bright, bitter and sour all at the same time. Kind of a paradox in a bottle. Well balanced, easy drinking and complex all at the same time.

A black appearance with a tan head. The aroma contains a lot of coffee, chocolate and some licorice. The flavor contains some mocha, chocolate, coffee. The finish is quite bitter on this one. Overall a well done porter for those who like it bitter!

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a small very dark brown head. The aroma was moderately sweet chocolate and bitter coffee. The flavor was very bitter and roasty with full malts and a strong, somewhat rough fruity hop presence. The finish was very long, bitter and roasty. The body was thick and full. A bit too dry and roasty for my taste.  Good.

THOUGHTS: A really nice porter. It was similar to Anchor Porter, but not quite the same. Also slightly like Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout without all the raspberry. Just great really. I cant really explain it. Everything just comes together well. Its like dessert and coffee after the meal. I need to get more. I only bought a single bottle, but this is worthy of a case purchase. I gave it a bonus point for being greater than the sum of its parts. I highly recommend this to porter, stout and beer fans in general.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was an opaque black in the glass with an average, light brown (the darkest Ive ever seen on a porter) head that mostly diminished, but left good lacing. Th aroma was moderate to heavy strong coffee, dark chocolate, roasted and burnt malts, and slight cream. The initial flavor was sweet and lightly bitter; while the finish was more sweeter and more bitter with an average to long duration. There was Hersheys Special Dark chocolate, a little fruit, coffee, roasted malt, a little burnt malt and a little hops. There was as much coffee bitterness as there was hop bitterness and it was hard to tell where one started and the other ended. The medium body was silky with very tingly carbonation and a light astringent and lightly metallic finish.

Solid black color with a thick tan head. Mocha and roast aroma, mostly sweet. Taste is an excellent bitter chocolate and roast coffee. The strong coffee taste does not linger very long at all which is nice, but the body is pretty thin.

12 oz bottle, from miketd.  Pours a very dark brown body with a nice one finger frothy dark brown head that left some nice lacing.  Great depth to the nose, lots of milk and bitter chocolate, roast, coffee, licorice, and a good bit of hops as well.  The hops grab me up front with dry roasty and chocolate malt taking over towards the back end.  A good deal of licorice and burnt malt lingering.  I like this, but its not among my favorite Porters.  Too roasty and burnt, I want something more chocolaty and less hoppy.  Mouthfeel is is medium bodied with a very dry, almost ashy feel to it.  And to think that I wanted this for so long?  Its a bit of a disappointment.

One of,the best Porters Ive had.  The nose is brimming with warm chocolate, espresso grounds, and a touch of licourice.  Through the palate the same thread of cocao powder and roasted malt found in the breweries more powerful dark offerings can be found.  This porter gives the up front impression of weight and holds, as the round body offers a degree of polish.  As  we finish the palate lightens up gradually as the bubbles give this beer and uncanny lift.  Warm chocolate, slight mission fig sweetness and hop spice linger.  95

Dark brown with a large brown head that leaves some lacing behind.  Aroma of coffee, roasted and sweet malts, licorice and a touch of smoke and caramel.  Taste of roasted malts, coffee, black licorice, dark malts and peat.  Western Michigan once again churns out another stellar dark beer!

Impressive porter, a great beer start to finish.  Rich brown body with a 1/4" swirling head and a spotty coat of lacing.  Heavy aroma of black licorice, chocolate, cream and some underlying hops.  Medium to thick bodied with a blunt bitterness and a fair sweetness.  Extremely robust with plenty of burnt and roasted malt flavors.  Chocolate, coffee and black strap molasses.  Some noticeable hop flavor.  One of my new favorite porters.

bottle poured a black in color with a thick frothy tan head that retained well. aroma has rich dark malt, brown sugar, chocolate, and light alcohol. medium mouth feel with low carbonation but it coats well. flavor has rich chewy chocolate malt, pokes of bitterness from the hops, brown sugar sweetness, nuts, and a touch of roasted coffee. rich and creamy but the flavors are balanced and soft.

black with white head.  strong malts to the nose.  low carbonation.  some hop bitterness to start followed by strong black and chocolate malt presence that is balanced by a lot of low crystal malts to provide some sweetness.  some hop flavor present, but nothing too evident. some fruity esters makes me consider a possible english ale yeast.   flaws:  maybe a little too much chocolate malt, resulting in a little too much chocolate towards the end.  great porter though.
Pours a light tan head with a dark brown body.  Smells of dark roasted coffee.  Flavor is coffee, roasted, hint of anise and chocolate.  Flavor is thin compared to the aroma.  Palate is dry.
Pours a dark brown. Aroma of coffee, chocolate. Strong roasted coffee flavor with hints of chocolate and hint of spicy hops. Some carbonation, creamy mouthfeel Very well balanced Porter

Looks dark, smells dark, must be dark. This stuff is black in color. Dark malty coffee nose. Mocha as well. Lighter than I anticipated in weight but in a great weight. Licorice, mocha, coffee, roasty grains. Great porter. Never over the top with its dark flavors. Great balance. Best Porter Ive had in a long time.

Bottle shared at the 6th Cellar Reduction.  Very dark brown pour with minimal brown head.  Sweet roasty nutty milky chocolate aroma.  Flavor is very nutty as well, like hazelnuts, and some anise.  Medium body with low carbonation, silky mouthfeel.  Lingering coffee bitterness.

Pours a rich brown color with mahogany edges.  Some lacing, and a chocolate-milk head.  Aromas are complex -- peanut butter, bittersweet chocolate, hay and dry grains.  Biting hops on the front of the palate give a burst of bitterness that gives way to the rich mocha center of the beer.  Coffee on the finish, but never is the palate overwhelming or one-dimensional.  This is a fine, complicated porter thats a joy to figure out.
Pours pitch black with a fully receding mocha head. Chocolate, toffee, coffee, caramelized fruits, vinous and smoke. Mouthfeel is full bodied with moderate carbonation.

Bottle: Pours black with a thin brown head. Aroma is chocolate coffee beans with hints of caramel. The rich, malty flavor is roasty bringing out the chocolate and coffee in the creamy smooth finish. A well balanced and fantastic porter!
Black color with no head.  Strong aroma of coffee and lingering chocolate.  Very roasty and malty flavor.  Lots of chocolate.  A bit of smoke.  The alcohol tastes stronger than 6.5%.  Excellent brew.

Bottle. Dark brown to near black opaque pour. Short brown head. Nose is strong coffee and roasted malt. Taste is rather sweet with light candy notes, sweet, roasted malt, caramel, coffee and chocolate. Soft bitterness throughout this one and it leans on the sweet side. Body is medium and creamy. Soft carbonation. Ends with cocoa, dark chocolate, light candy, caramel, sweet malt, roasted notes and coffee. Tasty!

Deepest brownest blackish color, decent initial head.  Great aroma, loads of coffee and gummy caramel.  Touch of tootsie roll.  Flavor is chocolate, faint coffee, and some spicy hops on the finish.  A bit more tootsie roll, which is kind of like kahlua and cointreau, but without the alcohol kick. Excellent porter.

Deep dark brown-black beer with a thin head.  Aroma is great.  Lots of big rich coffee and chewy fudgey malts.  Sweet and cocoaish with lots of soft light fruitiness.  There is a light chewy herbal hoppiness but mostly lots of rich sweet rich chocolate and a light cherry character.  Its another really tasty beer.

(Bottle via trade with pantanap, thanks Kan!) Pours a viscous-looking very dark brown, nearly black, basically opaque, two sturdy fingers of mocha-tinted head. Aroma of milk and dark chocolate with a hint of molasses. Mouthfeel smooth, lightly fizzy, fairly thick. Flavor of semi-sweet dark and milk chocolate over some coffee. Hints of grassiness sneak in toward finish. Overall a very solid porter and one of the best American versions Ive had.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with pnista.  Pours black with a moderate brown head that lasted through mid-glass and left a thin layer of foam with each sip.  The aroma of this beer is both powerful and luscious.  When I walked into my family room with the glass and sat down, my wife could smell the beer from across the room.  Delicious fragrance of chocolate, hazelnuts, coffee and roasted malt.  The flavor, while solid,  is very different from the aroma and is predominantly cigar tobacco with some roasted malt and minimal amounts of chocolate and coffee.  A bit dry as the beer finishes.  Id love to try another one of these at some point to see if there is any variation among bottles.  If this one had tasted as good as it smelled, this would have easily scored into my top ten.  As it is, a very good beer nonetheless.

Well, this was wonderful.  Pours very dark and stout like with a dense creamy soapy head that lasts.  The aroma has roasted malt, rich chocolate, nougat and earthy spicy hops - excellent.  Medium body that is luscious creamy and smooth with flowing soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with roasted malt and some sweetness, chocolate, lush cream and some very dark berries.  The finish has some complementary earthy / spicy hops giving it amazing balance.  This is a fantastic porter.
Pours black with a small brown head...slight chocolaty aroma...full body with a nice creamy mouthfeel...lots of roasted flavors and a big chocolate finish...smooth and delicious

A very nice porter with chocolate, roasted malts and coffee.  Smooth yet finishes dry.  For a porter it sure is complex and flavorful.  This is one of my favorite porters right up there with Edmund Fitzgerald from Great Lakes.

Bottle.  Intensely deep rich brown colored body with a medium sized dark tan head.  Exceptionally dense nose of cocoa nibs, semi-sweet charred wood and plenty of roast and chocolate malt.  Texture is medium-full with moderate frothiness.  Somewhat dry chocolate/cocoa flavor with a turn to sweetness in the finish.  Full of rich dark chocolate chips and roast with only a faint level of astringency.  Amazingly drinkable and delicious. Porter rating #200.
Thanks to whomever shared this with me.  JuiceIsLoose?  This is one of the better porters Ive had.  The aroma is fantastic, roasted malts, coffee and chocolate.  More of the same in the flavor.

12 oz. bottle.  Roasted malt, molasses, and alcohol.  Dark brown with brown head.  Sweet with a little chocolate bitterness.  Medium bodied.  Mild carbonation with dry finish. Thanks to Vince for this.  This was a nice treat that I wasnt expecting.
Black in color with a small dark tan head. Aroma is of peanut butter, milkchocolate, cream, and cocoa. taste is of milk chocolate, sweet, light bitter cocoa powder, and a roasty finish.

Pour is black with a thin dark tan head that dissipates to almost nothing but some lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, dark fruits and roasted malts. Flavor is bitter with a little sweetness.  Incredibly smooth and wonderful.  Rich and creamy.  This porter lives up to the hype.

Bottle thanks to durhambeer!Dark brown, coffee ring for a head. Nose of roasted malt, oat, milk, chocolate. Relatively sweet flavor, more malt than the nose, also some chocolate and woody nut. Moderate, roasty finish, creamy body. Pretty tasty stuff even though not very complex.

12oz Bottle  Trade  StFun
Aroma: Big robust malt aroma.    
Appearance: Brown in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big porter flavor with dark malts, coffee and chocolate flavors.  
Palate: Dry finish, with a Decent Mouthfeel.  
Overall: This was a excellent brew I loved the flavor this melted in my mouth and was a great brew.

Moderate tan head, but it lasts.  Leaves generous lace on the glass.  So dark (brown, near black), I could not see any light shine through.  

Chalky, chocolate milk aroma.  Light bitterness in the background.

My first impression is "rustic".  Theres a little bit of everything here without the smoothness of a well-blended brew.  I like that.  Lots of hop finish that does blend nicely with bitter black patent malt.  Good body, almost chewy, but lots of balancing carbonation.  A complex porter, worthy of each sip while wondering each nuance of flavor.  Another winner from the guys at Founders.
Bottle courtesy of stfun.  Pours brown with a huge brown head.  Smells of chocolate, cocoa, metallic hints.  Tastes creamy and chocolatey with a rich chocolate finish.  Great beer!

12 oz. bottle poured to a Czech pils glass, presenting a dark, black/brown hue with some ruby tones as the glass was raised. The head was a foamy dark tan but reduced quickly to a thin layer with a fair ring of lacing. The aroma was roasty malt, chocolate, and to a lesser degree, some coffee notes. The flavor was these plus a touch of caramel, more defined chocolate as bakers variety, and a hint of smoke, resulting in a firm but mellow bitterness that remained the same to the finish. A very tasty, full bodied, creamy to the tongue, porter.
Pours almost black with a very thin tan head.  Aroma is coffee up front followed by chocolate, and plenty of great roasted malts.  Taste is coffee, milk chocolate, nuttiness, with a hop presence.

On tap at the brewpub. Opaque black with small burnt tan head.  Nice dirty chocolate, cold coffee, dry bakers chocolate, nice.  Big cold coffee flavor with dry roast, a little milk chocolate, a little smoke, tasty.  Medium to full, creamy body.  Nice and dry with excelent coffee/roast characteristics.
The smell is nutty, milk chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts,  The look is black in color, dark, and has a good tan colored head.  The taste is roasty, chocolate, nutty, coffee, and malts.

Bottle.  Bottled:  03/31/09.  Jet-black pour with a very thin chestnut head.  Rich, chocolate cake-like aroma with tons of cocoa, roasty coffee, toasty malts, vanilla, some caramel, and brown sugar.  Medium to full-bodied and fairly smooth.  Lots of caramel and semi-sweet chocolate start things off taste-wise.  Cocoa and toasty malts follow.  Finishes with a roasty black coffee bitterness and burnt sugary malty flavors.  Very solid porter.

bottle.
Entirely opaque black pour even when held to light.  Half inch of creamy coffee colored head that clears, but leaves a nice ring and layer.  Big, thick roasty aroma with some notes of coffee and acrid smoke.  Sexy?  Flavor is indeed dripping with hot lovin.  Big, heavy, chewy roasted malts.  Light floral bitterness with some similar hop character behind it.  Some faint toasty sweetness in the background.  Brew becomes even smoother as it warms- very nice evolution in a single pour.  Notes of cocoa and bittersweet bakers chocolate, espresso, and some boozy liquor.  Incredibly deep, flavorful, and inviting.  Palate is full, thick, and creamy, thought with little if any slickness or oilyness.  Mildly bitter finish.  Overall, a damn superb porter and a damn superb all around beer.

Near black body.  Thin head.  Preliminary (cold) aroma is hoppy and roasty.  More coffee notes emerge as it warms.  The body is creamy, with a little bit of fudgeyness.  Long, dry finish.  A very hoppy brew.  Overall, an intense black beer that eschews the traditional concept of a porter by a wide margin.  Taken for what it is, I think Id prefer a little sweetness to round out the harsher edges of the hops.

Bottle thanks to Daknole! Thick viscous black with small brown tight head. Rich mocha aroma is fudgy with some delicious chicory smoke in there too. Great silken mouthfeel is smooth. Fudge beer. Total dark chocolate mocha fudge in a glass. Lingering chocolate aftertaste, lovely balance of sweet and roasty.

12 oz. bottle (2009) in a shaker. Pours a rich, opaque black w/ an incredibly beautiful pillowy mottled chocolate head that rapidly diminishes into some sparking bubbles/surf. Aroma is dominated by coffee w/ undertones of milk chocolate and light brandy; flavor ir again heavy w/ coffee, chocolate, roasted malts and the teeniest hint of vanilla; thin-medium bodied, finishing very much like black coffee (coffee/chicory bitterness) and a little dry. Probably the best porter I have had thus far- yummy.

12oz shorty bottle.  Wowsers.  I had high expectations, and they have certainly been met.  Opaque black with thick tan head.  Awesome choco-coffee aroma, oh so sweet and pleasant.  Roasty and full bodied, there is also quite a formidable bitterness to this Porter.  This is certainly one of the best Porters Ive ever had.  Rich and tasty.  Top notch.

Bottle from Dave.  Eaaaaaaaaaaspointttttt.  Faint nose of ashy burnt malts, big coffee, dark chocolate.   Flavor plays between chocolate malts and some caramel sweetness.  Flows well, deeply integrated.  Nice bitter transition in the finish.  This porter makes sense.  Not mind blowing in any sense, but still a top notch example of the style.  Highly enjoyable.  Thanks dude.

12 oz bottle courtesy of the Binnys Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL). Pours a dark blackish brown, mostly opaque, with decent dark brown head that bubbles and dissipates to a smaller layer and laces. Aromas are  chocolate and caramel right off the bat, with lighter coffee and roast notes with some darker fruits nestled in. Faint bitterness. Initial is medium bodied, not packing on a face slap in the taste department. Smooth chocolate and caramel, light creaminess, decent roast that isnt overpowering with faint peanut (for some reason), light dark fruit, and decent bitterness and floral on the end and finish. Overall, this drinks smooth and well without any harsh notes. It lacks defining characters, but what it does offer is a well rounded Porter that would be welcome anywhere. I prefer the Fullers Londer personally, but they are both significantly different. Cheers.

Black, thin tan creamy head.  Charred chocolate and caramel cream aromas warm to a deep roasty coffee berry-like tone.   Dark chocolate and black currant notes balance on a light bitter coffee swirl.  A touch of hops late rounds this out to near perfection.  Medium bodied and smooth, soft carbonation, bittersweet, roasty finish.  A fantastic session porter (bordering stout) that will certainly become part of the dark beer rotation.  So good to have you in DC now

Pours very dark brown with a 3 finger tan head that has great retention. Aroma is chocolate, roast, lots more chocolate, dark caramel, toffee, toasted nuts, vanilla bean, toasted wheat bread and a little espresso. Flavor is lots and lots of roast, chocolate, french roast coffee, hints of bitter hops, wheat toast, sweet grains and hints of toasted wood. Finish is coffee, chocolate, bitter hops and burnt sugar. Body is creamy and slick with an oily/slightly sticky finish. Damn good porter.
12oz - Aroma strong dark roasted malts and lots of dark chocolate.  Pours black with a medium brown head and good lacing.  Flavor matches.  Palate is creamy and sticky.  Very tasty.

Black pour with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel and roasted malts. Medium-heavy body. Sweet, nice chocolate flavor with some roastedness. Slight alcohol at the finish. A stronger porter and very easy to drink.

Pros: Above average malt structure with some complexity.  Nice looking beer especially for being a dead beer.  

 

Cons: Nose isnt offensive, but is really dull and void of character.  Seems really dead.  Lacks purity and richness.  Thin mouth feel.  Finish is short.  Not alive.  

 

I was expecting a better ale.

Pours a four finger brown head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Totally black color. Light carbonation and medium-heavy bodied. Burnt chocolate nose. Flavor is almost sweet chocolate with a bakers chocolate finish. $3.60 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.

Bottle.  pour was dark with a nice creamy head.  Aroma was strong with chocolate, toasted malt, and a light sweet character.  Flavor was chocolate, nutty, and had a light coffee character.  Real well balanced brew that would be fun to try again.

12 oz bottle.  No wonder why Founders makes so many porters.  The original is so damn solid.  Pours a nice deek dark black with a mocha head and nice lace.  Aroma is roasty with light coffee, tons of various chocolates, dark and toasted malts without getting too burnt out, and a nice floral hoppiness.  Flavor is chocolate malts, dark chocolate, tootsie roll, big nuttiness, some roast, toffee, caramel and moderate hop usage.  Really smooth finish without being too dry or too sweet.

This poured a very very dark brown color with a light tan head. Aroma was lots of deeplyy rasted malts mainly. Flavor was very roasted like the aroma some coffee bitterness, but no sweetnesas at all. This one is great but a bit one dimensional compared to edmund fitzgerald which is more balanced by hops and some sweetness.

Bottle  Pours a good deep brown with a decent reddish tan head.  The head has average lastability and laces well.  Has a good aroma of dryness, chocolate and lightly roasted coffee.  Hasa good carbination.  Blended well.  Has a nice burly roastd flavor.  A good sour sweetness which really makes for an awesome beer.  Has a medium body and isnt as thick a texture as it looks.  Has a eal good finish with a nice aftertaste.  This is a good one.

On tap.  Gorgeous pour.  Ultra dark brown with a head that was somewhere between tan and brown.  The head was slow to recede and left great lacing.  The aroma was lots of roasty coffee, dry chocolate and had a bit of piney, earthy hops to it.  The flavor was tons of roasted, chocolaty malts and coffee with definite hops on the backside.  The mouthfeel was medium in body, quite drinkable.  A great big bold example of the style that doesnt overwhelm with an ABV thats so high it becomes a task to drink.
12oz bottle. Pours pitch black in color with thin brwon head. Aroma dark chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. Taste of roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee with bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2009 Oooohhhhh  Yeeeaaahhh.  A beer that presents molasses and sour cherry on the nose,  a deep roasted malt and coffee in the flavor, and a mouthfeel that develops and evolves along with the temp range.  When its cold you think it taste and feels like a stout, but as is warms it lightens up and the carbonation comes alive making it a hefty, robust morning roast type porter.  At this point I wouldnt say that Founders makes everything great, but anything that they make is certainly on the must try list due to the level of quality that they represent ( no kidding right ).  Thank You Founders.  2009 12oz.

12 oz bottle. Pours an attractive deep black with a small, quickly fading mocha head. Incredible rich roasted coffee and mocha nose. Beautifully bold and flavorful - Id call this a Robust Porter. Perfect balance of dark roasted malts, underliying caramel sweetness, rich dark cocoa, mocha and earthy hop character. Pleasant slightly burnt tinge but not at all astringent. Flavor lingers in the mouth like it does after eating really good dark cacao.Has a perfect medium-drinking porter body BUT with a silky non-waterly texture. I hope this beer will continue to be available in my region for a long time. It will join Bells Kalamazoo Stout in my regular rotation of stout/porters.

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Pours black, darker than some porters, with a thin tan head.  Rich aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, graham cracker and brown sugar.  Full flavored porter with tastes of chocolate and coffee with a hint of hops to finish.  Leaves a lingering bitter taste on the palate (reminded me of cocoa powder, but it was good).  A fine porter, near the top of its class.

12 oz bottle from Corral liquors, Granite City IL.
   Pours black with no head. Very rich, somewhat sweet chocolate aroma.
 Tastes as good as it smells. A creamy,chocolate flavor with a slightly bitter finish.
Just a spectacular porter, never had one more smooth and delicious and creamy than this.  Will definitely have to start drinking this much more often.

12oz bottle from Norms Wine and Beer.  Pours an oily, totally opaque, deep black with a thin, slightly beige head that faded fast.  Aroma is nice, raisins, coffee, nuts, toast, a touch of wood, chewy malts, breads, dark fruits.  Flavor is heavy on the licorice and coffee, nuts, bread, chocolate, just a bit of booze.  You can really taste the barley and grains in this - something I thoroughly enjoy.  Slightly creamy, slightly oily in the mouth.  A bit astringent in the throat with a lasting malty sweetness on the tongue.  Really really good.

Source:  12 oz bottle purchased at Friar Tucks in Bloomington. Glass: Poured into my North Coast Stem Glass. Appearance: Jet black pour (reminiscent of an Imperial Stout) with a thin brown head.  Aroma:  Heavy chocolate and a hint of coffee. Flavor: Full of chocolate.  The alcohol seemed to come through a little.  Hint of coffee. Palate:  Full body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.Overall:  Good porter, but not great.
Bottlethanks dave.  Black body and tan head.  Really dark chocolate malts and coffee hints.  Very tasty.  Hope to have again.  Porters are gaining popularity with me.

Bottle: Deep brown bubbly khaki head. Nutty roasted aroma with some burnt graham cracker and chocolate (reminiscent of smores) Slick oily texture- richly malty in the flavor yet easily drinkable. Light licorice notes and chocolate. Rounded and richly malty with nice drinkability.

Bottle.  Pours viscous dark brown, settling with a brown head.  Aroma of black coffee, roasts, and dark chocolate.  Perhaps some licorice as well.  Flavor starts with mild roasts, and dark chocolate, moving towards a firm semi-sweet chocolate with ash in the middle.  Finish is dry, with coffee and more roasts.  Nice full flavor while maintaining the delicate dry presence of a traditional porter.  Sweetens nicely as it warms.  Decent, but I prefer Smuttys Robust Porter, or Fullers.

bottled 3/4/09

pours pitch black with a 1 finger coco brown head. smells of chocolate. tastes of roasted malt and chocolate with a nice hop bite in the finish. mouthfeel is creamy and light when compared to stouts which this beer kicks ass over lots of stouts.  this beer is almost a mirror image of breakfast stout without the coffee and is a tad lighter body. when you run out of breakfast stout this is your next best year round option and is half the price. this is in my top 5 of all time porters
Fantastic. Rich and chocolate. Lots of coffee. My senses get confused. How much does this beer differ from Breakfast Stout? The flavors are close.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2011 On tap at the Bocktown, very nice place! Looks like a big black stout, creamy head. Beautiful and appetizing creamy fading head. Roasty toasty aroma.  Ooooooh, the first taste is overly strong, hey dudes, this is in the impy stout category, not porter!  Alky bitterness builds on the palate. Very little carbonation. Taste is a little overboard for a porter, IMHO. Bitter lingering imp stout finsih, in yer face man.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
courtesy of frampin
Pours deep black, thick golden/mocha head
Aroma lost of roasted malts, chocolate with light bitterness. Gained a lot in chocolate aroma as it warmed up
Taste, roasted malts, thick mouthfeel, chocolate, medium carbonation, with light coffee / mocha presence
Light smoke in the middle. This is one solid porter, leaning on the stout
Excellent porter.  Mocha chocolate aromas and flavors with a little hint of vanilla.  Nice mouthfeel.  Overall Excellent.

12oz bottle pours a deep brown with a wonderful fragrance. Smooth well balanced with hints of coffee and chocolate finishes even better then the start. After writing this I had to raise the overall impression another point.

Bottle from JoeMcPhee. Glad to finally see this for sale again! This must have been one of the most wanted beers on the site before it was rebottled in late 2008. Dry, chalky, bitterish aroma. Dry, flavorful, yammy and vegetal flavor, some celery and zucchini. Some sweetness in the flavor. Balanced and drinkable. Quite nice, a very solid example and very sessionable.

12oz bottle courtesy of FtownThrowDown poured into a tulip.

This one poured dark, dark brown out of the bottle and settles in black with hints of mahogany around the edges.  An aggressive pour produces a smallish tan head that recedes to a ring quickly and leaves little lacing.

The aroma is stunning on this one with everything you could ever want in a porter.  Its got dark sweet malts, with lots of chocolate and hints of roasted coffee.  Its also got plenty of sweet dark fruits and hints of caramel, vanilla, and even a hint of hops.  One of the best aromas Ive had on a porter.

The taste is only a small step behind the aroma in my book.  Its definitely sweet with lots of dark chocolate malts and molasses sweetness.  Tastes like a dessert with a splash of coffee infusion.

The mouthfeel is full-bodied with low, soft carbonation and just completely coats the mouth with the dark sweet malts.  Decadent mouthfeel overall, especially for the style.

Quite simply, one of the best porters Ive ever tasted.  The nose is world-class and the taste and mouthfeel are pretty damn close.  Im not sure if Ive ever had a beer with more flavor at this ABV level.  Wonderful stuff.

Pour is black with brown head.  Aroma is really nice: roasted malt, brown sugar,  molasses, vanilla, coffee, and chocolate.  Flavor is very nice: roasted malt, cinnamon, and chocolate up front with coffee and a hint of hops and clove in the finish. One of my favorite porters.  Nice thick coating mouthfeel with a perfect amount of carbonation.

Bottle, Friar Tuck, Savoy. Ive enjoyed this barrel aged and with maple. Its nice to see the standard version in the bottle. This is really an exceptional porter, much better than the standard go-to porter of Fullers, and much more drinkable than the Alpha Klaus, which I also appreciate. The nose is dominated by semi-sweet chocolate with a touch of anise and a surprising note of chamomile that doesnt show up on the palate. Palate is viscous with bittersweet chocolate dominating, added to notes of cardamom and robust molasses. Another great beer at a great price from the good people at Founders.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2010 bottle poured into a pint glass... Founders Porter is one of the best Porters in the world.  It pours a deep black with a huge 2 finger rocky tan head which lasts throughout as a good creamy quarter inch.  The nose is filled with sweet  whiffs of chocolate and dark coffee aromas.  Founders Porter has a big and almost chewy body... really thick for a porter.... this one flirts with being a stout.  There are big roasted malts, lots of chocolate and a good level of bitterness throughout the mouth.  Some dark fruit notes come forward as well including raisins and dark currants.  The coffee and chocolate notes really come through over the palate and create a smooth almost velvety character, while a splash of bitterness hits the front of the mouth.... this profile carries through the finish as well.... very very nice!
Brown black with thin white head. Aroma is roasty chocolate, but not over the top.  taste is the same, very chocolate, with a hint of smoke.  $3/12oz

Pour is thick and black, even more so than is typical.  A nice one finger tan head doesnt have a lot of retention.  Powdery lacing.   The aroma is not big and offers roasted notes, must, and some hops.  Flavor is quite aggressive for the style with a big coffee and chocolate bang.  Hop bitterness washes over the mouth in waves and also provides some zing in the mouth.  This porter is world class.

Bottle pours black with a minimal head, and some lace.  The aroma is toasted chocolate and roasted coffee.  The flavor is coffee chocolate, body pretty rich for a Porter.  This is a really good Porter.

I have to first say that this Porter is what a truly amazing porter should be.  Smooth and smoother is what best describes this brew.  Nice coffee in the nose with a bit of roasted malt.  Nice coffee flavor all the way through on your palate with this one.  Never ever even comes close to overpowering.  So balanced you coulid cry.  Small amount of head with a medium body.  This one sets the bar high.

Dark, rich and sexy? I dont know about the sexy part but it is a fine brew... Poured into a snifter, black in color, small head that faded quickly. Nice aroma of roasted malts and chocolate> Taste is the same, lots of roasted malts, chocolate, a sweet bitterness in the after taste. Rich. Texture is on the thicker side. Great porter, thanks weeheavysd for the brew!

12oz bottle from bruisin ales. pours a velvety black with a thin, cinnamon brown head and sheet lacing. aroma is fantastic with burnt chocolate, roasted coffee, a slight hint of citrus hops, and dark ripe fruits. flavor is delicious as well with big, bitter chocolate, dark coffee grinds, vanilla, almond, and a lovely balance of bitter, tart hops. mouthfeel is smooth and full bodied with a long, bitter coffee and wood smoke finish. overall, best porter ive had to date. great brew.
Black, tar like color.  Rich, lightly burnt chocolaty aroma.  Delicious rich flavor and mouthfeel resplendent with cocoa and vanilla.  It may be the perfect porter.
12oz bottle. Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Smells of chocolate, malt, caramel and a bit of vanilla. smooth flavor and quite tasty drinking.

12oz. Pour is pitch black with a dark brown creamy head. Aromas of dark chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, and some caramel. Flavor is exploding with coffee, coco, roasted malts, and an amazing full finish. Holy hell, this is one great brew.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: another solid beer from founders.  12 oz bottle.  dark, rich, chocolate, .  thin head. sligght bitterness.  NIce

Bottle. Pours out black with a thin brown head. Aroma is light roasted malts, chocolate and a very slight bitterness. Flavor is very complex, a velvet-like mouthfeel with chocolate, roasted malts, slight coffee, nuts, earth and a slight lingering bitterness. Smooth as silk and very complex, once again Founders doesnt disappoint.
dark, rich, and sexy...just as it says. pours nice thin black with a thin head. nose is roasted malts and coffee. a bit of chocolate finishes this nice poter

Bottle thanks to laguerita. Pours a pitch black with a ring of head. Brown around the edges. Nose is roasted malts, chocolate and a touch of floral hops. Taste is robust, bitter and roasty. A touch of acid and acridity. Mouthfeel is pretty nice and oily, like Id expect from a porter. Very nice.

Bottle courtesy of hellbilly.  Thick black pour with a creamy, lacy brown head that lasts throughout.  Aroma of dark chocolate, ripe fruit, deep roasted malt and a hint of hops.  Great roasty flavor as well, with lots of chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  Thick and coating in the mouth.  Seriously good brew.  Thank you very much Joshua!

Bottle.  Pours a dark and viscous brown with a small and dense head.  Aromas are an interesting collage of chocolate malts, pears, a bit of damp earth and some dark fruits.  Flavor is even better... a mix of chocolate, peat, nuts, leather and just a touch of vanilla/cream from time to time.  Finish is a bit bitter and a bit burnt... almost an earthy peat end to things.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle thanks to thecheeseman, shared with angrypirate06 and ilovedarkbeer. Thick fudge pour with a creamy tan head and a dark brown body underneath. Aroma is nutty and fudgey with chocolate everywhere. Taste is roasty and nutty with hints of tobacco and ash. Creamy mouthfeel and light carbonation. Tons of flavor for a 6.5% porter.

Bottle with bman1113vr and ilovedarkbeer. Pours a thick black with a brown head. Smoky aroma with notes of coffee and fudge. Taste is lots of smoke, and a little hint of dark chocolate. Excellent staining on the glass.

Nice full rich aroma with beautiful tan head. Almost too pretty to drink (got over that quick enough).  Rich flavor w/ hints of chocolate & coffee.  Well balanced.  An excellent example of a porter.  Rivals English brews.  Seems like a little bit of England is located in Michigan.  Break out a nice chunk of Stilton with this one!

Bottle thanks to bman1113vr. Nose is fudge brownie baking chocolate dirt ash and a little bit of coffee grounds. Taste is bitter dark chocolate and ash and burnt coffee. Mouthfeel  is smooth and medium weight   with a medium finish.

355 mL. Pours almost pitch black with a thick, almost three-finger, dark tan head. Completely ridiculous lacing. Beautiful aroma of milk chocolate, espresso, vanilla, roasted malt, and black pepper. Taste is ultra smooth- just awesome. Lots of espresso, semisweet chocolate, and vanilla ice cream. Alcohol is beautifully hidden. No cardboard dryness in the finish- just chocolate and coffee. This is my perfect porter.

Pours thick black with creamy brown head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt- simply, but nearly perfect.  Flavor contain rich roasty coffee notes and some deep chocolate, also has a bit of vanilla mellowness.  Rich full body with no stickiness. Amazing porter.

pour opaque BLACK. Wow, does this look thick, looks like an impy stout! Big aroma of coffee, milk chocolate, cocoa, lots of roasted malts. Mouthfeel is chewy, and quite a bit thicker than i expected. Lots of roasted malt in the flavored tailed by lots of coffee, and cocoa. Mild bitterness in the finish, with a touch of hops. Wow, in a blind tasting i think you would be hard pressed to guess this was a porter. But damn its delicious.

Thanks to BVC for this bottle. Ebony body with a thin khaki head. Big roasted nose, dark chocolate, coffee, and a soft charred note. Coffee comes through more in the flavor, bitter bakers chocolate in the finish. Smooth body, fairly heavy weight to it. One of the best ports Ive had in a long time, tastes really big for 6.5%. Thanks Brandon.

12 oz. bottle.  Deep black pour with a thin, tan head.  Aroma of cocoa, roasted malt.  Flavor is smooth and silky.  Lots of cocoa, licorice, and a hint of coffee.  Finish is bitter and dry.  Really nice beer.

Thick black pour with a frothy, 2 finger, tan head.  The aroma is roasted malt and licorice with notes of cocoa, and some spicy/peppery hops.  Very chocolaty flavor some more notes of licorice, and a dry well hopped finish.  Velvety full body.
Thanks AgentSteve.  Pours dark brown/black, coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, slight licorice, dry finish.

From Mreusch, pours deep brown with a beautiful creamy and thick tan head. Nose is quality coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Same in the flavor with a dry, slight bitter finish. Lots of coffee in the finish.

Bottle at home ... Thanks to iowaherkeye for this one ... Deep black ... medium large tan head ... big coffee roast nose ... Deep roast ... bit heavy on the alcohol ... again quite a lot of coffee and some chocolate  ... little licorice ...A decent but not stunnign porter...
Bottle and tap. Love the tap better. Poured oily black with a creamy brown head. Big aroma of chocolate with some coffee. Great mix of chocolate and coffee. More chocolaty. Very smooth.

Chocolatey and roast character.  Whispy off white head with a small amount of lacing.  Flavor is quite dry and roasty with a sweet chocolatey body.  Finishes with a nice mocha roast flavor with hints of char.  Lingers with a semi sweet bitter dark chocolate flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 Im not generally big on porter.  Oh, do you see where this is going?  Well, frankly put, this is the best porter Ive had.  Dry, bitter chocolate, good hop character.  Rich, medium body, great mouth feel.  Defining.

Brewed in the USA..... Pours black in color with a super small thin beige head. Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts and mild coffee. Taste is of chocolate, malts, coffee and a hint of hops. The mouthfeel is robust, with some lingering smokey notes. This is exactly what the commercial description said : Dark, Rich and Sexy.  :)

bottle thanks to emacgee.  poured a motor oil black with a thin fading tan head.  aroma of dark roasts, caramel, chocolate, and some jerky.  flavor was dark roasts and jerky.  medium body and low carbonation.  overall a nice solid porter.

Pours dark and thick with a small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee.  First sip tells you this is no ordinary porter.  Taste of coffee, roasted malt, and slightly sweet that finishes dry and just a little bitter.

Thin dark brown head of very fine bubbles.  Reduces quickly.  Rick dark chocolate aroma with some mild coffee, toffee and some raisins.  Color is essentially black.  Medium bodied with a bit of zippy carbonation.  Solid dark chocolate bitterness along with burnt toast and some carbon.  Coffee flavors are more prominent.  Light alcohol flavor.  Lingering bitter coffee and somewhat dry at the finish.  A pretty good and strong flavored porter.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown with little to no head.

Aroma: Strong aromas of espresso, roast malts, and chocolate. There are spicy hop notes, that blend with the carbonation level. Either way, there is a nice spicy tickle on the tongue after the roastiness makes way for the finish.
Taste: A bitter espresso coffee flavor starts it off. It finishes with chocolate and burnt malts.

Mouthfeel: Very fizzy on the tongue. Much more full than Breakfast Stout. The flavors linger long after the sip.

Overall: A top notch porter, with tons of flavor, and a unique mouthfeel.
Bottle: pours pitch black with a dark tan head, aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, taste of chocolate, coffee, malt, some bitterness in the finish, fairly full mouthfeel.  Pretty nice porter.

Courtesy of Nbutler11, thanks Nick. It is pitch black with a brown, creamy head. The aroma has notes of hard roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and hints of smoke. The flavour has a light sweetness, notes of roasted malt, coffee, licorice and chocolate. It is really nice, quite hard roasted and it has a roasted bitterness in the finish.

12 oz bottle-pours a rich to rocky light brown head that laces and black color.  Aroma is chocolate/cocoa/coffee-dark malt, roasty, some earthy hops.  Tst is chocolate/cocoa/coffee-dark malt, roasty/ashy, some earthy hops bite.   In aftertaste, the ashy becomes more dominant.  Creamy, full body.  Thanks to Joe-jwc215 for picking this out.

bottle.  thanks bri.  black pour with thin head.  roasted malt, coffee, light vanilla and hint of dark fruit in aroma.  smooth.  dark chocolate and nice roasted malts, great balance.  chocolate and coffee dance on palate.  good stuff.

Courtesy juiceisloose.  Pours a dark brown/black, with a medium light tan head.  Smells of rich roasty malts, nuts, dark malt, and hints of chocolate and coffee.  Nice aroma.  The flavor was equally impressive.  Rich and roasty on the palate, the roasted malts and chocolat flavors really make a nice combo, blend well nicely together.  Very smooth and easy to drink with plenty of flavor.  I dug this one.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2012 Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a deep, dark brown/black with a rich tan/copper head. Aroma of dark roast, some coffee, faint chocolate. Flavor of nice dark roast, malt, faint sweetness. Mouth feel is medium body, medium carbonation. Overall, pretty tasty!

Bottle. Pours a deep deep brown with a thin burnt tan with red hue head. Nose is burnt malt, some chocolate. Flavors are roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate. Something extra in there too, like a mint tone. Not sure if it fits but after a little bit has a slight resemblance to a Thin Mint cookie. Has a smokey tone to it as well.  Mouth is medium to full bodied, smooth drink. Pretty good beer, I ran out trying to figure out all the flavors I thought I was tasting so a resample down the road is in order.

[Bottle] Pours a deep brown with a small tan head. Aroma is loaded with bittersweet chocolate, roasted malts, a touch of vanilla, and some leafy hops. Flavor is rich, again with the chocolate, roasted malts, french press, and ends on a chocolaty note. Dry finish, but nice. I could drink many of these - very tasty.

Courtesy beernbourbon. Black. Small brown head. A TON of bittersweet chocolate in this brew, with some light roast and a touch of hop bitterness. Medium to medium/full body, smooth, easy to drink. I cant handle this much chocolate in a session brew, but it drinks very easy. Great porter.
How can you beat the first micro brew you fell in love with? Great taste, with hints of chocolate, and a little caramel, this is the best porter Ive had!

Date: February 11, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Brusin Ales, Asheville NC
Appearance: opaque dark brown, fine tan head, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: rich chocolate aroma with a roasted coffee edge, touch of caramel sweetness
Body: big creamy body
Flavor: rich dark chocolate flavor, dry roastyness, bitterness rolls out from the roasted to add a dry earthyness
Overall: rich and flavorful, but a bit too dry and bitter which holds back the rich chocolate
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+/4

Nice looking porter. Off-white head. Nice black beer with a strong roast aroma. A huge roast and toasty aroma. This aroma is very pleasing for a porter. Just a lovely aroma. Extremely roasty beer. This beer has a decent palate. Somewhat of a smooth palate, but an amazing roasted taste. Nice malt taste as well. There are no hops to speak of, but I dont care because this beer has one of the best roast/malt flavors I have ever had. Great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 Very rich and complex, beautiful looking, but I think its too earthy and muddy tasting.  Is this one maltier than other porters?  Or maybe its one of the hop varieties thats not doing it for me.  Not sure about the specifics, but Ive had a few other porters that Ill take hands-down over this one.  Kinda bummed because this one had such a great rep.  Guess my taste isnt in line with the gen pop.

In regards to Poters, this might be the best one I have had.  This beer has a lot of flavor, which differentiates itself from most porters.  Nice flavors of coffee/chocolate are balanced quite nicely.  One thing I must comment on is the fact that the bottle is a twist off.  I think beer brewing 101 states that it MUST NOT be a twist off.

Dark black pour with a thin dark brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, sweetness, and coffee. Taste is great- sweetness, some dk. roasted coffees, and finishes up dry. Beer is thick, it left a coating on the glass. Left some lacing on the glass. Im ready for the rest of the 6-er and will get some more tomorrow.

Bottle from Rozis in Lakewood ohio. Pours a dark brown with a beige head and nice lacing. Aroma of chocolate and dark roast. Body is on the lighter side of medium with average carbonation and smooth mouthfeel. The flavor is very well balanced, with notes of dark chocolate, mild roast coffee, vanilla, tobacco. There is just the right amount of hops to give this balance and a detectable,  but not overdone bitterness. This is an excellent session Porter and perhaps one the best ones I have had since Bells. I will be buying this again.

Courtesy fantomas23. Pours a very deep and dark chocolate brown color with a foamy, tan colored head. The head slowly fades and leaves spotty lacing around the glass. The aroma is full and rich of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, cream, and some earthy hops. The flavor is just as rich and decadent with dark chocolate and fudge playing prominent roles and then smoothed out by the vanilla cream. Some roast and bitterness from the earthy hops come through to balance this thing out perfectly. Medium-full and silky smooth on the palate with a long, chocolatey finish. This is a fantastic porter.

Taste 3/9 Bottle. Looks: Black opaque body with a glass clinging tan head. Aroma: Dark chocolate and some smoke. Taste: Thick chocolate, both milk and dark, with coffee bean. Nice spice/hop presence. Tasty.

12oz bottle.  Pours almost pitch black with a thick milk chocolate head.  Tons of fresh coffee on the nose as well as aromas of chocolate, burnt malts and a touch of hops.  A very full flavored Porter, on of the better ones Ive tried to date.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2013 The last of Adrians Michigan Christmas 6 pack.  Dark pour with nice tan head.  Fine malt aroma with some tang and yeast.  Rich flavor that develops nicely on the tongue.  Toasted grains, sweet malt, hops, prunes, woodsmoke, marshmallow, and a bit of coffee in the finish.  Well balanced and delicious. One of the best porters available and another terrific beer from Founders.  I had it on tap a couple of times too and this confirmed my belief that this is one of the best, and possibly the best, of the widely distributed beers in America.

Courtesy of tpd975. Pours dark darkness with cool looking cottage cheese brown head. The aroma is full roastiness with highly roasted malts, some chocolate malts, and a dash of burnt malts to go along with molasses. It seems very stout like. The tastes starts with a quick sweet pulse of malts that then turns roasty to burnt with hints of sweet molasses filling in the cracks. It ends with a bit of drying malt astringency. Very bold notes for the label stated style but very tasty.

Best porter I have ever tasted. the label reads Dark, Rich , and Sexy. That is exactly how I would describe this beer. Gorgeous coffee and bitter chocolate aromas and flavors. Not too much alcohol and very low IBUs. If you can find it, buy it.

Single purchased at Rozis in Lakewood.  The aroma is a strong roasted coffee and chocolate scent with a hint of vanilla.  The flavor is smooth, crisp and with a semi-dry roasted chocolate finish.  The scent is considerably more memorable than the flavor, but it is all quite enjoyable and not too much of a beer, very drinkable.

Bottle courtesy of tpd975. Pours a pitch black color with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasted and malty with notes of brandy, wood, smoke, vanilla, ripe dark fruit, some hints of chocolate. Flavor is roasted and malty with notes of brown sugar, ripe dark fruit, coffee, toffee, hints of chocolate. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing roasted malt finish.

Bottle:  Near black pour with a finger of brown head.  Rich nose of choco, roast, and espresso.  Flavor is also rich with the roast and espresso really standing out.  Light bitters in the tail.  Lots of full roast.  Excellent.  Thanks to Cpferris for this bonus brew.

Thanks tpd975 for the share.  Pours dark brown with dark brown head.  Nose is lots of roast with some licorice and coffee.  Flavor is lots of dark malt with with hops and some bitter coffee.  Nice start, roasty flavor, then a bitter finish.

Wow...This isnt an Impy?  Black as night with a small amber head.  Heavy aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Thick.  You can almost chew this stuff up.  Coffee, chocolate, brown sugar/molasses.  This is a meal by itself.  There went my diet.

Bottle, courtesy tpd975. Black as midnight pour, very dark tan head, thick lacing. Nose is huge candied roast, brown sugar, coffee and some dry grain. Very dry, roasted grains, caramel, some chocolate, and a nice sweet finish. Porter? Eh sure. Smooth, medium-bodied, drinkable and chewy. Very enjoyable, but obviously a stout.
black creamy goodness.  hops and chocolate, coffee malt nose.  taste is robust... rich dark malty frame with some great hop balance.thick and creamy, but with a somewhat dry finish.  good stuff

12oz bottle: Deep black pour with a rising, tan head that settles into a thick whipped top after a few minutes.  The aroma is complex and hits all the right notes for me for the style. A healthy dose of freshly ground coffee starts things off, with a meandering hint of baked brownies and sweet chocolate cutting through the roastiness from time to time.  Roasted almonds and vanilla also come to mind as the beer warms.  The body is just as complex, with equally interesting mix of fresh press, cocoa, dark nuts and more. Very hoppy, which is nice to balance the blanket of malts. Very creamy and full on the tongue. A very nice example of the style - it reminds me of the first time I tried Arcadias London Porter years ago.  I hope this one stays around as well as it will be great to pull a fresh six from the shelves from time to time. Do not pass this up.

12oz bottle, no date from Le Cork in Mount Horeb.  Black with a one finger dark tan head, slowly fading to a thick ring and thin film.  Aroma has lots of milk chocolate up front with plenty of roasted barley and malts in the backend.  Some light vanilla is also present.  The flavor is roastier with only mild burnt black patent malts present, otherwise much the same as the aroma.  Dry finish with bitterness peaking around a 3.  Moderate carbonation with a medium body.  A good solid robust porter with no flaws I could find.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 12oz bottle from drewbeerme, thanks Andrew. Super dark pour with a chocolatey head. Aroma is chocolate as well, slightly bitter, very nice. Slight coffee, more chocolate and a little bitter, not bad, but not my thing either.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Courtesy juiceisloose.  A deep, dark, chocolate mahogany body is crowned by a lasting, foamy, mocha colored head.  Big spots of lace mark the glass.  The nose is big, rich, and roasty, with notes of bittersweet dark chocolate, espresso, lactic cream and bitter earthy hops all working wonderfully together.  As great as the aroma is, this stuff tastes even better.  Dark cacao nibs and rich chocolate fudge blend superbly with silky smooth oatmeal nd heavy cream.  There are some mocha-chocolate milkshake tendencies here that are just decadent.  Medium-full, rich, smooth and creamy, I cant think of another 6.5% beer that feels this good on the palate.  Awesome stuff.

(bottle) Been wanting to try this one for awhile.  Pours jet black with a thin dark tan head that leaves plenty of web-like lacing on the snifter.  Aroma is strong with roasted malt, tons of chocolate, and berry skin.  Once in awhile, upon an initial sniff, I catch a whiff of burnt popcorn that detracts a bit from the other pleasant smells.  There is also a subtle touch of smoke here with roasted peanuts and salt.  The taste is nicely roasted malt with a very long-lasting finish of chocolate coupled with espresso.  That burnt popcorn again shows itself in the flavor, which is a shame.  Other than that, the taste is simple, but its really well executed.  A really smooth, silky mouthfeel.  This is a great porter.
Draft at Moan and Dove. Once again Founders knocks it out of the park. Dark roasty and chocolatey. Thick full creamy body and a nice lingering aftertaste. Simply awesome.

Bottle sent as a trade extra via pantanap. Thanks Kan! Pitch black color that yields a temporary mocha brown head that dissipates to a still surface. Low carbonation. Looks more like an Imperial Stout; I like that! Big roasted malt and dark chocolate nose with some medium-strength coffee. Flavor is quite roasty, with more smooth chocolate and coffee flavors. Some sweet dark fruit mixed in there too. Finishes with a touch of sourness with a dry palate. Very tasty!

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2009 12 oz. Pitch black with a small head that quickly disappears. Aromas of espresso and dark chocolate, maybe some cream. Flavor is a nice blend of milk chocolate, espresso, charred wood and ash. Medium body is drinkably watery and roasty dry, but a little too fizzy with carbonation.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter. This porter pours a beautiful black with a nice  brown head. as the head sat it left nice webbing on the glass. I gathered subtle aromas of nuts, chocolate, malts, and acidity. The flavor was much of the same with the acid a bit more prevelant. This is very tasty stuff. Founders is kicking ass!

Very dark pour with a half inch rosie brown head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma consists of several elements both sweet and bitter.  Some chocolate nuttiness along with some hops and burnt malt.  Very silky body.  The hops come out in the finish but dont leave any bitterness after theyre first noticed.  Rich chocolate notes through out but theyre not overwhelming.  Nice aroma and great body but the flavor does not seem to be all that it could be.

This is a very dark porter. Theres a definite American hop note but its kind of buried in the licorice coffee, chocolate and toast of the malt. A bit on the thick side. Im really surprised that they called this a porter. This is very stout like and robust at that.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of TheCheeseMan. Pours black and opaque with a nice, light brown head. Distinct coffee aroma. Medium body with hard roasted malts and vanilla and again these very strong coffee notes. Dry and lightly malt bitter finish. 010209

12-oz. Thanks, SuzyGreenberg! Ebony/black with thin brown film atop. Huge chocolatey coffee nose. Creamy medium body. Plenty of roasty coffee up forward, supplemented by hints of chocolate and a bit of dark tree fruit. Nicely balanced bitter hop at the finish. Dark, rich, and sexy, indeed. This is an awesome, awesome porter.

absolute black pour with a small dark tan head. very light aroma of roasted malts.....and that about it. but the falvor is HUGE! Roasted malts, coffee, caramel and bitter chocolate. It is very thick on the mouth feel, the flavor is much of the same of the aroma. This shit is awesome. enjoy the complexity. It sits sooooo well. The lacing is decent too. one of the best.

Like a Breakfast stout toned down....if thats possible. Pours a rich brown/black with a heavy dark tan head. Initial aroma of chocolate and coffee beans, with the first palate giving way to an almost Cream stout mouthfeel. Roasted malt and some detectable hops flavoring but rather faint. Good coffee and chocolate with brown sugar notes.Absolutely outstanding.

A simply marvelous roasted aroma,displaying all thats wonderful about roasted barley,all that distinct hot chocolate  and coffee bean texture,a delight to just smell and enjoy. Bold aggressive chocolate brownie with a slurp of coffee in your mouth flavor,satisfying bitterness in the finish. Seems like it wants to go slightly sweet ,but doesnt get thereOne of the best porters Ive ever tasted. I dont see much room for improvement. A near masterpiece

Dark brown to black; thin tan head. Bitter roasted black coffee bean aroma, and almost sweet burnt chocolate as well. This is supposed to be a porter? Very roasty flavor if so. Dry, almost ashy. Good though a little one-dimensional. Actually tastes like Breakfast Stouts little brother.

Bottle.  I could smell this before it even finished pouring out of the bottle.  HUGE chocolate, coffee and roasted malt smell.  This beer is a steal, Pours like a stout, smells like an impy stout.  The most flavorful porter I have had.  Great buy, Try this out, you wont be disappointed.

12 oz bottle thanks to andrew for this.  Pours a dark black with a thick tan head that laces in strands down the glass.  Roasty nose thats extremely ashy.  Burnt malts, molasses, chocolate, and espresso flavors surround my tongue with a bitter roasty finish.  A reatlly tasty porter, I"ll have to find some more of this.

12 ounce bottle shared by cdumler. Thanks! Pours almost pure black and viscous, like oil. Medium head shows good head retention and lacing. Taste is huge roasted malts with notes of espresso and tobacco. Taste is bitter roasted malts, espresso, tobacco, carame, mintl. Very bitter finish. Full bodied.

Bottle:  Possibly the best porter Ive had...pour was dark black with a minimal tan head.  Nose was heavy on the dark roasted malts with a shitload of espresso bean, black cherry and tobacco noted.  Medium-full bodied...great mouth feel.  Roasted malts, leaf tobacco, chocolate and black cherries all meld beautifully in the taste.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of rich cacao dark chocolate, roasted malts, wood, and some smoke, and some resin hops.  Black in the gl with an average sized frothy medium brown head taht somewhat lasted and left some lace.  Flavor is roasted malt and smoke with a little peat on the semi-bitter finish.  Palate is medium bodied and oily soft. Fantastic beer, I cant recall a better porter.

Bottle thanks to mreusch, thanks Matt.  Poured a deep brown color with a half-inch dark beige head that faded to a light film and ring that left a little lacing.  Aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts with some hints of coffee, a bit of charred oak, and some light earthy hoppiness.  Lightly prickly, semi-sweet entry with some dark chocolate, a hint of light roast, and a bit of lingering smoke complimented by a relatively moderate earthy hoppiness that finishes with some dryness.   Low carbonation, somewhat thin mouthfeel.  Overall, it is a solid porter  with a nice nose, but it didnt strike me as having any over-whelming qualities.

Pours black into an English pint. Mocha micro head recedes to coat surface leaving spot lacing. Charred espresso and dark chocolate aromas.  Tingling smoked malts upfront with a lasting bitter chocolate and hopped mocha finish.

Bottle kindly shared by theisti. Pours black with a thin tan head and patchy lace. The nose is a thing of beauty and sadly overshadows the flavor for me: milk chocolate and round dark roasted malt; much like a roasty chocolate malted milk shake. Light-bodied and slick with an almost astringent, mildly bitter finish. Roasted malt, cocoa and an interesting, bitter hodgepodge of hop notes. While the flavor falls short of the aroma, this is a fine porter and one that I can easily recommend. Thanks for sharing it with me Tim!

12oz brown stubby purchased from Oades Big Ten.

Pours an oily, completely opaque black.  Hints of scarlet show themselves as well.  Very little head after the pour.  Lacing is almost non-existent.

Aroma is rich in malt, with hints of molasses and a nose that reminds me of chilled chocolate milk.

This porter starts off thin, but gathers up a nice mid-mouth feel.  with roasted malt and a hint of grahm cracker.  Finishes with a dryish hop bitter.  Not too much bitter though.  Rather, just enough to round out this fine beer.

Overall, this is a great porter.  Old school with its bombardment of malt, yet the uncharacteristic subtle hop finish leaves the drinker classically refreshed.

Bottle courtesy of fiver29.  Pours a pitch black with red highlights and the bottom and a half finger brown head that faded into a ring almost immediately.  The nose is roasty, smoky chocolatey coffee  really great aroma.  The taste is not as good as the nose, but still nice.  Milk chocolate, roasted malt, cocoa and charcoal with a bitter hoppy coffee finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Very good porter  thanks John!

12oz bottle from Archer Liquors. Pours dark brown nearly black with dark tan head. Aroma is heavy with roasted malt and coffee with dark chocolate and dark fruits. Flavor is full with roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee. Nice mouthfeel. Finishes bitter. Nice Porter.

Black with big, creamy brown head / Rich roast tobacco nose / Medium body, vinuous,  a touch thin but some chewiness, with good balance and finish / Flavors of roast coffee, tobacco, unsweetened chocolate, and plums / Thin body only flaw.

Darker brown color with a medium tan head.  Aroma is big and roasty with a heavy dose of coffee, dark chocolate, and even wood.  Flavor is big on the roast with dark chocolates, dark coffee, and even some vinous fruit.  Finishes very nice and has a mild hoppiness at the end.  Very nice mouthfeel.  For a standard porter, this is nothing short of incredible.

Thanks to my bro for sharing this.  Pours a rich black color with thick frothy head that fades quickly leaving a nice amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is of roasted coffee, dark chocolate malts and a bit of anise and dark fruit.  Taste is some milk chocolate, cocoa powder, light floral hops and mild coffee.  Full bodied and silky smooth, this is a heck of a porter.
UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 Bottle. Nice deep black body with nice head. Aroma is a nice blend of chocolate and hops. A very hoppy porter but it blended in nice with the chocolate malt. Smooth.

2008 Bottle - Thanks tjtjresh - Pours a medium consistency dark brown  with a malty brown head...aroma is suprisingly hoppy, chocolate, vanilla...flavour is an explosion, smokey on the front, yielding to bitter charred wood and a massive creamy bourbon barrel like finish...never had a porter like this, smooth with very fine carbonation, damn that was good...

12 oz bottle generously sent to me by tjthresh. Pour is deep brown, blocks the light. Nice one inch off white head that falls fast. Only small amounts of lacing are left behind.  Aroma of milk chocolate, chalky-roasty malt. Some tobacco leafs. Really engaging nose, nice. Taste is lactic milk chocolate and roastiness. Some bright bitter pine hoppiness to the finish. Palate is silky, smooth chalky, dry and nice. Overall this was a nice one, though the pine hops over played the soft roastiness a bit in the taste for me.  Thanks for sending this my way, Tom.

pitch black pour with a finger sized cocoa brown head.  Aroma is Toffee,  coffee,  heavily roasted malt,  and a bit of cocoa.  Flavor is chocolate,  caramel,  coffee, cream.  Finishes pretty bitter,  lots of burnt roastiness and rich creamy sweetness to back it up.  This has perfect carbonation for that sweet/bitter thing it has going on. Im pretty torn on this one.  I cant see why it is rated at a 4,  yet I have it at a 3.9 and feel my score isnt bloated.  Odd.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2009 Pours a pitch black with some bits of off-white particulate and a thin mocha head that fades quickly.  Aroma is chocolate milk, chocolate brownies, coffee, fudge, and light roasts.  Mouthfeel is very creamy and silky, with a slight bitterness on the finish.  Taste is chocolate brownies, coffee, medium roasts, with a tinge of bitterness. Well done!

UPDATED: APR 30, 2009 Pours black small tan head that disapates rather quickly but lacing goes on till end,aromas of chocolate malts and coffee taste is full of sweet chocoltes malts and hops on of the best porters that Ive had to date smooth and creamy just great, rated by style of brew just what a porter should be un like the leader in this catagory which should be in a different style of imperial/strong porter IMO

This one is up near the wow level. An inky black pour from which you can coax a bit of a head. The scent is slightly sugary with a fresh hint of chocolate. The beer rolls over your tongue and pleasantly engulfs it, and the aftertaste is full and barely sweet. A genuinely outstanding porter that lives up to its excellent score.

From bottle, blindtasting #7. Pours pitch black with a diminished white head. Dry roasted malty and smooth chocolate. Quite dense aroma. Smooth. Light sweet malty with a solid hardroasted base. Smooth chocolate and hardroasted malty flavoured into a nice lingering finish with a solid hoppy finish, slight fruity.
Smokey coffee aroma with taste the follows aroma. Nice dark appearance with average lacing. Nice beer that is a good representation of the style.

Just about black in color with a tan head.  Aroma is fairly intense for a porter and shows roast, dry chocolate, mild malt sweetness.  Very clean, great aroma.  Taste has roast, dry chocolate, medium to full bodied with some nice caramel sweetness and a touch of fruit.
Some floral hop character as well.  Some light lingering roast and a moderate hop bitterness in the finish.  Probably one of the best porters Ive had.

Pours a black body with a lasting, light brown head. Burnt coffee dominates the flavor. Kind of harsh to be honest, but its growing on me. Odd windex type flavor at the end (not that I know what windex tastes like). As it warms, it becomes a really enjoyable porter.
Nice and dark almost black with a tan head. Not too overpowering. Very smooth and tasty. Chocolate aroma. Good stuff.
On tap.  What a great tasting porter.  Not too much roast malt-- so not too harsh.  Very rich and chocolate in smell and taste.  Just an outstanding porter-- especially fresh on tap.

Beautiful beer.  I actually marked appearance down slightly, as I felt that it was a bit TOO dark... almost like an imperial stout.  But, man, this is one hell of a beer.  Aroma is all roasted malt.  Excellent on the palate - roasted coffee and chocolate flavors balanced out nicely with just a touch of hops.  I say "a touch" of hops, but this one has 45 IBUs!  So theres a whole lotta hops in there, which just speaks to how malty this one is!  Great balance.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2009 12 ounce bottle. Black color lets no light through. Medium head. Aroma and taste were roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Some sweetness up front, but bitter roasted malt after-taste.

12oz. bottle, with thank to alexsdad06.  Pours a nice dark brown/black with a three finger creamy tan head, good retention and lacing.  Aroma is a nice roast, with chocolate, light char, and espresso.  Flavor is more of the same, with a "just right" roastiness throughout.  A very nice Porter for sure, thanks again Brad.

multiple bottles of 2009 by way of emacgee.
pours viscous and nearly black. no light gets through and there is no color change at the edges. its capped by a soft creamy purple tinted brown head.
the nose is full of green leafy hops, ash almost like spent charcoal (the real stuff), chocolate, roast, raisins and faint smoke. 
the palate is malty and thick... a touch fudgey but in no way sweet. theres lots of ash and roast present along with flavors of chocolate, scalded vanilla cream, pale molasses and a pleasant lactic sourness throughout. medium full bodied with lots of substance. its rich, creamy and smooth with the perfect carbonation yet almost parchingly dry and hoppy. i think its those differences in texture which keep it interesting...
it is missing some depth, complexity and development of flavors but its really effen good! i think i like how they shied away from the lux nutty, coffee and caramel characters and allowed the harsh bitter and dry stuff to come through! 8/5/8/5/18/4.4

12oz bottle. Pours black with a brown head. Moderate carbonation. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, hops, and strong burnt coffee. Taste is burnt coffee, dark chocolate, malt, brown sugar, vanilla, and bitter hops. The coffee overpowers the other flavors at first, but then settles and everything comes through. Creamy mouthfeel without being to heavy. Drinks easy, and is worth the price.

Bottle, thanks to NachlamSie for sharing. Pours black with tan head. The aroma is roast, charcoal, little bits of molasses, vanilla, and wood. The flavor is molasses with some ash and bitter chocolate. The finish is wood and vanilla with a little bit of walnut. The mouthfeel is rich and chewy... quite a good beer.

bottle shared with Tronraner. Pours a really dark hue, near black, with nearly no head. The aroma is very roasty and bittersweet. I feel like I can almost chew the smell alone. Raisins, dark chocolate, earth, and faint hops. Man, this stuff is so chewy. Tons of chewy, earthy, dark fruits; dark chocolate. The finish is bittersweet and dry. This is super porter.

Bottle courtesy TheCheeseman. Pours black with a thin off white head. Nice roasted grain and dark cherry aroma, not overpowering and very nice. Roasted grain, chocolate malt, coffee and dark fruit taste. Very nice light body with a hint of coffee in the finish. A stunningly good porter.

Bottle. Lots of flavor in this porter, but what makes it even better is the smooth, creamy body. Small tan head atop a deep, very dark brown-black body. Head diminished fairly quickly. The aroma is full of rosted malt, dark chocolate, black coffee and toffee. There are hints of floral hops, but only hints. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. But the finish revs up the bitterness to moderate leaving tastes of bitter chocolate, espresso with a hint of vanilla and molasses. The result is a nice balance between sweet and bitter. The finish is also dry, but avoids the metallic flavor found in many porters and stouts. Medium body with a creamy texture and low carbonation. This gets high marks on  drinkability alone. Nicely done.
