This stuff is awesome, glad to see it back in the regular line up.  Pours pitch black with a thick chocolate head.  Deep roasted grain aroma with the Founders house character.  Great coffee/burnt flavor with quite a bit of bitterness.  I could drink this stuff all day long!
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Pours black with brown tint, minimal brown head, and moderate lacing. Huge chocolate aroma with some coffee. Malty rich body, extremely smooth. Lots of chocolate and robust rich malt with a pleasant hoppy kick at the end. Very good porter.

bottle - Pours black with a thin dark tan head.  The assertive roast malt aroma is rich with coffee.  The flavor has sweet roast malt with coffee and dark chocolate notes backed by a generous quantity of hops.  It has a well hopped, espresso-like finish.  Excellent porter.  Its one of the best youll find.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2011 12oz bottle. Pours dark brown/black with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and dark chocolate. The flavor adds notes of coffee and a surprising hop bitterness. Amazingly smooth, creamy, and thin on the palate. Very drinkable. This is an amazing porter... the best Ive ever had.

Picked up a six-pack today from Champanes in Warren, MI for $7.99, quite a deal!  Poured into a tulip glass, came out black as night with a rich tan head.  Left a nice sticky lacing on the side of the glass.  Aroma of dark bitter chocolate and roast coffee.  Taste of espresso and chocolate.  Rich and smooth mouthfeel, pretty creamy but thin enough to differentiate it from a stout.  Great beer!

Bottled.  Poured deep brown with a creamy initial cap of tan head.  The aroma was on the sweeter side with chocolate, caramel, and molasses represented.. roast was moderate.. vanilla and warm woodsy hoppage showed with warmth.  The flavor was a bit more hoppy in character with woodsy and earthy bitterness standing out over bakers chocolate, molasses, and lesser coffee.. vanilla again showed on the edges.. finished moderately bitter with earthy notes, chocolate, and caramel.  Medium-bodied on the palate with an interesting contrast between sweeter malts and bitterness.. long finish with more sweetness and hoppage.  Solid brew.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 1/23/2009:  If anything, Founders Porter definitely has a "dark, rich & sexy" appearance.  The rich, dark,  chocolate brown liquid has a really smooth and sexy pour from the bottle.  There is a small tan head that coats the surface.  The roasty aroma contains rich dark chocolate and smooth coffee.  The flavor is also quite roasty, but is has a softness to it that is unexpected and welcomed.  There is a really rich, dark chocolate flavor, cocoa, and the finish is much like espresso.  This beer has a medium-full body and is smooth and a bit creamy on the palate.  Overall this is an excellent robust porter that is bursting with wonderful flavor, has a fair amount of depth, and is very satisying!

12 fl. oz. short twist-off bottle (45 IBUs, 6.5% Alc. by Vol.) from Tmoney99.  Thank you!  I appreciate it.  Rating #144 for this beer.

I have been wanting to try this for a long time.  Dark brown pour with a failry small brown head.  Aroma has some great chocolate up front and then leads to some nuts and coffee.  Flavor is very nice.  Full body of chocolate, coffee and the hops are there, but as others have said this drinks like a stout.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown with a thin medium brown head.  The aroma is full of coffee, chocolate and malts.  A very roasted malt flavor comes through with a hint of chocolate, coffee, and even some nuttiness.  The hops are very muted, but come through at the very end of the sip.  This drank almost like a stout, but had a tremendous flavor and body.  A huge porter.

Draft.  Pours a dark black, with a thick brown head.  Aroma of malt and coffee.  The flavor contains the above elements, and also notes of chocolate.  Nicely balanced by hops, although a bit less hoppy than most other porters.  A bit stout-like, even.  Excellent, creamy mouthfeel.  One of the best porters that Ive ever had.

This thing was really good.  Pours out a deep brown almost black color with a thin brown head.  aroma was that of dark roasted malt, choco, and a bit of expresso.  Flavor was very much the same with a nice hit of dryness to it.  A fantastic brew.

Bottle as an awesome bonus from ogglethorp.  Thank you Brian!  Pours a rich dark black with a medium lived tan head.  Smell is roasty malt, coffee and is quite nutty as well.  Taste is very richly roasted, dark bitter chocolate, roasted coffee beans, bitter charred malt, and just really nice.  A pretty substantial amount of bitterness either from the hops or the charred malt.  Body is medium to full with medium carbonation.  Damn tasty and easily one of the best porters Ive had.  How is this not a stout, and why is it not a year round beer?

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2009 After three years of looking and waiting - finally a bottle!  Lovely chocolate and roast nose, balanced and smooth, luscious creamy expectations.  Love the thick, deep-throated malt.  Pitch pour with a picture-perfect beige rocky head, lovely lacing and cloud formations.  Fat body, dry and smooth and just all around pleasant (though a little worty).More refined second bottle warrants the extra 0.4.  Loads of sexual chocolate and surprisingly subtle roast.  As solid as they come.

Bottle from Daniel.  Glad we found this one.  Pours out a dark brown color without much of a head on it at all.  Smell is huge, very full bodied, plenty of coffee and chocolate in it.  Some hops as well, but not very strong in that aspect.  Flavor is very thick, almost dominated by coffee.  Kind of is like breakfast stout but not as thick or with THAT much coffee.  Really good porter, one of the better ones I have had really.  Almost to the level of an imperial porter, but the ability to be able to session this beer leaves it in the normal porter category.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2009 Bottle. Rating #200 
A dark black color ,with some ruby tones if you hold it to a really strong light, thick lasting light brown head,with very nice lacing. Sweet aroma of coco powder,and fudge,very nice,a hint of the dark roasted barly as it warms.Flavor is awesome,like dark chocolate and good coffee in layers.A touch of the roast at the end ,and just slightly bitter. Medium body ,smooth creamy mouthfeel. The best Porter I have had to date and and maby the best beer. An honor to drink as review #200 Thank you Founders !

Near black with a cascading pour. Tall, lasting, creamy, light brown head. Roasted and black malts mix with hints of grassy hops and cocoa. Pretty much how a porter should smell. Light toffee sweetness in the start. Middle is more acidic with the black malts taking charge. Some espresso and ashes. Light and smooth in feel. A nice return of base malt in the linger along with a touch of black malt bitterness. Strong flavored. Not one that I could sit with all night, but one here in there would be very enjoyable.

Pours black with a deep ruby glow allowing a bit of light through only at the edges with a very thin lingering tan head that leaves good lacing, gorgeous beer...  Aromas of roasty malts, chocolate, coffee and subtle dark fruits(raisens, prune)... Taste continues the trend with a mildly creamy, roasty flavor with big notes of bitter chocolate and coffee... Very drinkable porter with a roasty lingering medium bodied finish... Overall, this is a lower ABV, less creamy version of breakfast stout... Awesome beer, easily in the top few porters ive ever had...

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 Best porter Ive had. Pours a rich black with a great head. Aroma is chocolate and roast. Flavor is big and bold, full of chocolate, malt, and hops. Perfect balance. Mouthfeel is nice and creamy, which works great with the chocolate. Almost like drinking liquid fudge. Roasted finish, no stickiness at all. Did I mention chocolate? Fantastic.

Bottle, purchased from Bella Vista beverage, bottled on 12/5/08.  Pours dark but not particularly thick relative to recent stouts (Ten Fidy, Southern Tier Choklat, etc.).  Excellent aroma, not too thick on the mouthfeel; deep, roasty feel and plenty going on.  The 45 IBU is right about where it should be-- I could enjoy this a bit less bitter, but it really balances things out to keep any sweetness from becoming cloying.

I really love this, but wish it was lower alcohol so I could have a few more.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Big thanks to Honkeybra for this.  Huge beer.  Thick, oily pour.  An absolute knockout of a beer.  So thick and chocolaty.  The description says it all.  This is definitely dark, rich, and sexy.

Deep roasted malt aroma, some plums and char.  Very dark pour with very little light brown head.  Very full bodied and creamy.  Tons of rich chocolate, toasted caramel, slight cherry fruit and a hoppy swallow.  Exquisite.

A wonderful beer. Pours a gorgeous black color with just a tad bit of light coming through on the sides. Fairly thick tan head. Loads of roasty coffee aroma along with some sweet scented chocolate. Great roasted malt taste. Strong chocolate in the middle. Just the right amount of bittering at the finish. Velvety mouth feel. I could drink this all day.

12oz bottle from armenettis....pours very close to black with barely brown edges and a thin tan head that quickly gravitates towards the sides of the glass....aroma is a little yeasty with chocolate, a little roast.....generally sweet with more pronouncedroasted malt, and chocolate flavors.  incredibly smooth with moderate carbonation and really quite drinkable.  dry, almost ashy finish. def one of the best porters i have had in awhile.

12 oz bottle.  Pours black with a medium tan head.  Malty aroma with some coffee roastiness.  Nice roasty flavor, but something was off about the aftertaste.  I liked this one okay, but apparently not as much as everyone else does.

Ok, this starts out pouring like an imperial stout, really thick, and dark with a deep tan head. The aroma is distinctly that of a porter, and a good one at that. First sip is fantastic! A full flavor from front to back, combining a very chocolately taste, with a thinner mouthfeel that I expected from the pour, and a moderate amount of hop flavor and bitterness rounds it all out. Overall this would be in my top 5 porters.

12 ounce bottle.  Pour is pure fudge with an awesome dense brown head.  The nose is rich with plenty of chocolate character, and back ground hop notes.  Huge fudgey chocolate flavors with just enough hops to keep you interested.  Full body and mouth coating.  Roasted dry finish.  Really a wonderful beer.  Its my understanding that this is going to be a standard in the Founders lineup.  This is a better world for it.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2013 12oz bottle from emacgee - thanks, Ethan! A nice deep dark brown pour, with a lively 1-inch cafe au lait head. Lively carbonation like a lot of Founders brews, but nothing that detracts from the oily and appetizing qualities of the beer. Serious dark roasts and chocolate malts in the nose. Its the kind of description thats par for the course in a porter rating, but it doesnt quite do justice to the way this brew just nails the style. Rich and thick, bitter dry finish, but with a complex hop profile that delivers it from mere chewiness. Delicious.

#400 and counting.  Bottle pours pitch black with a tan head.  Aromas of dark roasted malts and coffee.  Has a medium heavy mouthfeel.  Flavor is dark chocolate, dark roasted malt, coffee, and some slight hop flavor.  This is a really nice brew.  It has several dimensions of flavor that will most likely age well.  Very smooth and creamy.

Bottle.  Pours very dark for the style, pretty much pitch black with a dark brown head that doesnt stick around long.  This looks like an imperial stout.  Aroma is huge coffee and chocolate.  Did they just bottle the Breakfast stout in a new bottle?  Yeah, huge chocolate, huge coffee, very nice.  Not entirely complex smelling but delicous.  A great aroma.  Tastes the same as it smells.  This beer is seriously just as good as the Breakfast stout. Slick, smooth, creamy body. This is remarkable, especially for the price.  Maybe the best porter Ive ever had, though it seems so rich and decadent I cant even call it a porter.  Great.

deep black color with a dark tan head and good lacing...looks like an imperial stout.  very chocolatey aroma with hints of espresso.  very complex with rich chocolate flavor, coffee and burnt toffee present.  heavy and oily motuhfeel with a hoppy espresso bitterness that pleasantly lingers on for some time

Bottle.  Pours a pure black body with small tan head.  Dark, Rich and Sexy... I cant get over it.  Too much.  The nose was full of coffee and dark chocolate.  The body felt smooth and full, but not too heavy.  The alcohol is so subtle that this beer truly feels rich on the pallate.  The flavor featured noted of chcolate, coffee, roasted malts and potentially some dark fruit, dates maybe.  The finish has just enough hops to seal it up and give you that bitter dry sensation making you crave more of this, one more time, Dark, Rich and Sexy adult beverage.

Pours a black color with a brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and molasses.  Flavor is dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and molasses.  Pretty decent bitter finish on the end.  Amazing porter, probably one of my favorites.

Almost missed this on the shelf at Sams.  Dang, this is tasty.  Deep black color with light brown head.  Chocolately roasty goodness.  Some coffee and toasted nuts. A light hope presence, but not too much.  A bit of lactose and a touch of smoke. Dried dark fruits. With food, some licorice notes come out.  Light, velvety smooth mouthfeel. Gotta love the 6.5% ABV as well.  I hope they still have more of this at the store...

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2010 Love the label sans the UPC code.  Pours a sloppy near black with a thin tan froth.  Fantastic aroma, similar to some of Bells finer work, great balance of dusty chocolate and deep roasted malts/coffee, and I can get a bit of the salty nuttiness people are describing.  O wow is that good, so well balanced and flavorful, not as hoppy as Edmund Fitz but way tastier than Bells Porter.  First taste is strong dark and bitter, creamy bittersweet chocolate and roasted coffee. Quick finish but with a long
piney hoppy aftertaste with lasting notes of creamy milk chocolate.  A very complete brew, delicious, decadent and rich.  Medium bodied, not sticky, with lots of larger soda carbonation that makes it light and easy to drink.9.4.9.4.16  . . . . . . . . . [bottle from September? October? November 09? not really sure... might actually be from Jan 09. rated 5.27.10 ] Okay, this is freaking awesome! might have picked up some slight infection from somewhere? opened up with strong hissing sound and some fizzing, poured as a gusher.... who knows?  Aroma of roast and plenty of berries! flavor follows, sweet berries and dark chocolate roast, oh so delicious, true roast barley aftertaste, so delicious, Im so happy this ages with the best of them, granted this is probably a once in a lifetime infected bottle, but... wow is this good! Black Albert-like! 9.4.9.4.16 ....

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 Bottle. Aroma of lightly roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, gorgeous earth and nuts, perfection. Flavor really emphasizes the nice earth and nuts character while the coffee remains and the chocolate becomes more subtle but contributes nicely in the finish. Great aroma and flavor profile. Very drinkable on the palate, just left me a TOUCH wanting in terms of body by the end of the glass. In any case, great brew.

Bottle (I didn’t realize this was re-released by Founders and thought I had stumbled upon a rare bottle...exciting nonetheless!)  Pours black with a very small dark tan head that fades rapidly.  Aroma of luscious coffee, roasted malt, and roasted nuts.  Flavor is pretty much the same with lots of coffee, some bitter chocolate, and rich malt.  Amazing mouthfeel.  Full, yet completely drinkable.  Definitely the best porter I’ve had to date.  This is a luscious beer.  Wow.  I knew that it would be good but I didn’t think it would be this good.
9/4/9/5/18 (4.5/5)

This poured black in color with a moderate brown head of larger bubbles.  The nose showed off cocoa, coffee, roasted malt and fresh herbs (rosemary).  In the mouth it was medium-bodied but concentrated with nice richness balanced by fresh carbonation.

Pours a nice deep black with a medium creamy dark tan head that left tons of lacing.  Aroma of mlik chocolate, caramel, toffee, nuts, dark fruits, cinnamon, light campfire smoke, vanilla and roasted malt.  Wonderful porter aroma...one of the best! Flavor of roasted malt, dark bitter chocolate, coffee, caramel, nuts a touch of vanilla and light smokey notes.  Moderate hop bitterness.  Really great beer!

Finally a beer that lives up to its hype, and possibly the best porter i’ve had.   Dark brown pour with chestnut colored head and spotty lace.  Roasty aroma.  Medium bodied with a creamy mouth-feel.  Complex robust flavor; heavy roast (almost smokey), and coffee upfront.  Finish is: hops, and chocolate milk (late)

Wow this is a great beer probably my second favorite porter next to the Olfabrikken. Its all here the smoothness ,chocolate,malt balance. This is a great beer and I highly recommend picking it up if you get the chance. I had this on draft at the pud in Grand Rapids and was not too impressed but picked up a 6 pack over New Years and was a totally different experience. Creamy and chocolate about reminds me of a good stout but not as over the top.I must admit this is right up at the top and just about half a notch below an Olfabrikken. HIGHLY RECOMMEND..

Poured an opaque black color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, wet roasted grains, smoke, and dark fruits.  Taste of roast, dried fruits, smoke, char, cocoa, and a sweet chocolate finish.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a hazy tan head.  Nose is coffee, smoke, peanuts and prunes.  Tingly medium body, a bit chalky.  Taste is dark roast, mocha and anise.  Hints of figs and grapefruit.  Dry, cocoa powder finish.  Assertive, balanced and drinkable.  Very good, nice seeing this finally back.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2012 Finally got this around here. Pours ink black with a one finger chestnut brown head. Glory. Nose is very rich and intense, roast and coffee come upfront, popcorn, chocolate, . The flavor is roasty, nice balancing bitterness. Good lord this has to be the most balanced porter of all time. Fantastic bakers chocolate/coffee bitterness along with a nice hop bitterness. Fruityness comes through with a little warmth. Very smooth on the palate with the perfect bitterness. Special this porter is.

Bottle. 6.5%.  Glad this is now distributed again and in NC no less. This is what this style is all about.  Big, rich, malts, lots of roast, a bit of coffee, and a hefty amount of bitter cocoa. Very drinkable, yet decadent, and silky smooth porter. I was prepared to be a bit let down by this, but it lived up to the hype.  Wow. Im blown away.  A great way to start new years eve 08.

Very dark pour with a tan pour. Roasty, chocolate nose. A subtle roastiness in the flavor, with lots of chocolate and a bit of coffee, some anise. Soft, creamy mouthfeel. This is more chocolatey than most chocolate beers. Absolutely awesome, better than any porter I’ve ever had.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 The abv said 6.5% on the bottle I had.  Nearly black pour with a dark cream almost brown head.  Much darker head than the usual porter.  Roasty chocolate/caramel nose.  Roasted peaty flavor of the standard porter, with much more chocolate and a slight hint of coffee.  Creamy carbonation, a solid medium body and rather drinkable.  An excellent porter for sure.  Not sure why they dont distribute this one more widely.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, slight coffee, and a hint of vanilla.  Poured pitch black in color with a medium-sized, creamy, dense, brown head that lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Excellent lacing.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter flavor.  Tastes of chocolate, roasted malts, hops, slight oreo cookie, light vanilla, slight coffee, and a hint of sugar.  Medium body.  Creamy texture.  Average carbonation.  Chocolate and roasted malt finish.  A really nice Porter.

12 oz bottle, marked at 6.5% ABV.  Pours nearly opaque brown with a tan head.  Aroma is very rich dark chocolate and coffee, cream, a hint of anise.  Flavor is rich roasted coffee with some dark chocolate, cream, and smoke.  A very robustly flavored porter, great to drink.

12oz Bottle. Aroma dusts my nose with the ash of Canadian hearth, brisk with black 

spruce bark and granite. Pours in dark charred, heart of wood - a deep 

black-brown, feathered with a tuft of chicory-tinted mousse.  Flavor 

develops a dynamic sensation of historic renditions. A really rich, 

dense smoky char, nearly burnt, but holding a toasted caramel edge to a 

blade of roast. Light sea mist spritzes salts into my sinuses and the 

long dash of oak rustles up a memory of campfires and horse rides. The 

body is delicate, dry and nimble, carrying flavors as though a fast 

Nordic wind blowing down my back. Bright, flavorful and characteristic. 

This is a fantastic porter, graced with dapples of hop sugars and gums 

in the finish across a glow of November morning dawning on the Great 

Lakes. Robust, bristling with flavor and delicious. Thanks Sean!

Pours a pitch black cola with a medium light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee beans, and chocolate.  Taste of fine roasted malts, chocolate, coffee beans with a touch of smokiness to it.  Excellent  !!

Growler, thanks to WeeHeavySD for sharing it! Pours a deep black with a thin light brown head that fades to a ring. Rich sharp burnt, toasted malt aroma, with a lot of chocolate and coffee, dark fruits, and bread. Huge taste, of burnt toasted malt, chocolate, cocoa powder, and bread. Lingering sharp chocolate toast. Huge and delicious.

99th rating of this highly desired porter.  Ive been wanting to try this since I first came upon the high quality beer that Founders consistently makes.  Growler via trade with Organized chaos on the beer spot.  thank you good sir.  Poured into my livery pint glass, black with a puffy brown head.  Nose is damn good, tons and tons of rich roasty malts, a touch of chocolate and smoke and maybe a bit of coffee.  Taste is sweet with chocolate and big roasty malts.  This is a fantastic porter, as good as I expected it to be.  Smooth mouthfeel, very drinkable.  Great!!!
5.24.08 tap at Andy’s.  A very suprising find.  Delicious porter.  I was quite impressed having never heard of (at least I don’t think) of this brewery or beer.  Very nice.
Poured like molasses from the tap with a trim head of tan foam.  Mildly bitter with hops, coffee, and cocoa.  Very direct and successful.

on tap at Founders brewpub. pours black with off white head. nose is roasty, chocolately. flavor is roasty, milk chocolate, dry finish with a nice piney hop character. nice grassy and pine hop finish. really tasty porter, why don’t they still bottle this?

In short: Typical but above average Porter.  Good beer.
How: Tap at brewpub
The look: Black body with a little beige ring of foam
In long: Lots of dark malts, light-medium roastiness level, A few figs dipped in a black chocolate.  Those dudes at Founders really know how to pack a whole lot of malts in a beer.  Nicely hopped too.  Nothing new but this was a damn fine porter.  Sometimes you dont need to re-invent the wheel to get impressive results, you just need to put big shinny 15 mags on them.

On tap at Founders and served in an English pint glass.  This beer poured a deep, dark black with a thin head of tan foam that quickly settled into a lasting cap.  Decent lacing.  The aroma of the beer was made up of heavily roasted malts, bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and also some pine and citrus.  The flavor included bittersweet chocolate, lightly bitter coffee, and a nice citrus hop finish.  Tasty!  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with minimal carbonation and highly drinkable.  A really nice porter.

Thanks to Ryan for this one.  Dark black body, creamy brown head.  Aromas of licorice, chocolate, lightly roasted coffee.  Flavor is bitter bakers chocolate, dry and roasted.  Body is light but not thin.

Growler
This was the second best beer of the night - the first being the post dessert Kentucky Breakfast Stout.  Apparently the plan is to re-release this at some point in the next twelve months.  I cant wait.  If it is anything like the glass that I got to try it should be a very rich and complex porter.  I can see why it is one of the best on the site.  I was told however by Founders that it was 6.8% ABV.
Aroma / Appearance - An ashen head lingered above a fluid oily black body.  Sticky lacing trickled down the sides smoothly.  Smoke, black coffee, vanilla cream and a general sweetness mingled in a way that was somehow still light and airy.  Everything I expected in a porter was present.
Flavor / Palate - Hazelnut and blueberries tickled the tongue.  Afterwards I picked up chocolate, coffee with a trace of milk and caramel.  A smoky finish wrapped up an excellent time.  Easy drinking at 5% I could see having two or three over the course of a night.

Had a taste and left with a growler. Has great body for a porter with rich malts and light hops. Pours a great chocolate head that will leave you licking your lips till the end. Some notes of coffee and caramel make it both rich and bold. A true American Porter.

growler from ryan (danke).  black!  aroma of chocolate, roast.  medium-heavy body.  lots of caramel, chocolate, some figs and higher sugars.  finish is nice and balanced, with the rollercoaster of flavors fading, not too sweet.  this is delish.

Poured from a growler.  Silky black pour and a chunky beige head.  Rich burly roast aroma; sweet fresh coffee, no acridity, dark chocolate malt, no ash.  Mild lactic touch.  Dark tobacco and a tannic dark fruit flavor dusted in bakers chocolate; really pure and rich without copping out in deep end, heavy decadence.  A floral touch of bittersweetness that lingers in lightly with an unexpectedly lovely herbal quality; this lends an imaginative, subtle vibrancy thats quite endearing.  Full, acidic, heavy coffee flavor never leans into astringency, but stays fresh and bold.  Palate medium to full, giving a slightly frothy texture; some peppermint and chocolate in a pleasant, loitering sweet finish.  Detailed yet simple; an exemplary effort.  Thanks Ryan!

(growler, thanks ryan) Small tan head atop cola black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, chocolate, roast, cocoa, light caramel, coffee.  Taste is moderately sweet, bittersweet chocolate, coffee/roast, some floral/earthy.  Medium body, some stickiness.

Tasted 4/27/08.  4oz pour from the brewpub.  Dark brown hue.  Webbed beige head.  Cola coffee aromas with notes of toffee and toast.  Full bodied with a rich roast.  Bitter with caramel malts.  Nice roast.  Sticky pitch root flavor.  Fudgy.  Good malt roast.  Solid bitterness in the finish.  Totally delicious brew!

Growler, via artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a very dark, slightly oily chocolate brown; medium brown head with solid retention and fine-bubbled lacing, coating the glass; great pour.  Lots of chocolate, cocoa, and even some caramel in the aroma; very pleasant; no chalkiness, just dark chocolate and a bit of mineral bitterness.  I could drink the entire batch of this: medium-to-full mouthfeel: oily, velvety presence in the mouth; perfect mouthfeel; chocolate, cocoa, and zesty mineral bitterness without the slightest astringency or chalkiness; beautifully done beer: generous, chocolatey, and incredibly drinkable.  I cant think of a better example of the style that Ive had; even something like Olfabrikken goes so far it becomes something beyond a standard porter; this is, in contrast, for me, an archtype of the style.  Lengthy finish: toasty malts, chocolate, and cocoa; balanced, slightly oily end.  A gorgeous freaking beer.

DLD 08: Growler thanks to Chris: Pours black with a big tan head. Aroma, roasted notes, coffee, chocolate. Flavor, roasted malts, some coffee, chocolate, roasty bitterness on the finish. Really nice.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a black body with a dark tan coffee head. Beautiful appearance.  Aromatics are a dry hoppy coffee bitter nose.  Caramel and roasted malt.  Full bodied with a roasty initial start dry with a roasty earthy hoppiness.  Chocolate accents finish is slightly cloying but not domineering.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2011 smokey and more like a stout. roasted malt and cocoa. low alcohol is surprising. thick, creamy and black roasted scent nice but truly not exceptional. just a real good smokey porter. tap on 10/18/11 iron monkey smooth, malty with caramel and cocoa. a bit slick and less smoke. bitter hop finish, mild pine.

Growler from the pub.  I agree with the last rating.  It looks and tastes like an imp stout.  I cant believe that it is only 5% alcohol.  Very dark with dark thick head.  Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  Very good.
i would not call this a porter.  it resembles most big stouts, in that there is a lot of caramel and dark fruit flavors in there.  tastes stronger that it is.

On draft at Founders.  Pours a very dark brown for a porter.  Smell is chocolate and roast.  Creamy and full in the mouth.  This is a real easy drinker.  Nice and sessionable, you dont tire from drinking this one.  Just like the Imperial stout, when are the bottles coming?!

I tried this for the first time on tap at the Founders Brewery, in fact it was the first beer I tried there. Pours like hot chocolate with a darker color to this. Nice tan head with light carbonation. Simple to drink with hints of cream as it goes down. I wish they would bottle this, this is a tasty brew.

Michigan Winter beer festival 08.  Pours a dark brown with a healthy light tan head.  The nose is sweet with some strong chocolate and caramel malt presence.  Full on rich sweetness, creamy, with low key hopping.  The mouthfeel is full and luxurious for a standard porter, really creamy.  Residual sugar anyone?  Runs through the flavor too.  A lovely creamy sweetness with ample sugar.  Low hop level too, subtle floral.  Low roast.  This is rather reminiscent of the Olfabriken porter, a lovely beer.  I wish this would make its way into bottles in my neck of the woods!

Very nice well balanced porter.  Not a whole lot of outstanding flavor, but easily drinkable on tap.  I guess i was just hoping for something a little more than the regular...coming from Founders and all.  Guess i have to wait for some of the specialty porters.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2008 On tap at brewery.  Pours dark brown with a thin head.  Taste is very nice, chocolate, nice and roasty.  Bitter notes make it balanced and drinkable.  Exactly what you would expect from a good porter.  Nice and straighforward.

Re-rate: had this on tap last night.  Really good stuff.  More roasty than I remember.  Beautiful dark tan head.  I dont think I am changing my score, but this stuff is really solid.  lets hope they bottle more of it.

Ok, I had it again on tap, this time I am bumping up my score.  This stuff is really good.  I swear the recent recipe is different.

Tap.   Pours dark, dark, brown, almost black with a thin tan colored head.   Aroma is roasted malts, coffee.   Flavor is roasted malts, caramel, coffee, floral hops.   Palate is medium to full, mildly carbonated, bitter finish.   Excellent example of the style.   Very enjoyable beer, I wish they would bottle this again.

I dont know about porters well...but this is an excellent brew.  Draught at Founders Ale House.  Very dark with a rough, light brown, creamy head.  Starts very sweet, caramel, chocolate, roasted malts of all sorts....finishes well with a bit of bitterness and sweetness to balance.  A VERY enjoyable beer.

Draught pint at Redbones on 8/13/06.Small, but modestly retained medium-tan head is perched lightly atop a deep tan-brown-black body, with high opacity.  It eventually fades to partial cover, and ring, but leaves some lacing in trail.What could be mistaken for diacetyl, is actually just a creamy, yet bittersweet mix of malts producing a butterscotch-like note.  Some toffee, bit of roast and almost a touch of lactic acid or something similar.  It is braced by some medium-dry chocolate notes, a smattering of juicy green hops that are deeply floral and woven in to the background of the aroma.  Overall, a rather weak strength of aroma, with some nutty yeast blandness and a dash of acrid roast.But the flavor bears little resemblance to the aroma.  Toffee/butterscotch is smoothed in to a warm chocolate chip cookie flavor, with pale sugars, pleasingly bitter, but not in-your-face hops, and a finishing roast that is dry and lightly vinous, more flavorful than bitter.  Attenuation tends slightly to the sweet side, for the style, but by no means is it too sweet, and certainly the beer is quite drinkable.  Thick, like many of Founders dark beers, with a moderate to low carbonation on draught, keeping it creamy.  The hops really add a good side of balance, more cascade-like citric/floral notes, though held in check by the malts.  Alcohol not apparent, bit of fresh yeast flavor.
Tap at Founders.  Didnt smell much aroma.  Coffee flavor.  Good balance of hops.  Really good beer but isnt close to their best.

Draft @ Red Bones. Pours a very dark, heavy looking, velvet black color with a creamy, smooth tannish colored head. Nose is roasty and ashy, heavy chocolate and tobacco. Palate is thick and creamy with a nice kind of edge to it. Flavor is big chocolate and roaty notes with a tobacco kind of dirty finish to it.

On tap at The Oak Cafe, courtesy of MikeMac. I am usually not that big of a fan of porters but this one was pretty good. I also got one of the last 2 pints off of this keg. Poured very black with avg tan head. Aroma of maltiness and smooth chocolate. Not one flavor was too prominent.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2008 Draft at Founders. Black body with medium sized, creamy, dark tan head. Lasting cover, some lace. Heavily roasted nose with chocolate, molasses, toffee and ash. The flavor is chocolate and caramel, balanced with roast malt and piney hops. Medium body with a soft and smooth texture. Awesome robust porter.

On tap at brewery.  This was a good f-ing porter.  Poured black with little head.  Aroma was bittersweet chocolate and burnt coffee.  Flavor was similar with some hazelnut and a very well appreciated bitter end.  Mouthfeel was a bit starchy and drying.
This was my second favorite beer I had at the brewery.  Lots of coffee and chocolate roasted malts in the aroma and flavor.  Full bodied and rich in flavor.  I wish i could find this in bottle form.
i remember 2 things about this beer: 1) it had a ton of peanut butter in the aroma and flavor.  2) probably one of the better porters ive ever had.  but im not really a huge porter fan.

on tap 2 The black party. This was one of favorites of the night. nice big black with a beautiful tan brown head nice aromas of chocolate roast malt. A tad bit on the thin side but still very enjoyable.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained 15-Jul-05 in trade with Pailhead, thanks Kevin!) The label says "Dark, Rich & Sexy".  Well, its definitely dark, pouring pitch black in color, even along the edges.  Its also very rich in flavor and body, boasting equally massive doses of dark, bitter roasted malts and lightly sweet chocolate for a full-bodied and very satisfying mouthfeel.  But sexy?  Well, it offers good, long-lasting head out of the bottle, does that count as sexy?  Tall, creamy, light brown in color, it leaves spotty and patchy lacing around the glass.  The nose presents fairly intense aromas of dark roast and sweet chocolate, but though quite nice, it doesnt blow me away.  Its the flavor that does that.  The chocolate is like eating a quality bar of dark chocolate, lightly sweet, long-lasting flavor.  Dark roasted but not burned, bitter, lightly hoppy even, this is an exceptionally well-made and well-balanced porter that really pushes into Imperial Stout territory, but without the higher alcohol.  Definitely a beer worth trading to get more just for special events and tastings.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2006 Draft growler from the pub. Now I know Im a rating whore. I passed up a chance to load up on more Breakfast Stout to get a growler of something I havent had yet. That and those bottle deposits. Well:Deep brown to black color under a thick tan head. Big chocolate roasty smell. By the time I get to tasting this, its gone a little thin, more like a nitro stout. Light Brit mouthfeel cant compensate for deep roasty black malts. Goes for quite a bit of bitterness, which makes me wonder why they didnt just make this a stout? Still very very enjoyable.

Bottle Pours a dense opaque dark born/black with a very large creamy light brown head.  Thick sticky lacing almost like merangue.  The aroma is fantastic !  Lightly smokey but full of milk chocolate, a little cinamon, vannilla  and a touch of nutty esspresso.  Dellicious.  
Flavors are not the let down that some of these great smelling porters are for me.  Less of the sweetness here and more of the expected dark roast, slightly bitter smokiness.  Fairly thin porter like feel but smooth. Fairly dry finish
Thanks to Pailhead for this, my new favorite Porter.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Pailhead.  a rich chocolatey & coffee aroma rise up to greet the nostrils. a superb looking porter with the customary dark black pour and quickly fading tan head that shrinks to a coating of lace.  Unfortunately, for me, this one starts to fall a little short from here.  the mouthfeel while almost silky, just never quite gets to medium-bodied and the lingering bitter coffee flavor is tough to overcome.  out of the 6 Founders brews Ive rated to date, this is the only one Im not crazy about.
(Bottle)  Pours a black body with a large light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt and vanilla.  Flavor of roasted malt, silky smooth chocolate, and coffee.

Pours black with beige head. Dark roasted grain aroma, with hints of coffee and cocoa. Flavor has a little too much coffee for my liking, but enough grainand malt to balance it out somewhat. Finishes very dry.

Thanks to pailhead for the bonus brew. This porter pours a beautiful black with a huge 2 inch brown head. as the head sat it left nice webbing on the glass. I gathered subtle aromas of  nuts, chocolate, malts, and acidity. The flavor was much of the same with the acid a bit more prevelant. This is very tasty stuff.i have not had a founders brew I have not liked yet.

Bottle:  Lots of dark chocolate in the aroma with some roasted coffee and slight vanilla.  Pours a dark brown that barely has some lighter brown hilights.  Flavor is roasted coffee with a cream and chocolate balance.  Roasted coffee is strongest in the finish with just a touch of dark chocolate.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Pitch black ale with a sizeable, tan head. Chocolate, pistachio & vanilla nose. Chocolate, prune and molasses flavor while shying away from the typically associated  sweetness. Full-bodied and silky with mild carbonation. Lengthy, coffee/chocolate finish. Another world class brew from Founders!
Pours Dark with no head.  Dark with roasted malts.  Overall a good beer!

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2007 Pours a murky dark brown color with yeast in suspension and a ring of light brown lace around the glass. Strong and very appealing aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Excellent flavor of rich, luscious roasted malt and chocolate, bitter finish. Medium body, creamy and dry texture, soft carbonation. Very good.

Typical dark brown body wears a faint tan head. Rich dark malt aroma emanates from the bottle. Sweet coffeish nature is enhanced by a beany vegetal profile that fits well. Fitting generous, yet smooth roastiness reveals chocolatey and mellow vanilla undertones. Perfect porter mouthfeel, soft yet supported carbonation. Cocoa and chocolate interplays are accompanied by a light dose of lactic acid, well contained surprisingly. Ample hops fortunately do not create a spoiling citric aspect. Suggestion of smokle and beans add to its charms. I do pretty much agree with whats been said already, this is a top quality porter, were I judging based on style, this would get close to full marks besides appearance, but Im not and porters rarely excite me. I do appreciate the balance and texture, but its not a beer I would go far with.
Closest thing to oil Ive seen come out of a beer bottle, with a big tan head.  Sweet aromatics, enticing you in.  Rich smoky flavors, yet sweet, an unusual mix.  Almost fruity, yet roasty.

Thanks to jsquire for this one.  Pours jet black and a tad thick with a small light brown head.  Chocolate aroma greets you before you get too close to the glass and then you notice the fragrant hops and caramel malt.  Hoppy chocolate flavor that is silky smooth.  Warm and full-bodied palate.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2009 Re-rate 10/17/09
Black body, no head to speak of.  Nose is milky cocoa, roasty, nice malted milk ball character, some dark fruits & really dark caramel.  Flavor is sweet roasty malt, a dark chocolate malted milk ball, rich dark fruits with a hint of unripe twang.  A touch of burnt in the really roasty & malty finish, along with a bit of hop that balances things perfectly.   I really wish we could get this regularly.


Original Rate: 3/7/05: 7/3/7/3/15/3.5
Black, thinnish tan head.  Nose has vanilla, burbon, milk chocolate  Flavor is a little tart at first, milky with vanilla, cocoa. Not too shabby

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2005 The Lure:Rich roasted malt and subterrean hoppiness converge, happily. Obviously, something luxuriant thrives within.

The Festivities:A joyously plump body of roasted malt and citrusy hoppiness creates some acidity in the back. Nothing is overstated, everything performs beautifully and coherently.

Transcendence:A worn-out  workman slams the door after a hard day and heads for the fridge, on a mission.

Nose of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts is strightforward and appealing.  Opaque brown with fair tan head that recedes rapidly to ring.  Chocolate and roasted malt flavours are dominant with plenty of underlying sweetness and some herbal bitterness especially in the finish.  Moderate carbonation and medium body.  Bottle enjoyed with MartinT and Olivier.
Tap at the brew pub. Great place. Dark black color with medium tan head. Aroma was strong sweet malt and hops. and the flavor was as equally complex. Rich finish. Good find.
lots of chocolate, lots of malt in this one.  super smooth, but almost a bit thin.  lots of dry roastiness and smokiness deep in the body.  quite good, but not spectacular.

Pours black and thick with light  tan head.  Nose is extremely huge of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor is much of the same, velvety smooth, rich and wonderful.  Quite robust.  Some underlying smokiness.  This is an awesome beer.  Nice hop bitterness in the finish.

Flowery green hops, coffee, and toast in the aroma.  Dark, dark brown color, tan head.  Nice balance of chocolate, coffee, charcoal, and hops in the flavor.  Decent bitterness.  Medium-full body, slight astringency from roasted grains.  Great balance, solid flavor, very enjoyable.

Chalky raosty and dry.  massively dark and producing an awesome tan head. Nose is slightly waxy at the cold start but gets chocolatey and roasty. Body is thicker than most porters, like Alpha Klaus.  Thick, coating body is coffe and espresso-like, bitter hops at the finish dries along with the nicely complementing alcohol burn.  Aftertaste is chalky, espresso-like and bitter. Massive.  Damn.  This place is amazing, every beer is noteworthy.  You MUST visit!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2005 easily one of my favorite porters...a nice chocaltely roasted coffee flavor...one which begs you to continue mass consumption.  it has a smokiness flavor that ties in nicely with its other flavors....nice full body, great lacing, a rich, lasting impression.  CONGRATS TO FOUNDERS

Dark, rich, coffee bean color, near opacity,, with a creamy tan head nestled above, a nice 1/4" that assuredly slims, but not too swiftly.
Aroma: bittersweet espresso from sniff #1...roasty, toasty, deep, and inviting.
Lush mouthfeel, big chocolatey malt character hits first in the flavor, nice and thick, then it rounds out and quits the mouth on a happy note. And urges further sips and swallows. Fills the mouth happily with the cocoa/coffee quality all good porters must have, but never too bitter, very, very smooth, and not at the sacrifice of flavor and body. 
I really like this one. Actually, I really, really like this one, this is truly my kind of porter, and I know them when I find them. 
Ful bodied, long, flavorful finish, lush texture...this is one porter Id be happy to call me own, and would have caseloads on hand at at time, were I the Michigan type...cheers to you who are, for having this fine brew!
Very dark, opaque with a brown head on the edge. Roasty chocolate coffee nose, bitter chocolate flavor, very nice.

Very dark beer with a small creamy light brown lasting head. Nice chocolatey caramel aroma. Taste is a dry coffee/chocolate concoction. Sort of an earthy / burnt grass thing. Some sweet smokiness in the finish. A little oily. Me likey.

Thick and oily black, waffer thin cocoa brown foam that sits thickly but quite thin even after a strong pour. Lacing sticks in strings.

Aroma is nice and darkly roasted with black malts, coffeeish notes, tangy molasses, dark caramel, and bittersweet chocolate.

Great taster, rich, dark, deep, and inviting flavors of heavily roasted barley and malts, nice chocolate tones meld within keeping an ever present bitterness of roasty/burnt qualities. Touches of coffee/espresso roast intermingle with all the other roasty things in the finish where the bittering ensues and drys out with a nice play of everything chocolate and roasty. Some burnt tinges and charred wood notes make their way in as well. Wow! Fantastic porter character in its flavors. Oh my is it yummy! 

Feel is well rounded and creamy full with a fantastic finish of drying roasty/burntish chocolate bittering. Im reminded of burnt chocolate cake or cookies at every sip. Fantastically good stuff.

This could be one to top Descutes Black Butte and Summit Great Northern in my book, something I never thought could be possible, but this stuff is wonderful! Yum times two.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2011 rerate-tap at brewpub-black with a small tinge around the rim of the glass.  big choclate and resinous hops on the nose.  quite hoppy for a porter.  char and baking chocolate qualities on the flavors.  finish is a little metallic from all the hops, but thats to be expected.  Know i know why this is highly rated.  Nice long roast on the finish as well.  
12 oz bottle-pours pitch black, probably the darkest porter i have ever seen.  nice tan had that didnt last long.  Coffee, burnt, roasted aroma, but i get some notes of cardboard-this maybe an old bottle.  The flavors show the cardboard effect even more meaning this bottle was infected or just old.  I would love to get a fresh bottle of this stuff.  It had great potential when fresh. 
Rerate I,have had,this,beer on tap many times and this is by,far probably one of,the,top 3 porters I have had to date lovely all aroumd

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2004 Black with a big brown head. Aroma of malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavor of coffee and some smoke. Finish of strong bitter coffee. Really thick and malty just the way I like this style.

On Tap: Served to cold, but easily remedied with time.  Dark black color, with ruby hues.  Thin creamy carmel colored head.  Sweet coffee notes.  A little bit of carbonation.  Pretty good porter, sweeter, like I like them.

Bottle pours pitch black, small tannish head, fairly sticky lacing.   Aroma is of unsweetened chocolate and burnt malts.   Forwardly chocolatey (unsweetened and dry), with a good malt profile.   Slight coffee flavor on the finish.   Quite enjoyable.   Thanks goes out to MarkR for the trade!

Nice dark brown color,small brown head that faded slowly leaving a nice lace behind.The aroma was malty and chocolatey with a decent hop presence.The flavor was chocolate and mild coffee with a good amount of hops and nice roasty flavor.Very nice brew and it makes me wish i had more for later.Thanks to Jsquire for sending this brew my way.

Thanks to alcfron for the trade. Pours beautifully, flat opaque black with a thick chocolate milk-colored head that dissipated but not too quickly. Nice thick lacing too. The aroma is strong coffee and roasted malt. Medium-bodied, and unfortunately the flavor is not as robust as the look and smell. Bitter coffee and burnt malt flavors dominate, but the balance is a little too much on the bitter side. The finish is fairly bitter with coffee and some chocolate. Overall a pretty good Porter, it just needs better balance.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2016 Pours dark black with some red when held up to light.  Aroma is chocolate malt.  Flavor is chcolate,coffee and malt but all to the extreme!  The flavor hits you and stands out, one of the better porters ive had.
This is one of the best Porters Ive had.  Color, aroma, and top notch flavor are simple and successful in creating happiness.  The chocolate & coffee flavor is rich, yet smooth and easy to drink.

Dark beer with brown head that quickly became a lasting ring around the glass.  Roasted grain nose.  Lots of coffee bean roastiness and nice hop bitterness.  Clean and dry finish with a subtle, pleasant lingering coffee bitterness.  Very nice porter.
Yummy.  This is a very roasty porter, low hop nose.  Balanced, though, so it isn't too sweet.  Great stuff.
Black with a little bit of red.  Full of soft chocolate and roasted coffee.  Quite robust and smooth.  Hoppy enough to keep the crystal malts in check.  Very easy to knock back a few of these.

garnet red color shines through up to the light, otherwise almost black. no head to speak of. aroma is mostly roasty coffee, maybe a little chocolate and lactose. flavor is roasty and creamy as hell. yep...this thing is good.

Another nice beer from Founders.  Dark brown/black - can't really see thru it - thin ring of foam from begining to end.  It starts off smooth and sweet, and as it warms, it gains a nice roasty bitterness - not a lot, just enough, then finishes mostly dry with a tiny bit of sweet and roast.  This is an easy drinking session porter.

Dark black in color with lots of yeast floating around, small and creamy tan head that leaves a good lacing, roasty chocolaty malty aroma. Roasted malty chocolate and coffee flavors, nice dry burnt bitterness in the finish, a good porter I would like to try again.
Pours like 10W40 (and I mean that in a good way).  Enticing look of black opaque body and thick tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and coffe roasted together.  Rich mocha flavor.  Excellent brew.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2011 A very nice looking porter, black with a large, rich, medium brown head.  Head fades a bit too quickly for top marks.  Nose is also nice, with both roast and chocolate qualities.  Flavor is very much dominated by bitter roasted flavors, leaving the chocolate to the background.  A nice porter, overall.    

RE-RATE: Though Ive had this out of a bottle, previously, I was able to sample it on draught and it was a different brew.  More pronounced chocolate flavors throughout.  Quite delicious really and a bit more polished than the bottled version.

Deep reddish brown hue with good frothy head abd very good lace. The aroma hints of nuts, mocha, molasses, smoke, coffee and aromatic hops. The taste is mostly bittersweet chocolate and acidic fruit with a nice touch of smoky dryness upon the finish. While the body is thin, the mouthfeel is still creamy and smooth. An excellent porter with all the qualities I look for. Complex enough for the beer geek, smooth enough to drink 2 or 3 of in one night.

On draft at brewpub.  Sat black and opaque in the glass topped with a thick and creamy tan head.  Mild smokey malt aroma.  Flavor of burnt molasses and chocolate malts with a bitter hop finish.  Full bodied and creamy carbonation - nice porter!
GABF '03 Intense full bodies beer.Rich and malty,with a roasted and chocolate note.

Oil black body with rim remnants of a nicely tanned head. Smells like chocolate malts, coffee, toffee. It tastes awesome, almost a cross between a porter and an Imperial Stout. Wonderful burnt marshmallow flavor, coffee and deep dark chocolate. It has a hoppy finish. Like the bottle says it is dark, rich, and sexy. Great Porter.

One definition for porter is "janitor," which I do say is a fitting epithet for a style lurking in the shadow of its elder sibling, the stout.  That said, this porter is a nice addition to the Founders line.  Dark and malty, with a rich roasted/burnt aroma and flavor of coffee and chocolate.  If you like this porter, hit the brewery and try the Breakfast Stout if it is available; the stout is like a supercharged version of this porter.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2003 roasted coffee aroma, dark, mirky appearance. Tastes a little malty with a strong chocolate/coffee flavor. Not an outstanding porter, but not that bad.  Like the bottle says, its 'sexy'.

Great creamy mouthfeel, an exercise in chocolate malting, great hoppy balance, hits the finish on the lips wonderfully. The perfect session porter, as something like Fuller's would get too thick and sweet I think, after a while.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Roasted chocolatey nose hovering above the rich black body.  The initial flavor is somewhat unnoticeable, covered by the robust palate which finishes smooth and malty with almost a burnt aftertaste.  Goes down remarkably smooth for its viscosity.  A very good porter.

Weird first porter that I can smell the roast malt.  Very dark in appears.  Taste like a chocolate stout to me.  Very drinkable.  Love hops but I cant taste them at all.  I think this beer would be a good one to age.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2009 Dark brown with a thick dirty head, this is a tasty brew
Some burnt/roasted notes on the nose; dry & bitter on the palate. A nice, tasty porter.
If Im homesick, its for this brew. Chocolate, toasty, man, I want it to snow here.
This was a decent porter. Could have been alittle more malty.  About the same quality as an Edmund Fitzgerald.

Since this beer caused at least one rater to muse on Michigans best porters, Ill weigh in here, too.  The best porter in Michigan, imo, is Arcadias eccentric London Porter.  Equally eccentric and interesting, though a touch rougher around the edges is Dark Horses Black.  That leaves this beer and Bells Porter lagging behind in third and fourth: more mundane, hop tinged affairs - decent, darkly edged, and satisfying but - well, not unusual enough to reach the top echelon of the peninsulas porters.
Nice coffee and chocolate malt taste. A nice amount of hops also. This is  a solid porter.
Dark brown color, roasted cholate malt taste with coffeeish undertones, nice hop finish a very nice beer
Black appearance.  Some roast aroma.  Bitter palate, some roast.  A solid example.

What a great thing to find hidden in my brother-in-laws fridge!  He didnt know where it camve from, but I sure enjoyed it!  Compares nicely with Bells and Guiness.  A bit sweeter and more chocolate then Guiness. It ranks high on my list!
A very smooth Porter with a nice before/after flavor.
Really good for a local American porter.  Worth a try if youre in the midwest
Pretty good.  I enjoyed this yet my tasting girls didnt as much.
Although not the best porter in Michigan (Bells is) it is still good.  Nice proportionment of chocolate malt
